GAME: Carcassonne
RANK: 138
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Light and simple, it's good as a gateway game and with the right mood (no deep thinking, just easy going tile placement) can be a pleasant filler once in a while. Quite simply, it never really caught my heart, wearing down quickly. The luck factor can be a problem, further exalted by a high number of players, but most of all its limited depth simply doesn't appeal my inner meeple, I suppose. And, of course, my overall feeling about this game is not even remotely biased by the fact that, the last time I played, a pretty lady heavily kicked my rear end twice in a row. 

RGG edition w/ River included. Tiles are sturdy and with a simple yet nice artwork, same goes for the scoreboard (large but going only to 50, not enough for a typical Carcassone game but also not a big problem, anyway). And then there are the meeples! Cute, highly symbolic for modern eurogaming, absolutely needed (and great) to keep yourself occupied during downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't know if it is because I own only the basic game but it feels a little dry to me. I like the easy to teach factor.

Creo que es obligado para sobre todo familias.

RATING: 7
Our beloved gateway game that sucked us into geekdom a few years ago. The quintessential Euro game and, IMHO, infinitely preferable to Settlers!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fairly light tile-laying game.  Random factor due to single tile playing.  But optimal play each turn is quite difficult to determine.  Farmers seem to be the key to winning, unless you get into a "Farmer war", then the city builder will win.

Just played this with 6 players and the Princess & Dragon and The Tower expansions.  They turned a nice game into something very nasty.  It was also highly random due to the 6 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Visually appealing and a very good entry level game if you can get people to understand the farmer scoring. All the expansions add some more bells and whistles but the game really is good enough on its own

RATING: 8
An easy to start game when you are new to boardgame. With the simple game mechanics, the play is mostly depended on the lucky draw tiles, strategic tile placement, and resources (meeple) management. While the game is fun when having more than 3 players, the game itself is very predictable on 2 players (given you can memorized all tiles)

Good to play with 3 or more players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I fundamentally love Carcassonne; it's as placid or as cut-throat as you want it to be, one of the few games I've known which fits that bill. As an added bonus, it's a tile laying game (which I love for some irrational reason, maybe the building aspect, dunno). Best played with around 2, maybe 3 expansions at a time and that's it. (Almost always I&C, T&B, and one other that gets changed out periodically). One requirement is having a hand though, if I can have a hand of 3 or 5 tiles to choose from and draw at the end of my turn, it's great. As the rules are, the order of draw and place saps the game for me too much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcasssonne is our go-to for bringing new people into the gaming fold. Simple enough to teach quickly. Good replayability. We almost always play with at least a couple of expansions, though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the game that got me into gaming in 2008. It has the right balance of luck and strategy and is infinitely replayable. My kids enjoy it immensely though my wife finds that there is too much strategy for her. The expansions (especially Inns and Catherdrals & Traders & Builders) add a lot to the game as well. If you purchase the game, make sure it includes the River expansion. If it does not then you MUST buy it. It makes the game start so much better.

I also recommend King and Scout as well as the Princess and Dragon expansions. They add new challenges to the game that are fun. With all of these expansions though you are talking about at least a two hour game so make sure you set aside the time. I love it!

RATING: 7
2-5 players, the expansion Inns&Cathedrals brings in the 6th player. Suitable for a wide age range and can be played casually or tactically. You can ally to finish roads and/or towns together, or can try to outnumber the opponent and take all the points. The expansions Inns&Cathedrals and Traders&Builders are recommended and they add more scoring elements and more tiles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne is a tile-laying classic that is one of our favorite games to introduce to new players, as well as a cut-throat two player slugfest between my wife and me. In Carcassonne, you are drawing tiles and laying them on the board in such a way that they connect smoothly with what's already been placed. 

You score points by building roads, cities, and monasteries out of the tiles you place. It's a simple concept, it's easy to explain, but there's a surprising amount of strategy and competition in this small game. 

My wife has proven to be incredible at this, always trashing me when we play with farmers, and often swooping in to steal my large cities when they're half-finished. I rarely win, though I often make it at least competitive. 

There are a few beefs with the game: most notably, without a hand of tiles to pick from, you really are reduced to luck of the draw. Additionally, monasteries can be a bit over-powered in the base game, and in a 2-player game the result will often tilt to whoever can draw the most monasteries. 

Carcassonne doesn't do all that much, but what it does, it does well. This is a great introductory game that has players competing to grab good spaces on the modular board. Carcassonne is a classic that I can't besmirch: it's well worth the little money it costs! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Carcassonne is perfect if you are looking for a strategy game that you can explain to friends in less than 5 minutes.  Very simple to understand, but still a lot of strategy involved.  

The big trade-offs in Carcassonne involve investing for the short-term vs the long-term.  Thieves have an easy short-term payoff.  Cities can involve short-term, mid-term, or long-term planning, depending on your preferences.  Farmers are the the definite long-term strategy, and if played well, players can rack up significant points with them. 

In most cases, it's unwise to play all short-term or all long-term; it's a game where you have to find a balance.  If you go all long-turn, you'll miss huge opportunities that come along.  If you go all short-term, you can get burned at the end. 

And yet in spite of all that strategy, it's fairly simple to explain and understand.  One of my favorites. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(From Big Box 2009.)

2010-04-14 (rating 8):

The game is great! The rules are simple (not counting some bizarre expansions interactions) and yet the game is challenging and fun.

It can be played aggressively or calmly so should fit many needs. Due to large number of expansions a lot of options is available and the game scales well with used time (just a base game is short, all the expansions are long - it is easy to choose a combination which fits needs and available time very well).

However playing just the base game especially in more than 3 players may become somewhat boring and a bit too random after some time. But again the expansions are there so no problem!


Currently I prefer to use [gameid=45748] as the base game. Also I am testing a variant where one draws 3 tiles selects one and discards the rest back to the pool. This way the game is less random.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
my fave game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2008-07-10
This was my introduction to boardgaming along with Illuminati. Still enjoying it.

2016-02-08
In many ways I regard Carcassonne one of the most versatile games of all time that fits almost any situation or group. It can be played with novices, kids and hardcore gamers alike. It takes only about 45-60 minutes, which you usually have at your disposal. There is a significant amount of skill involved but the luck of draw makes every game different and gives the less experienced players a chance. The game scales to all player numbers, although the more players the more chaotic and luck driven it becomes.

For its graphical design, Carcassone is great with all the necessary information clearly visible. The rules are fairly simple, except for the scoring of fields, and this is my biggest criticism towards the game. It is just a pain in the ass to figure out who has the majority for each city and it is even more difficult to explain this to new player, especially since most of the people who are new to Carcassonne are rather green with boardgames in general. The solution they came up with in Carcassonne Hunters and Gatherers is much more elegant and intuitive.

Another minor thing with C is that once two players share a city or a road, neither of them has an incentive close it, especially in two player games. This has also been fixed in Carcassonne H&G by introducing the gold nuggets and bonus tiles into the game.

Carcassonne can also be expanded with a myriad of expansions. Personally I deem the base game the best with maybe the one or two of the first expansions thrown in at max. You still want to have a rather compact experience and using too many expansions will just make to whole game too convoluted and away from all the fun.

I'll be happy to play Carcassonne any time but my personal choice is the H&C version of the game, since the problems have been fixed in it and H&G needs no expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Whilst this is a good game, it's far from being the best of the Carcassonne series.  It's historical importance to gaming is large and I will normally be up for a game of it, since it's a lot of fun (esp if you play with everyone always having a tile in hand to speed it up). Hunters and Gatherers is a better game because the forests are less fiddly than the cities, the rivers allow for better scoring than the roads, and (most importantly), the meadows are not likely to be as sprawling as the farms.

But, let's be clear here - this is the first of a series of superb gateway games.  I'd rank the best of the series right up there with Ticket to Ride - and much better than Settlers (but then again, I don't like Settlers at all, so I'm biased there). Art is good and to play it at its best you need to throw in at least a couple of expansions - esp with 4/5 players.  TBH though, this is better with 2-4 players.

I will state though that even on the first play, I did see a problem with the  the endgame in particular. Despite not having any Cloister tiles in a four player game (and thus lagging behind as those tiles are a real boon to pick up), I still won because at the end, I drew a tile I needed to connect an extra meeple to a HUGE farm that I was equalling the control of. This enabled me to win the game, scoring a decisive 40 points.

It seems to me that at the end, you can either draw such a lucky tile, or you can draw rubbish.  Similarly, if you draw no Cloisters and then also draw badly at the end, you will have no chance of winning.

So, I enjoy the game, BUT H and G IS more balanced and better at the end and The Castle is more cerebral (although it's only 2 player).  Haven't tried The City, but that may well be wonderful...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Wow... just wow.  I played this for the first time today.  Honestly, just from hearing what the game would be about, I wasn't too keen on it.  Building cities? Connecting roads?  Gah, boring!  But now that I've played it, I don't even remember what I thought of it before... it has been erased with the awesome that is the game.

Sure, I didn't win, it was only my first time playing, but it is exactly the type of quick game I like to play - the laying of the map tiles is very much like a puzzle, and I was able to screw-up my husband, not once, but twice with a single river placement.  That alone made the game for me.  Well, that and messing up another one of his cities later in the game...

I really like games that have a visual matching aspect - probably because that is my strong suit.  Anyway, long story short, I now need this game, so that I may thwart others in the building of their cities and cloisters!

So, my husband and I had a rematch.  He was well prepared!  I was winning for most of the game, but at the very end he surpassed me with with farms!  Gah!  Now we will have to play again...

RATING: 7
Great tactical euro game that looks deceptively simple. The only real weaknesses are the lack of theme and variety once the main mechanics and tactics have been learnt. Also, to play the game well you need to learn the tile distribution somewhat.  The expansions are hit and miss, and some players will get frustrated by the tile draw.  Put a bidding mechanic in for tiles, e.g. suburbia, and it's a much better game.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Do you remember your friends from kindergarten? Remember how you couldn't wait to leave the house in the morning because you were still working on that airplane to fly to the moon, or to see that invisible squirrel again, or to finally convince Ms. Miller that beans actually can grow out of children's ears? Do you remember how you were entirely convinced that life will always stay that way and you will always be friends, solving the worlds mysteries together?

And do you still see your friends from kindergarten? Well, to be honest, I don't. My kindergarten friends were great, while I was at kindergarten age. Life was simple. Planes that were made of cardboard were able to fly you to the moon (and back). But by now, life is more complicated, and suddenly cardboard airplanes are ... well ... basically just the cardboard wrapping that came with new fridge. 
It is the same with Carcassonne (and Settlers of Catan, really, I don't see a difference). It was great starting with those games, they defined a whole new world while that world was new. But by now, so many other great games are out there, and Carcassonne and Settlers are ... just cardboard. Nice, lovely cardboard full of good old memories, but basically just cardboard.

Oh, screw it. I admit I do miss that squirrel.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
There isn't much to say about this game that hasn't been said by everyone else already. RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great zen masterpiece. Essentially a puzzle you play and score, Carcassonne is an easy to learn, simple game great for newbies or anyone looking for a light and enjoyable quick-playing title. The River addition provides a nice starting point and "trunk" for the map to build off of. I have yet to meet anyone who didn't grok and enjoy Carcassonne within 5 minutes (it probably takes less than that to explain the rules in full). It isn't Pandemic or Twilight Struggle, but there IS still strategy, and an experienced player will squash new players most of the time.

RATING: 7.3
1,000฿ (มือ2)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pick a tile, place the tile and decide whether to place a meeple or not - only at the tile just placed. Also, a meeple can only be placed on an area without any other meeple connected to it. Choose the meeple's role - either a thief, knight, monk or a farmer. Score points by completing certain requirements and also taking back the meeple - each player only has 7 meeples.

Think strategically before placing the meeple. Or else, player may end up with no meeple. Also, high chances to sabotage another player by either not letting them take back their meeple, sharing the scoring with another player or totally snatch the player's score away.

Smart and unique game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Muller Exklusiv Edition

Carcassonne is a light game. It doesn't offer a great strategical depht but surely some cool tactical choises. The luck-factor is clearly there, but the skills of the player are still predominant in my opinion. Yet... what I enjoy the most about Carcassonne is watching the landscape take form as the game progresses. I like seeing "what we built" at the end of the game, before putting the tiles back in the box. 

Overall a nice little gateway game that I enjoy. After a 20+ plays I still like it, but it seems that I'm less and less interested in playing it...

Rating without the expansions: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the old time favourites. It is the father of tile placement games, with easy to grasp rules. You simply pick a tile and place it. The tile might feature a city, a road, a cloister, grassland or some combination thereof, and it must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played, in such a way that cities are connected to cities, roads to roads, etc. Then you may place on of your meeple and score or hoping that you will score later on. No wonder it is one of the biggest seller boardgames.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.4
I don't rate expansions nor log plays.  I consider them part of the base game.  Perhaps I'll change my view once BGG stops listing them as if they are separate games.
Expansions owned:  Inns & Cathedrals, King & Scout, Princess & Dragon, The River, The Tower, Traders & Builders
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Even though the theme is the quintessential quaint, the clean colours and emerging pastoral setting is a joy to behold. Each tile feels like an opportunity and the shared act of creation always makes me feel warm at the end of each game!

Mechanically, there's much more going on here than most people see. Quick scoring seems best, but this is a game of investment and particularly a game that shines when players 'speculate' by trying to share features. Farming can be a little hard to understand at first, but it provides a necessary strategic element and high-level risk appraisal in permanently placing workers. 

Dynamically, this game is an investment game. It might mitigate a lot of the risk with seven workers, but that's exactly what I want to be able to play with friends and family. So many other games with this dynamic are all-or-nothing or involve intense diplomacy; Carcassonne is a game where you can just plod along making a pretty landscape or play hard and share or block other player's development proposals. 

Overall, this is a deserving legend of boardgaming. It was probably my gateway game (at least, it was the first game I played when interested in board gaming as a hobby as an adult). I think most people have played it, but it's still a winner with most people who haven't been exposed to modern board game designs.

HOW I LIKE TO PLAY: I prefer 2er, where we only play with [thing=2993][/thing]. I'll extend to three players with [thing=2591][/thing] for a less provocative game, if we're new to gaming ;). Beyond three players, it's a bit too tactical for mine, but for an easy evening with casual gamers, this is an absolute go-to game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
[With River, River II, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Count, King & Scout, the Phantom]

It's a fine game, we sure have played plenty.  Hunters and Gatherers may be a bit more elegant, though.

So, the base game + Traders & Builders or Inns & Cathedrals is LONG, too long for what it is.  The base alone has too few city tiles, making luck of the draw too important, even for this.

BUT, for two players, base + King (from King & Scout) gives a light, fun game -- less thinky and deep than Hunters & Gatherers, but more relaxing, perhaps.  Thanks to sister-in-law for leading us to figure that out.

Hrm, update:  K&S is too luckish once you both are playing well (yeah, took me a while).  So, what to do?  Carc is good, but maybe not so good as we thought, once you are used to it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Interesting tile placing game to build a map of cities, roads, churches and farms.  Have only played the basic game but I think that the core idea of the game is unique.

By placing different tiles, your 'worker' can become 4 different characters in the game: namely farmer, knights, monks or bandits.  With different coniditons met, points are scored and your 'workers' will go back to your pool and ready to be dispatched again.

Good points: Innovative gameplay, balanced between strategising on where to place the tiles and luck to get the tiles you need to score.

Bad points: Can be irritating if you cannot get the tiles you need.  A bit too little 'workers' in the game to be placed on the tiles.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If you're thinking of checking out the "Eurogame" style, this is probably the best place to start in my opinion. The game is one where you lay out tiles on a table which have pictures on them of fields, roads, cities etc and claim those features with your "meeples" (little wooden men, from "my people" - yes I am a geek) you score points depending on the size of each road, city etc and get your man back when it is scored, so you are having to balance high points scoring areas with having less men to place. It is true genius.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I recently purchased the "Big Box 2" edition (2009) that contains: original Carcassonne game, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, The Princess & the Dragon, Abbey & Mayor, The River II, and Count, King, and Cult. (The River is not included in this version!) However, grooven does recall that we found the original River to be broken, so maybe it's not great loss that it's not included in this collection. I got this because each expansion is marked with special symbols to make them easy to distinguish for separation after a game. And I'm enamoured by the prospect of separating and storing all the game bits neatly in one box! Based on BGG comments, I don't think that I'd care for Princess & Dragon and The Tower. 

UPDATE 1: Extremely happy about getting the Big Box, since I have fond memories attached to the base game plus Inns and Cathedrals that involve my bf, chilled beer, summer breeze, my parent's dining room table, and our introduction to BGG and board games. 

UPDATE 2: My excuse for getting the Big Box was to introduce it to my parents. We played the base game without the farmers because my dad was impatient with listening to the rules and keeping saying "let's play! let's play! let's get started. let's go!" in that childish way of his... hey wait... grooven... My dad ended up winning with 69 points, my mom with 50, and the two gamers in the house with less than 50 points. Bah! 

2015 UPDATE: I might be regretting getting the Big Box as I haven't played any of the expansions in it. I think I will consider getting an updated version of Carcassonne and scrapping the Big Box as it takes up a big amount of shelf space!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Carcassonne was a blind buy after Settlers of Catan was becoming the staple game at my house. I wanted something new and refreshing that had the replay value of Settlers. I had not heard about Board Game Geek at the time of this purchase and my confidence in this title came from reading customer reviews of Settlers on Amazon.com and other vendor sites.

Carcassonne has since become my favorite "gateway game". Much like Alhambra, I love this game with four or less. Two is obviously this best, three is good. Four is manageable and anymore than that is purely when I am playing with non-gamers. Carcassonne has won over so many people into acknowledging that boardgames are a great way to pass the time.

Add to that the game has numerous GREAT expansions which make it completely customizable and you have the makings of a top 10 game for me. I love this game.

RATING: 10

We stack up all the tiles and grab the number of stacks we want to play and usually have 3-4 Games of varying lengths lined up.  If playing head to head with my bother we have been  known to play 8 games in an evening.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Carcassonne is a tile-placement game in which the players draw and place a tile with a piece of southern French landscape on it. The tile might feature a city, a road, a cloister, grassland or some combination thereof, and it must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played, in such a way that cities are connected to cities, roads to roads, etcetera. Having placed a tile, the player can then decide to place one of his meeples on one of the areas on it: on the city as a knight, on the road as a robber, on a cloister as a monk, or on the grass as a farmer. When that area is complete, that meeple scores points for its owner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Farms are absolutely essential in the base game and it can get annoying how hyper-focused the game gets on farms (which are not even an interesting feature on the map!). The game is basically won or lost via farms most of the time with city heavy strategies only being competitive out of sheer, dumb luck.

Roads and monasteries are purely pick-up points on the side mechanics. You play on roads when you have nothing better to do. You play on monasteries when you're lucky enough to randomly draw one. Monasteries have a mite of strategy to doing well. But road and monastery tiles are MOSTLY relevant depending upon how much they might impact your farms!

Carc is fine, but it feels pretty same-y pretty fast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Carcassonne was my gateway game, followed quickly by Puerto Rico. It's a good gateway game, because it introduces players to a modular board, and of course has fun little meeples.  And what would BGG be like without meeples!  Playing with more than 3 throws too much chaos into the mix for my taste, and makes the game drag out too long (I know, there's the same number of tiles you're playing through).  Playing with the 3 tiles in hand, play, draw variant is a good way to cut down on the randomness.

RATING: 7
My rating should probably be higher on this one, but my group isn't a huge fan of it.  It's a fun, simple game that can be either light and pleasant or mid-weight and cutthroat depending on the table - which is unusual.  Surprisingly deep for how simple the rules are, and plays pretty quick.  It does take a lot of table space, has a gajillion expansions (most of which aren't great), and has a woefully inadequate score track.

RATING: 6.5
I don't own this game as a few of my friends do so I usually get to play it on a fairly regular basis at their houses. I enjoy the game quite a bit but have yet to really delve into the expansions which seem to add an extra degree of complexity to the main game. 

I've played one which I forget now (I think it was the builder) as well as the River expansion and they were quite good. Playing with "The Tower" on the other hand was a miserable experience. Carcassonne with too many expansions is a bloated mess in my opinion. The simpler the better!

My only gripe is that I always seem to pick the wrong tile I need - but I'm sure 99.9% of other people are in the same situation!

Good game!

RATING: 8
A nice straightforward game of tile placement.
Players take it in turns to place tiles to create an ever expanding land, players also place meeples to lay claim to castles, roads and fields. Points are gained when a city or road gets completed and at the end of the game when the fields get counted up.
Nice and simple mechanics but with a good amount of strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Includes:
[thing=2591]The River[/thing]
[thing=2993]Inns & Cathedrals[/thing]
[thing=5405]Traders & Builders[/thing]
[thing=45748]Wheel of Fortune[/thing]
[thing=153773]Hills & Sheep[/thing]

:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
This game popularized the now-ubiquitous meeple and remains a great time even after I've played lots of heavier fare. Pick up a tile and lay it down, slowing creating lovely bits of the countryside, like roads, cities, farms, and monasteries.  Committing meeples to incomplete projects ties them up until the project is finished, meaning that enterprising enemies can block you in, cutting your chances of completing and abandoning your meeples on the board. Points are awarded for completed projects, and expansions add additional elements like big meeples, shepherds, bonuses for scoring roads and cities, and lots of very cooky (but fun!) stuff.

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
There is something just utterly satisfying and cathartic about building the eventual sprawl of the French countryside which I can't find in any other game. Tile laying is enjoyable just for being tile laying, but the simple set of rules built around it, such as committing meeples and attempting to snipe projects started by other players, makes it especially interesting.

This is still my preferred gateway game.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
The obsession to play nasty. This game can be really rough if your intention is to shut down your opponents. I honestly like it the most when it's played more passively. I'm not going to give my opponents the tiles they need at no benefit to myself, but I'm not out to get them.

:arrowE: [size=13][url=https://play.spotify.com/user/jwilliamparkin/playlist/4JWklYt2KW8sDMigv8aORx][b]PLAYLIST[/b][/url][/size]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

I find this game scales so well, it works exceedingly well with two players, and still handles five players easily, albeit chaotically.  Excellent first choice as a gateway game for newbies.

RATING: 8
Very good game. Takes only a five minutes to explain the rules and one or two play throughs to adopt the them. With maximum number of six players and with one or two add ons this game still takes only about one and half hour. About 30-45 minutes with two to three players.

The game board is made up placing square tiles one at a time by each player so the game board will always different. I liked the art work very much, it's simple, beautiful and functional. Basic rules are simple and each add on adds an extra set of rules, which will all fit together with the basic game or with any other add on. Although, playing for example with six add ons youd better move the game from table onto the floor to make sure there is enough space and playing with six sets of rules can make a game a bit complicated.

RATING: 6
I have to say that I find the "can't join an occupied feature, but it's OK to start a new one with the blatant object of joining them together" rule/mechanic/strategy irritatingly artificial.
Why not just allow shared features:  if you're stupid enough to tie up all your meeples in a majority battle you should be allowed to?  I don't think it would make the game any worse.

RATING: 8
Still the best tile placement game as its success is in its simplicity. It's pure tile placement with no background noise to muddle it. Pick a tile place a tile and/or place a meeple on that tile. 

There are far too many expansions. If you add in too many expansions can make it too convoluted and the play time too long and thus take away from what makes Carcassonne great.

A couple of expansions at a time is best.

:star::star::star::star::nostar: Artwork

RATING: 9
Still the best tile placement game as its success is in its simplicity. It's pure tile placement with no background noise to muddle it. Pick a tile place a tile and/or place a meeple on that tile. 

There are far too many expansions. If you add in too many expansions can make it too convoluted and the play time too long and thus take away from what makes Carcassonne great.

A couple of expansions at a time is best.

RATING: 8.5
Carcassone is THE classic tile laying game.
And it still is a lot of fun to play.
Easy to teach and to play and to look to result.
Got a real revival for me when played with the familie in 2014.
Also not too bad as a solitaire puzzle.
The Android version is also good (I don't know if as good as the IOS version, but for me it is ok).
Played it also very often on the PC.
___________________
\_______GER_______/
Habe Carcassonne früher auch häufig als PC-Spiel gespielt. Und jetzt ab und zu als Androidversion zum Solospielen.
Mit echten Mitspielern ist es doch immer noch interessanter.
Nach Ankauf der [thing=5405] 2ten Erweiterung Händler und Baumeister[/thing] sind die Karten in den blauen Stoffbeutel gekommen. Ich finde das Ziehen aus dem Beutel am praktischsten. Umgedreht auf dem Tisch braucht man sehr viel Platz, den man eigentlich zum Auslegen benötigt. Den Turm aus der 4ten Erweiterung [thing=21385]Der Turm[/thing] finde ich dagegen nicht wirklich praktisch (der Turm als Kartenhalter sieht halt nur interessant aus). 
Am meisten Spaß macht mir das Spiel zu zweit (maximal zu viert) Mit mehr als 4 Spielern wird es schon sehr unplanbar und man muss auch zu lange warten bis man selber wieder dran ist. 
Eine interessante Hausregel ist das Ziehen von insgesamt 3 Handkarten pro Zug. Dadurch kann man im Prinzip etwas besser planen und ist somit nicht ganz vom Ziehglück abhängig.

Die folgenden Erweiterungen habe ich standard in das Grundspiel integriert: 
[thing=2591]Der Fluss[/thing] diese kleine Mini-Erweiterung gab es als Beigabe zum PC-Spiel. Die Flusskarten sehen schön aus, ändern das Grundspiel aber nicht dramatisch. Da diese Karten eine andere Rückseite haben sind sie leicht heraus zu sortieren.

Die [thing=2993]1te Erweiterung Wirtshäuser und Kathedralen[/thing] (7.5) bringt keine dramatischen neuen Regeln, hauptsächlich mehr Karten. Die Wirtshäuser sind ganz nett als Zusatzpunkte bei geringem Risiko. Die beiden Kathedralen können zwar eine Menge Extrapunkte geben haben aber auch ein grössere Risiko wenn man die Stadt nicht abschließen kann (dann gibt es gar kein Punkte).  Der große Meeple pro Spieler ist ein zusätzliches taktisches Element das gut ist.

Die [thing=5405] 2te Erweiterung Händler und Baumeister[/thing] (7.5) wird in vielen Reviews als die beste bzw. sinnvollste Erweiterung für das Grundspiel beschrieben. Der große Stoffbeutel ist eine nette und sinnvolle Beigabe, es passen alle Karten vom Grundspiel und alle von mir verwendeten meine standard Erweiterungen rein.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
There's a reason this game is considered a "Euro classic". Simple rules, quick to play, a little luck on the tile draw, but a good helping of strategy as well.
The resulting map alone is often beautiful to look at.

While it's not one of my absolutely top-favorite games, I consider the game design itself a stroke of genius.
And it's relatively easy to bring to the table. Many people like to play it.

This is the whole perfect lot of Carcassonne for a fun and disputed game between or among experienced or newbie players (it plays well with two or more players, but it changes quite a bit, ... with a higher number of players it gets more strategical because each player has fewer tiles to deploy thus less chances to score).

-[b]Impresión[/b]: :halfstar:
-[b]Mecánicas[/b]::star:
-[b]Aspecto[/b]: :halfstar:
-[b]¿Lo volverías a jugar?[/b]: :halfstar:
-[b]Opinión personal[/b]: :halfstar:

Fácil de entender, aunque la puntuación final puede ser un engorro de calcular.
Si no te dedicas a "interactuar" (aka fastidiar) a los opnonentes, puede resultar un poco soso.
Producción: buena, losetas de calidad, ilustaciones muy claras.
Compra: Si quieres tener un juego fácil de sacar a mesa con no jugadores que tengan interés.

RATING: 8.8
Carcassonne quickly became my go-to game almost immediately after I bought it.  I play with lots of people who are unfamiliar with the gaming hobby, and this is the perfect introductory game.  The rules are very simple to explain and there is almost no set up.  You can literally be playing this game five minutes after a "non-gamer" sees the box and tries to pronounce "Carcassonne".  Despite it's simplicity, there is plenty of strategy to keep the game interesting.  

My initial rating after a few plays was a 6.5, but I have bumped it up substantially the more I have played it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This game is a much, much better 2 player game than 3-5 player game. 3-5 player games are almost entirely decided by luck. 2 player games are much less luck--skill is rewarded at a much higher rate, and strategy is very important. I'd give this game an 8.5 as a two player game, a 6.5 as a three player game, a 5 as a 4 player game, and 3 as a five player game.

RATING: 6
Got this as a less-cutthroat game for Co and I to play together. Pretty fun - strategy seems pretty deep. Want to try it with more than two people, but it seems to play pretty well with 2. 

Will probably be picking up the expansions eventually.

The beauty in this game lies in it's simplicity. There are only a few basic rules you need to know, and yet the expanding map has an aesthetic appeal that makes the game pleasing to play.

I'm wondering why this hasn't hit the table at our gaming days with the group yet. I'm thinking that it will be a great way to let people cool down in between games of BSG and other cuththroat games (thereby making the wives more likely to want to play.)

Strongly weighted toward tactical decisions and no hidden information, so it works well with a young or new player as everyone can help them. That also means one person can play four or five colors solitaire and not give up the feel of the multi-player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
This game is very simple. Draw a tile, place one of your pieces (a follower) on that tile, then score for points. That's just it.

+ very simple, few rules
+ has expansions
+ not a lot of downtime
+ 2 to 6 players (and really works with 2)
+ looks good on the table

- very luck based (you don't have any control over what you draw)
- when you draw a bad tile you can't do anything
- no reward for finishing someone else's road or castle.
- not much player interaction. 

thankfully some (-) were corrected with some of the expansions.

Owned as part of the carcassonne big box 3.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Elismerem, hogy szép és precízen megalkotott játék, amit bemelegítő játéknak el tudok képzelni. Ha jól tudom, ez egy műfajteremtő darab, ez volt az első ilyenfajta lapka-lepakolgatós játék, ezt is díjazom. Ennek ellenére nem tartom egy nagy durranásnak, és nem tudom elképzelni, hogy ezzel mondjuk évi 1-nél többször játsszak. Amikor kaptam (2005), még elég kevés játékot ismertem ahhoz, hogy tetsszen a Carcassone, ma viszont már olyan sok jobb játékot ismerek, hogy ez számomra elveszik a szürke középmezőnyben. Viszont van két kiegészítőm is, amiket még nem próbáltam, azokra kíváncsi vagyok!
---
Kipróbáltam a kiegekkel is, így jobb!
---
Kipróbáltam egyszerre 8 kieggel. Tetszett, hogy a sok szabály révén kicsit összetettebb volt, mint az alapjáték, de azért a hossza miatt kicsit sok volt ez így nekem. Lehet, hogy egy életre kipipáltam ezzel a Carcassone-t, elég volt belőle:)

RATING: 7
Nice one to play with kids. Does not return to the table much these days though...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Combined base game, Big Box and expansion to make huge game.

+ Great gateway game. A good way to introduce new gamers, and slowly up the depth and difficulty with expansions.
+ Fun with 2
+ Expansions offer a lot of variability and difficulty settings

o The farmers, although seemingly simple, offer a lot of depth. (even more when adding Barns) Which is great for experienced players (I'd rather not play without) but might be difficult for beginners, or those who have trouble 'seeing' how they can expand their farmland.

- We hardly play this anymore, because with the amount of tiles we have, it takes hours to complete. We'd rather spend our time on a heavy euro. Whenever we want to have a quick 1:1 Carcassonne experience, we turn to Carcassone: Star Wars, which add a bit of direct conflict.

RATING: 3
An excellent game that just misses being considered a superb gateway game for me. Carcassone doesn't quite have the same caliber in game play as many of the typical gateway games. Overall, it tends to do better in raking in non-gamers, but it's not deep or complicated enough to push them over the edge into "real" gaming. The game is always fun to play, and the torrent of expansions do nothing but improve the game. I agree with most that there are way too many Carcassone expansions coming out way too frequently, but this can easily be eliminated by Not Buying All Of Them. Probably my favorite aspect of this game is that it is very playable with any age, from adult to teens, younger children down to two-year-olds. Fantastic.

RATING: 5
Fun, versatile game... but only if 2-3 experienced players are mixing it up with various features from multiple expansions.  I wouldn't suggest this as an entry-level game for it plays best with gamers familiar with the tiles & expansion features.  However, it really isn't a gamer's game, so I play it infrequently.

Although you can get by with just the base game, Inns & Cathedrals, and Traders & Builders, the game just wouldn't be as much fun without using one of the later expansions for the sake of variety.  However, some features from the later expansions are very annoying and/or non-essential.

RATING: 8
Top game that is easy accessible and a great intro-game, even for players that don't game too much (like my parents who otherwise only play a few card games).

It plays very well with only 2-players, but changes a lot. As a 2-player game it turns into a direct confrontation, zero-sum game which might turn some people off.
However, with more players this direct confrontation is gone and replaced with much more friendly co-building of cities and roads.

Since we own [thing=2993]Inns & Cathedrals[/thing] we always play with the expansion (although for new players we just use the tiles and ignore the additional rules)

RATING: N/A
When you find something like this at a thrift store, you just can't pass it up.  This is the 2001 edition with the river expansion.  All meeples are accounted for.  Unfortunately, one each of the following tiles are missing: D (straight road with end cap wall), J (90 degree road with end cap wall) and M (triangular city piece with pennant).  You can obviously play without those three pieces, but you may want this for extra tiles to augment your own game, or even the 40 meeples that come with it.  If no one is interested, that's fine...I'll just augment my own collection with more tiles. :-)  Game box is in fine condition.  Traded away at GameStorm14.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2001[/b]
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2001[/b]

[i]Posted: 10/2/04, Rated: 8[/i]

[i]Carcassonne[/i] is a fun game, with easy mechanics.  My five year-old (at the time of this writing) is able to play effectively.  I do have a couple of small complaints, though. The first has to do with tile memorization: when it is my turn, how I place a certain tile should be affected by my knowledge of the remaining pieces.  I feel that my understanding of the game is limited by not memorizing all of the different tile configurations with respect to roads, cities, fields, etc.  

The other complaint that I have is how overwhelmingly strong a well-placed farmer can be. In some games, I have found myself eschewing the completion of cities or monasteries, just so I could extend the reach of a single farmer. The farming score at the end of these games was obscenely large, and resulted in what appeared to be a huge come from behind win.

[i]Carcassonne[/i] can be taught to new players very quickly, and is a good introduction for those who have never played a European game before.

[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 7[/i]

[i]Carcassonne[/i] is still a good game, but it's not a "go to" title for which I would go out of my way to find a game.  Perhaps with the right blend of expansions it can still be an "8," but not on its own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game is really unlike anything else in my collection currently. It is equally good with two as it is with four. It is very rewarding to see what you and your competitors have built at the end. The first two expansions (Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders) add a lot and are probably all you'll ever need. After you get comfortable playing the game, you soon learn that there are deeper levels of play. You can be much more cutthroat in the placement of your meeples. Especially when planning on taking control of castles, etc. that your opponents are working on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fast and reliable fun with sufficient depth to be challenging. The game is remarkable in that it captures the attention of &#039;non gamers&#039; and pulls them into designer strategy games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[i][Rating for Carcassonne with River and Inns and Cathedrals expansions][/i]

Easy to learn, charming components, and elegant simplicity all in a casual (or more cut-throat, if you so desire) game for two to six (though I prefer to play with four players or fewer). The game can sometimes come down to a few critical tile draws, so chance can play a reasonably large role. Despite this, player decisions certainly contribute much more to final scores than chance, and the game [i]is[/i] intended to be a fairly lightweight family game, so I think the level of chance is appropriate. The River is a nice expansion, but Inns and Cathedrals is absolutely critical for the large follower and inns. Once I&C has been added, Carcassonne is a very nice game indeed.

Recommended 'variant': Each player has a 'hand' of one tile. The turn order is (i) Play tile; (ii) Draw new tile. This way players get to think about what their next placement is during other players' turns, reducing downtime during the active player's turn and giving each player something to think about while waiting. (2009-03; revised 2014-02)

RATING: 7
I used to play this solitaire quite a bit in college, and I love the whimsical tile art. It (the whole Carcassonne family, indeed) is a great game to play with casual gamers.

The expansions are very, very good.  Even if you use them all together.  Maybe especially if you use them all together.  Using the River II as a starter is pretty much a necessity when you combine a lot of expansions together.
  
I keep the original game around as it is a very, very light connection-style game with an innovative scoring technique---and with wonderfully whimsical art.  Non-gamers tend to like the Carcasonne series a lot, and this was one of my first Eurogames to love.

RATING: 6
Mixed feelings on this one. It is a light and pretty game, but there is not much control to it and the choices are hardly tense or deep. Not a great favourite when playing with adults, hence my pretty low rating. I would, however, give this a nine as a family title. My kids (five and seven) love it and can compete on equal terms, both with each other and with their parents. The fact that it is part of the game to have discussions about the tile placement helps a lot in this regard while the scoring is of just the right complexity to introduce the feel for Germanic titles. Also, the potential for high scoring farmers at the end of the game and the potential for some nice bits of screwage (a plus in our family!) adds a level of strategy that they can grow into as they become more familiar with it.

RATING: 6.5

At my point of view, the original game rules are boring, with no excitement. 

I am using home rules: the player who has bigger castle become a feudal and all other players add their farmers scores to feudal`s total at the end of the game. Also,the feudal may take seize of the other player(s) castle (by placing number of maples that = to number of castle tiles + number of "foreign" maples on them)  if he controls the road (maple on it) to that castle.

RATING: 3
The first modern Euro game that got me into boardgaming hobby. Played this too much in the beginning and now I don't want to play this again. This has the status of best gateway game and is easy to teach and grasp, but is by no means the best board game. I'm especially annoyed by the farmers and their endgame scoring.

Owned by friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We like to play this game with a hand of three tiles instead of being forced to place the tile you just drew. This will let you make plans several turns in advance and let you think about your next move while the other players are making their move. This makes for more fun and speeds up game play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An ok game. Initially got played very much. Was a great game to introduce new players into the gaming world. But lately it almost never gets played. It's appeal has slowly faded, though it still gets played once in a while it's just not as fun anymore.

RATING: 6
A fun tile placement game.  Farmer scoring is an issue for the first game, but we usually botch at least one rule in every game on the first try.  Knowledge of what tiles are available is a big advantage, so the game rewards repeated playings.

RATING: 8
Carcassonne is a medium weight "euro" game.  Simple, easy to understand rules that reward strategic game play.  I find that it is a very good family game to play with young children.

RATING: 8
The best part (besides infinite replayabilty) of Carcassonne is how easy it is to explain to newbies.  One of the Big 4 "gateway" games to Eurogaming.  Inns & Cathedrals is a must-buy (but you can throw out the catherdals), the Inns balance the scoring so that you aren't punished for drawing road tiles.

RATING: 9
This game is so good.

It is true that it might be a gateway game, but I feel that despite its simplicity it really caters to hardcore gamers as well (well, or at least it appeals to me).

And even though it is luck dependent, I always seem to be able to do almost whatever I want (I might have been lucky up until now).
On the plus side, I like how it can be both a rather peaceful game and a cutthroat experience.

Some expansions add a lot of depth to the game.

RATING: 8.4

Game has gone up in rating for me quite a few times as it keeps getting better and better.Big family hit!

RATING: 5
I've only played this twice and each time was quite a bit apart - when playing the game the first time, it's hard to grasp the importance of farmers and the fact that it can be quite easy to get your Meeples back.  Don't be afraid of deploying them as farmers if you can score a couple cities, I think.

A lot of your moves are also quite obvious, which makes for simplistic turns.  You know where you're going to put that tile, so now you're just waiting for your turn.

RATING: 7

--- after more plays ---
I'm actually liking this more, now. Even with 5 people, it's proving to be enjoyable. There are deals going on, threats, and groans as people play the tile you were hoping to get. 

We always play with the I&C expansion, and "hand of two tiles" variant. (Not sure I'd like to play so much otherwise....)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
When I started getting into modern board gaming, I fell hard for Carc and bought up a bunch of expansions. It's got a very special place in my heart, and really fostered my obsession with BGG as well. I still love it, but I don't get it to the table much these days. I like it best as a 2 player game. With the right players it gets deliciously vicious and cutthroat. But it's also perfect for lighter, more pleasant and carefree gaming. It's solidly tactical and lightly strategic. Sometimes feels a little too luck dependent, but usually there are enough useful choices on a tile that luck can be mitigated. I always play with Inns and Cathedrals, and then I like to mix in an additional 1-3 expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Most of the games I play now are have twice the game weight of Carcassonne, but I still love to play this game, there is something elegant about the design, this is just a fun mechanic to play.

I own the following expansions
:Abbey & Mayor :Cult, Siege and Creativity
:Bridges, Castles, and Bazaars :Inns & Cathedrals
:King & Scout:Little Buildings :The Count of Carcassonne :The Flier :The Ferries :The Festival:The Messenges :The Mini Expansion:The Phantom :The Plague :The Princess & the Dragon :The River :The River II :The Tower :Traders & Builders
:Wheel of Fortune
and other carc. games
	
Carcassonne: 10 Year Special Edition
Carcassonne: The Dice Game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice game that seems to appeal to non-gamers. WARNING: severe score crunching at the end. My biggest objection to this game is that it is often advantageous to count the score and plan your move for several minutes at the last few rounds of the game. This will annoy the other players a lot, but is worth it. So the game slows down tremendously at the end making it a big annoying. The expansions are not needed, they make the scoring even more complex, without much additional fun.

UPDATE: The Ipad app is great. The board game is good, but it's better on the Ipad. One of the best Ipad apps for sure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The base set is dull, but great with the right expansions.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
Simple and intuitive, Carcassonne even happens to have a somewhat deeper layer of strategy that makes it enjoyable by everyone: depending on the players’ skills and commitment, it works as a gateway game, as a family/strategy game and even as a more challenging game for the hardcore players.

Too bad not all of its expansions keep up with the original game: they rather make it duller. [i](September 2011)[/i]

[b]Update[/b] - Carcassonne is undoubtedly good, as long as it’s played once in a while. Thus, since one of the goals I set for my Fall 2015 rating revise was to keep half-point ratings to a minimum and Carcassone isn’t one of those by far, I rounded down my rating from 7,5 to 7.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
I like games where the board is never the same and this is one of Carcassonne's biggest perks.  You create the board as you play.  I tend to like it a bit more than Catan simply because there is less luck involved (anyone who tells you Carcassonne involves mostly luck simply doesn't know how to play it well - make good plays and it's rare you'll draw a tile that is not useful to you in some manner).

In a nutshell you are building a landscape with Roads, Cities, Fields, Abbeys, etc.  You 'claim' one of those things (if someone has not already) with a game piece (a 'meeple') of which you have seven.  Once someone has claimed the start of one of the individual structures building on to it and completing it will provide you points.  When you complete one you get the 'meeple' back that was on it in order to play it on a new construction.

The base game is very simple and easy to learn, but mastering it will make you really pay attention to the board.  There are many expansions to this game, so I would suggest buying the base game and the "River II" to start with, then read up on the expansions and add in the ones that look appealing to you.  I've added a couple expansions, but I find trying to use them all gets to be too much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Gateway Game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Here's my favorite way to play: Play will all the vanilla tiles (so, no springs, lakes, cathedrals, dragons, etc.) and then add in all the different meeples. So, big meeple, builder, pig, wagon, barn and mayor. All the rules can be described at the beginning, and no overwhelming or overpowered tile abilities. No extra bits, and no way to knock out any already placed meeples, other than simple majorities. Its all about positioning, like Carc should be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Carcassonne: The Discovery is a better introduction to the series.  This one has a few rough edges and is not as good with multiple players... but the rough edges make it a bit more interesting.

RATING: 7
Only the tile just drawn can have a worker placed on it. Not only does it matter where on the tile the worker is placed, but more importantly where the tile itself is placed on the "board". Different tiles give different options in both regards.

Typically, as the game progresses each tile affords fewer possibilities which means you rely on luck of the draw to a growing extent.

RATING: 9
I love Carcassonne. This game is everything from a lighthearted, relaxing, puzzle built with other friends that ends with the last tile being placed to a cut-throat tile-laying game filled with tension, ruining your opponents plans, and hearing the cries from small children witnessing this carnage. It's incredible the versatility that different players will create with this game. And it plays in about an hour, what's not to love?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne was my 'gateway' into the world of proper board games.

I guess for the same reason that not many people know about "that little Italian place outside of town that serves the most unbelievably authentic pizza", and instead frequent the more obvious and dominant restaurants, such as Dominoes, Pizza Hut, or Pizza Express*, one can never really know the true depth of scope when it comes to board games, if all you know is Toys'R'Us.

* don't get me wrong, I will happily trample over my own grandmother for a Pizza Express.

I had not scratched the surface of this world, but I was eager to claw my way into its depths. In purchasing Carcassonne, I had effectively discovered the Italian place, and tentatively ordered a margarita.

This game is great for kids (I have a 12 year old who can verify this), but just as good for a wine-fueled evening for two. Games are quick enough to not feel too hard done by if you lose, because before you know it, you're playing the next one.

As with all games, play this one enough and you'll eventually get that "played to death" feeling, but don't let that put you off. Carcassonne is a great game and I would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone... especially if they're not really gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
@ BSW

RATING: 6

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favourite euros. Very adaptable to different numbers of players which changes play dynamic without breaking the game. Only one expansion necessary - Inns and Cathedrals (and that is mainly for the extra set of meeples for a 6th player).
Also a favorite game to introduce to very young children, 7-, as you can gradually introduce the different scoring rules (cities first, then roads, ... and finally, if ever, farmers) to build up the complexity of the game.
Do not be afraid to play with less than the full compliment of tiles as more tiles => longer game. This is especially true when you start adding more + more expansions. Better to just play the base game with 1 more expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I suspect many people consider this the archetypal tiles game. Players draw, blindly, a tile from a bag, and lay it next to a previously played tile.

The goal is to connect tiles in such a way that they form cities, roads, cloisters, and fields, scoring points if that player controls the completed area.

It's a really good game. It seems completely luck dependent, but there are very few tiles that are as useless as they first seem.

I recommend this to most gamers, even those who think they detest luck-based games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Carcassonne deserves praise for what it was in 2000, before it created a whole family of games which further developed the design. Currently, as stated on the box, it's a "clever game of tile laying." It's rules still are surprisingly simple and the strategic thought that can be produced from those rules make it a great game to have in the collection, occupying an important niche. I can get it to the table with my wife or a non-gamer and even have the television on while playing. All of this said, there really isn't any theme at all; it's a very well designed competitive puzzle. This keeps me from loving a game which I at most can only like and respect.

RATING: 7
Really enjoy this game, though not a top favorite. It can take a while to play through, and sometimes you can get incredibly unlucky with the tiles you draw and when. A great deal of the strategy is based around the long term, where things just might not play out as you'd hoped, leaving you with little recourse. Too slow to play for me, with too little to do, can trigger AP pretty badly for how simple it is, and frankly takes up a LOT of table space and gets very annoying to shift around if you start building on a constricted side. Would prefer to play something else with the same time investment.

RATING: 9.45
One of my all time favorite games.  I like the simple rules and dynamic play.  I love how very expandable it has proven to be, and how those expansion make the game very modular, and thus the game play highly variable.

Optimal play is probably two players, but the three player game I think is still pretty good.  Above three can still be fun, but tends to be much more messy, and harder to strategize.  To play with more players it is probably better to use one of the expansions that opens the board up right at the start.

不是使用抽一張放一張的方式，而是使用手牌制，建議是抽圖板後有2-4張（越多運氣成分則越低）

RATING: 8
Aesthetically pleasing experience and good thinking to optimize. When playing with 2 players, we often play "nice" - one could be very mean and create impossible situations. The other option with 2 players would be to have a cut-throat game of not "i want to make good points" but "i want to make more points than the other player".

With more players, it gets less calculable, but instead ad-hoc cooperations between players can occur.

We noticed that too many of the expansions make it a bit overcomplicated, especially for introducing new players.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This was the game that sucked me into boardgaming.  It got to the point where we were playing mega-Carcassonne, using several hundred tiles, letting the tension build throughout the game as farms get connected to each other in convoluted and unexpected ways.  In some games, we end up with 7 or 8 meeples competing for a single massive farm.  The L-shaped road piece is the greatest single tile in the game.  So much damage can be done using this unassuming tile.

Personally, I don't like the rules in the expansions that allow a player to eventually free meeples from the board.  It's fun to trap your opponent's meeples and force them to look for a specific tile, watching them squirm the longer and longer they wait for that elusive tile.  You can really get an edge over your opponent if you make them squirm and lose focus on what they need to do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very playable for friends, family and others!!!! One of the lasting favs
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

I prefer playing a variant where you have a hand of three tiles to chose from.

RATING: 8
I absolutely love this game, and there was a point when I thought it was infinitely replayable, but then I made the awful mistake of playing a game with all 17 expansions, and it was that point I discovered I was dead wrong.

Be careful which expansions you use together, and how many you use, because at first glance this seems like an infinitely expandable concept, but it's really not.

RATING: 9
With more play of this game, it is soooo easy to play, and very enjoyable.   Like a more fun game of chess.   

I love that you can work on your own progression, while also working on watching what your opponent(s) are doing and prepare to block them, or just make their progression harder.

Very addicting, and I think it is because it is so easy to play.   Barely any setup/takedown, making multiple piles of tiles makes shuffling virtually unnecessary, scoring is a breeze once you know how.

Great game and reputation is deserved.

RATING: 8
For an abstract with hidden information with the drawing of tiles this is still a great game. Great theme and has quite a bit of tricks and manuevars and strategy in tile laying. I highly recommend this one. The learning curve on this one is really small, takes one game to get the gist of it really well. Makes a great family or party game. Even someone who appears to be in dead last with people in their 50 or 100 point totals already can pull in for 2nd place or even the lead with well timed and planned strategy in tile laying and meeple placement of farmers etc. The expansions are a must. And I highly suggest getting the Towers.

I highly suggest playing with 3 or more players!

*UPDATE*
This has become one of my standard gateway games, my wife's favorite 2 player game, and a good "dinner and game night" game with other couples.  2 player games are quick and vicious, allowing for a rematch.  4 player games are more random, but offer an enjoyable game that's not too long and not too complex for non-gamers.
We almost always play it with the I&C expansion.

RATING: 8.5
I love that this game has become so customizable, allowing you to add whatever expansions or, thanks to ebay, pieces of expansions that you want. My set is only about %50 more tiles than the stock set but it is still so useful as a gateway game that I think I may never add more for risk of adding too much complexity. The randomness can be annoying, and I think you can get screwed too easily with just the base set, but a few extra tiles really let's this game breathe. A great relaxing game. I love it with two, but with more its a great gateway. I just don't play it with my gamer friends.

The expansions are interesting (at least the first couple) but overwrought for a lightweight design. We gave the game & first 2 expansions to my sister & her family, and just play Carcassonne: the Castle now.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After Settlers, Carcassonne was my next introduction into the wide world of board gaming. As such, it still holds a very dear place in my heart. But that's not the only reason I rate it a 10. This game withstands the test of time and it is designed in such a way that the simple inclusion of 10 extra tiles and a couple of new mechanics can change the game entirely. I love the way the board fluctuates from one game to the next and I love the tension that builds up as the stack of tiles gets lower and your chances of drawing the tiles you really need become less likely. I also enjoy the subtle player interaction that can occur when two or more people are duking it out to win a certain feature.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A classic for a reason, but difficult to articulate exactly why it is one of my favourite games - and so prevalent throughout the hobby. There is certainly satisfaction to be had in watching the world develop as it is built by the players throughout the game. Mechanically, the game is incredibly smooth and intuitive but remains deeply engaging - and each tile that is flipped offers the player with unexpectedly numerous choices. 

A huge portion of my enjoyment of the game stems from how different each play feels as well; sometimes it's a real cut-throat affair as people are consistently building into one another's farms and cities and other times it's a serene affair, as I can calmly build roads and abbeys undisturbed by the players elsewhere in the world we are building. Furthermore, despite the game so often being very interactive and very "thinky" it never feels mean-spirited, slow-paced or frustrating. Highly enjoyable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

However, I find it enjoyable as a not so intense but yet still entertaining game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
RULES: ***** - The rule set is terrific. You can easily get the flow of the game in mere minutes. Of course, there are known issues with farmer scoring, but 4th edition rules are fairly intuitive and easy to grasp.
STRATEGY: ** - There is a possibility to have a vague plans of what you are going to do next, but you honestly can't plan much before the game, it's a lot more about reacting correctly to the current events.
TACTICS: **** - This game would be a perfect tactical game, but it isn't just because you have only one tile a turn to place and you can't choose which one it is, hence the choices get somewhat limited by your tile draw.
LUCK: *** - Most of the time you can find a proper place for the drawn tile to be placed, however, sometimes it gets very frustrating when you can't draw anything but roads while someone steals your city. Having a hand of three tiles would have been a lot better, and a lot more evil... But that's just thinking aloud.
PLAYER INTERACTION: ***** - Believe me when I say this game can get evil. Tension is high and fights for the biggest cities and largest farms can get mad. Furthermore, the turns are short and the pace is fast.
REPLAYABILITY: *** - Without expansions, I'd say the game is very fun, but the fun doesn't last long enough and the game does get repetitive after a while. A couple of better expansions to expand your opportunities will easily fix this though.
THEME: ** - It is an abstract. It has almost nothing to do with city or road building or farming. It could use any other theme and be just as succesful. However, I can't deny that all those cute cartoonish graphics on tiles do add some needed flavour, so the theme, however thin, does provide a nice touch.
BALANCE: **** - The cities and farms seem to be the hugest point sources in the game, leaving cloisters and roads in a supportive role. I would rather this was fixed, and I believe that certain expansions address that problem fairly succesfully. Anyway, the game is quite good without any expansions as well, it's just that you have to concentrate on cities more.
DOWNTIME: ***** - None! Grab a tile, place a tile, place a meeple, score! There is almost no place for analysis and the game flow is awesome. You will never feel bored while playing the game (not speaking of repetitiveness kind of boredom, of course).
ACCESSIBILITY: **** - Anyone can play the game. I mean it. You can teach your Grandma play it, and she is very likely to like it. It's easy, it's fast, it's fun. My biggest complaint is that the game absolutely sucks with more than three players, because it gets too chaotic. Otherwise, you can't ask for a better game to fit everyone's taste.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Perfect match for everybody - starting from 6 until 99 and on :-) I really liked the game play. The map and circumstances are always changing. I like it with expansion (builders) and it gives more possibilities and game speed (when you draw 2 tiles). You can also play 2 persons which is big plus too.

RATING: 10
My vote for top Euro-game of all time. Non zero sum, easy for all ages to enjoy, some luck but not so skill dependant anyone can't win. Fun all the way through, no expansions particularly necessary, can learn as you start to play, in about 2 minutes. Takes 30-40 minutes all in.

RATING: 9
I know it doesn't look like I've played this game a lot, but this is the game that hooked me in 2010. I wandered into the Board Room Game Center -- it was in Freeland at the time -- and owner Aaron "Quiz" Quesnel pulled it off the shelf and taught it to me.

I bought the game either that day or soon after. It was the only game I had, and I got lots of expansions for it, which all currently reside in the original box in printed tuckboxes and little plastic boxes for components.

I didn't find BGG until about two years ago or so, and by then I had played the mess out of Carcassone. Today, it doesn't get played much because there is so much more awesomeness on my shelf.

But I'm never getting rid of it.

RATING: 6
For the first few games, it appeared that luck was the most important factor. Then you start to see all these devilishly clever uses for tiles and ways to undermine someone else's goals. Lots of skill is required to master.
Still, carcassonne doesn't have enough game mechanics or strategy considerations for me to love.
There just isn't alot of planning or strategy. You are really just looking for the most effective use of each tile as they randomly appear, and trying to understand how to capitalize with each map as it evolves.
Your plans are more likely to fall through as succeed, and adaptation is key.

RATING: 1
Played this several times, base game and version with many many expansions - and every time I was bored after the first 5 minutes.

This game has neither strategy nor tactic to consider. Just draw a random tile, place it where it might potentially help you and not help or hinder the opponent, place one of your pieces if you want and you are done.

Unless you memorized all the tiles and know how many "outs" are still in the stacks this is a completely random game.

RATING: 8
  A great game for light gamers.  My wife and boys (7 and 8) 'get it' and really enjoy it.  my 8 y.o. is a genius with the farms (sometimes conceptually difficult).  It works for kids but don't write it off as a kids game.  We own the Big Box collection which comes with four expansions.  Some of the expansions add enough game play to rate higher than my eight and create some diabolical moves.  If you decide to buy I highly suggest the Big Box collection.  It will save you a lot of money in the end and provide significantly more play options to keep the game fresh and interesting.  If you add all of the expansions together you will have a long, medium wieght game for a rainy day.

It's almost like Scrabble but with puzzle tiles instead of letters and without all the miserable downtime.

:aristocrat: [b][size=11]The game that got me into the hobby![/size][/b]
:building: [b][size=11]My 2nd Best Area Control Game![/size][/b]
:building: [b][size=11]My 3rd Best Modular Board Game![/size][/b]


:!block: [b]IMPORTANT NOTE:[/b] This rating is done considering the expansions owned AND also using some variants to reduce the luck factor and enhanced the strategy.
* [thing=2993]Carcassonne: Inns & Cathedrals[/thing] (2002) :star::star::halfstar:
* [thing=5405]Carcassonne: Traders & Builders[/thing] (2003) :star::star::halfstar:
* [thing=31784]Carcassonne: Abbey & Mayor[/thing] (2007) :star::nostar::nostar:
* [thing=33458]Carcassonne: Count, King & Robber[/thing] (2007) :halfstar::nostar::nostar:
* [thing=153773]Carcassonne: Hills & Sheep[/thing] (2014) :star::halfstar::nostar:


[b]Base Game: Games Played ≈ 17 + 47 = 64 times[/b]
:gg::gg::gg::gg: [b]EPIC Purchase! (Less than 1$ per hour!)[/b]

[b]With Any Expansions: Games Played ≈ 47 times[/b] (92)
:gg::gg::gg: [b]Awesome Purchase! (Less than 2$ per hour!)[/b]

[b]SCORE  CRITERIA       WEIGHTING       ------- STAR RATING SCALE -------[/b]

(9.0) GAME FLOW        (x5):         FIDDLY :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar: SILKY SMOOTH
(7.0) DOWNTIMES        (x2):         LOT OF :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: ZERO
(7.0) RANDOMNESS       (x2):      PURE LUCK :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: PURE SKILLS
(8.0) MECHANICS        (x2):         BORING :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: INTERESTING / INNOVATIVE

(9.0) REPLAYABILITY    (x5):           ZERO :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: INFINITE
(8.0) SCALABILITY      (x3):           POOR :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: GREAT AT ALL PLAYER COUNTS
(6.0) PORTABILITY      (x1):          BULKY :star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: SUPER EASY TO PLAY ANYWHERE

(8.0) THEME            (x1):   UNATTRACTIVE :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: ATTRACTIVE
(8.0) AESTHETICS       (x1):           UGLY :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: GORGEOUS
(8.0) COMPONENTS       (x1):    LOW QUALITY :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: HIGH QUALITY
(9.0) VALUE            (x2):  TOO EXPENSIVE :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar: REALLY CHEAP(LOW COST FOR WHAT WE GET)

(9.5) SETUP TIME       (x2):           LONG :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::halfstar: ZERO
(7.0) GAME LENGTH      (x2): TOO SHORT/LONG :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: JUST PERFECT
(8.5) RULES COMPLEXITY (x1):        COMPLEX :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: SIMPLE
[/c]
[b]TOTAL = 385.0/50 = 7.70[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Great light-weight tile-laying gateway game that can scale from family game to a more medium-weight strategic game by adding some expansions (also using some house rules/variants to make it "friendlier" or more "cutt-throat").
++ Simple, elegant tile-laying / worker placement mechanisms.
++ Good replayability due to the random order tiles are drawn and also due to the high number of expansions you can add.
++ To reduce the luck of the draw and to make it more strategic several house rules/variants can be used easily and effectively:
* You can draw 2 or 3 tiles that you keep in your hand, and after playing one, you redraw (this also speed up the analysis time of the tiles drawn since you already have your tiles durings the other players' turn).
* You can have some tiles (between 3 to 5) facing up near the scoring board and players must choose from these tiles. Chosen tiles are replaced immediately (like cards in Ticket To Ride).
++ Easy to teach, fast to set-up and fast to play.
++ There are severeral expansions available for this game (which is useful to refresh the game when we have overplayed it).


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- The luck of the draw can be frustrating at time, but this can be made a more strategic game with some variants.
-- The area control part of this game can make this game too cutt-throat when playing against casual players or wife! (thus some house rules have been made)
-- Since I hate sorting tiles when adding or removing an expansion, we always plays with all the tiles, but not all the rules (before the game we state with which expansion we desire to play and ignore some icon on some tiles) but this make the game longer that it should (thus our variant to randomly remove a handful of tiles from the draw bag at the beginning of the game).


:arrowE: [b]OTHER GAME INFO:[/b]
[b]
Game Weight = 1.9-2.2/5
Release Date = 2000
Number of Player = 2-5(6)
2-player length (Base game) = 30-45 min.
2-player length (With expansions) = 60-75 min.
Player Count Preference = Best at 2, recommended at 3, 4 and 5! :thumbsup::thumbsup:
[/b]
