=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm starting to come around a bit on this game. I still am not a huge fan, but I can at least see it's appeal to the right crowd. For the serious gamer, this is still a game you won't be suggesting much, but if you have smart, non-gaming friends this can be a solid entry for doing somthing casual with them that will engage them without being threatening. For the fan of El Grande or Modern Art or Settlers of Catan, though, this doesn't have a whole lot to recommend it. If you do play, the first two expansions (the River, now included in the basic set, and The Expansion) are recommended in the strongest possible terms. Better yet, go direct to the more entertaining and visually appealing Hunters & Gatherers. Certainly later expansions should probably be avoided.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Some players are turned off by the perceived lack of strategic depth in Carcassonne, and that's why I've given it an 8.5 and not a 9.  Nevertheless, this one of the few board games that everyone should own. It's a much friendlier game than most, but it still leaves room for competition as players exercise their powers of persuasion over one another.  Player interaction is a necessity, although nothing concrete is gained or lost during these discussions.  You have to get what you can without stepping on anybody's toes, otherwise you will find your projects blocked and unfinished.  This is a great game for families and new gamers, and my copy has earned its keep amongst the collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Like a "modern day chess"; this game is a classic already.  The rules are simple, with the scoring being the hardest to catch on to, but once you play a game and actually do the scoring at the end things will suddenly catch on and you'll start to see the strategies more clearly.  This is a gateway game for sure and I'm currently using it for just that so that I can coerce a nongamer into starting on board games on a regular basis and he's fallen in love with this calling it "relaxing" and has stated SEVERAL times: "Man, I LOVE this game!"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Draw a tile and place it to form a map of Carcassonne, placing your meeple on the tile you just played if you'd like.  Once you have a meeple on the map, you'll want to complete the feature you placed your meeple on for points.  It's as simple as that!

Fun filler game if played without expansions, appeals to a wide variety of gamers, and a fairly set amount of time to play.  Virtually an infinite number of expansions these days if you're looking to spice things up!

RATING: 5
I play Carcasonne with the variant of one having one extra tile open in front of you. So when draw another, you have a choice between the two. A good deal more interesting. Without that alteration, this game is probably only a 5 for me.

Hunters & Gatherers is IMO the superior version. I recommend you buy that one instead of the original. More interesting. Further, the theme works better (better fleshed out) and graphics are more compelling.

RATING: 7.35
Great tile-laying gateway game.  The rules are simple (although Farming rules can be a bit complicated to non-gamers) and there is quite a bit of strategy and depth to be had.  

The game scales well although is probably the deepest and most and engaging at 2 players.  The game gets very cut-throat this way unless the players actively avoid blocking their opponent.  We love the complicated interplay and jostling for position.

The game is also well expanded with tons of options and very cheap.  Highly recommended as a baseline strategy game most people will enjoy.

RATING: 6
Essentially you bet on what things will turn out big in the end. Nice, but in addition to the luck factor of drawing the right tiles in the right moments, which has quite some impact, a satisfying game depends more than usual on on how serious your fellow players are: A single randomly acting player or a player who never allies with a certain other player for external reasons are much harder to ignore than in, say, Puerto Rico or Caylus. Otherwise, the possibilty of intentionally harming your opponents is often underestimated in Carcassonne - and a lot of fun, although you will regret it since cooperation is key.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A game with simple rules. Draw a tile, place the tile, and maybe place a meeple on that tile.

But the options are larger. Place the tile to block an opponent? To expand one of my structures? To start a new structure? To attempt to horn in on an opponent's structure? To enhance the value of a farm I'm expecting? As for the meeple, do I place it for short term gain, or end game scoring?

The new bishop rules aren't necessary, but it is fun to accumulate points with them.

However, to make this good game into a great game, the first expansion is required.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Somehow, I managed to make it to 2014 (that's something like 12 years of being active in the hobby) without playing Carcassonne.

I understand why this game has such a lasting appeal. It's a REALLY good weight - it's deep enough to be interesting for gamers and simple enough that I could see explaining it to a non-gamer easily, and actually having them get something out of it. I really like the curve of the game where you start out with very limited options and gradually as the game progresses you wind up with more and more to think about - feels perfect for a gateway game. The choices themselves are sufficiently juicy, and the not-insignificant amount of luck ties neatly into a fun risk-reward system and the game's profoundly interesting social landscape.

The game has this really fun semi-coop element (especially at larger player counts where you really have to rely on other players) that really promotes tabletalk and keeps people engaged. I've never seen such a simple dry Euro get people talking so much before - each tile draw sees players crowding around the active player, discussing the pros and cons of potential placements, and how they affect other players.

The only things that truly bug me is the farmer scoring and the road tiles. Farmers feel overly complicated and it's just hard to judge whose farmers are doing well at any given point. And roads just feel underpowered.

Note: Always play this where you redraw at the END of your turn so you have a full round to consider your next move. This should really just be the official rule.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was the very first German board game in my collection.  As the prototypical tile-laying, area control game, Carcassonne embodies some of the best aspects of family Euro games - beautiful components (including the signature, now-ubiquitous "meeples"); tactical and strategic gameplay arising from simple rules; a high degree of player interaction; no player-elimination; and a short playing time.  However, there is a significant amount of luck involved with this game, especially when the base game is played without any expansions.  Placement of farmers and competing for control of farms are key to victory and sometimes, who wins or loses depends on whether or not a player draws the tile(s) they require to connect an isolated farmer to a contested farm.  Familiarity with the tile distributions will help to improve one's play, but this game quickly becomes tiresome (unless one purchases expansions to keep things lively).  Works best with two players, but still highly enjoyable for up to four.  A must-play for anyone new to Euro games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Original version is fun,but the expansions make the game too long
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like matching up the pictures on the tiles.  It reminds me of a jigsaw puzzle, but more awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best part of this game is that it's ready to play within seconds. No setup necessary. Most strategic game takes around 5 minutes to setup and is boring to do so but not this. This is because the board is built during the game. This also adds high replay value. 

So far only played with two players and it works great. It's very interactive in a very subtle way, something few games manage. 

So one could say it's very luck driven because you draw what tile to play. But I think it's one of those play with what you got games. 

The most negative part of this game is the incredible boring theme. Although very pleasant artwork the boring theme (or lack thereof) gives this game a lower score. With the mechanics in this game it could have been in space, monsters or anything really but instead it consists of villages, road, cloisters and farms.

RATING: 6.5
[u]January 10:[/u]This was a gift to my parents. Last time I went and see them in October (to get Lasik surgery ), my dad and I sat down and played it for the first time. Well I must say I was surprised to like it. At first, it seemed like something great for my parents to enjoy but I didn't expect to like it very much myself. I was wrong, the gameplay is simple and very fluid.

We played 3 times during this week and after the second and third play I was also beginning to see how to mess my father's plan by bringing majorities into "his" cities, and also how that could be dangerous (you do block 2 meeples and if the city is hard to close... well you could be missing these two meeples later on...).

RATING: 8
I enjoy all Carcs as ideal two-player games: Relaxing pastime, accessible play, and I'm not normally bummed when I lose because watching the countryside develop is just enjoyable. And what's not good about a game you can play with your grandmother. There was a while when I was swayed into the slightly superior elegance of H&G and the other Carc expansions, but I've come to appreciate the big swings of original Carc. I really only play this as a 2-player. (It just doesn't do it for me with more)

I understand why so many gamers think there are very little decisions to actually make. But, really, I just enjoy this game as an activity to go with conversation and a good friend. I get why you think there isn't much game here, but I wouldn't feel right without the time I've spent playing this. It is a joy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Such a great game.  This is one of the first "modern" board games that I played and fell in love immediately.

Simple mechanics and very easy to teach.  Just grab a tile and play it, then decide if you want to put a meeple on the tile to possibly score points.

I've heard people say that the scoring can be confusing, but that is where the strategy of this game is deep.  Simple gameplay and beautiful tableau at the end game will make you want to play over and over.  Trying to steal scoring areas (especially farms) is what will keep you playing this game for years and years.

Base game is amazing.  Throw in an expansion from time to time to keep things fresh.

(~30 plays)
Farmers were confusing at first, but I hear they've improved the rules with the new edition.  Regardless, this is an excellent game for newcomers to the gaming hobby.  
It has a good middle of the road feel concerning the amount of strategy, tactics, luck, player interaction, and just plain fun.  
It's also appealing for those who enjoy creating things, as the finished position is always interesting to look at.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tile placement game that I describe to non-gamers as a combination of dominoes and chess. Easy to learn, barring the farmers can be somewhat tricky to grasp at first.  Game moves quickly and has a surprising amount of strategic depth that will be hidden to you on the first few plays.

Carcassonne is my go-to gateway game for people who enjoy pure strategy games (no conflict, no trading, no social, chess, etc).  Depending on the player I'll typically go a round without farmers, and then toss them in for round two.  AND there WILL be a round two. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Hardly ever play this anymore, but a good little game that works well with the right audience.

RATING: 8
Love it.
Best with 2 players.
30 minutes.
Ages 8+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[i]Soylent Green is Meeples![/i]

Quickly a favorite at our house.. And since my wife loves it, Carcassonne gets more play in the house. Fantastic as a gateway game for our non-gamer friends, but usually requires a second play before they fully "get it." Carc gets the most play out of any of the games we own and is the most requested among friends, both gamers and non-gamers. It works well as a group game and exceedingly well as a very confrontational 2-player game. 

[b]We play only third edition rules.[/b] :) We play with Basic, both River sets, King & Scout, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders and Die Katharer. We are very skeptical about what The Count, Princess & Dragon and The Tower have to offer, so we haven't bothered. 

[i]House Rules[/i] - Game starts using the river (using River 1 & 2), we start with the river fork and set three river ends aside for after the other river pieces are played.. expanding the river in three directions at once. We use colored glass markers (similar to Go pieces) as scoring markers instead of sacrificing a meeple to the scoreboard. We also use these glass markers to mark who built the biggest city & road during play and to assist in counting completed cities and roads at the end of the game for King & Scout scoring. 

[i]Note[/i] that this rating I've given Carc is for playing with the above mentioned expansions and 3rd edition rules. Playing Carc with just the basic set and 1st ed rules would be a rating of 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Yeah, this one just doesn't do it for me.  It's fun to play, and I'll play with non-gamers to see if they like it - but why when there are so many other awesome games out there?  This one is so-so for me.  A little too light maybe.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne was the second "gateway" game that I bought in Jan. 2009 (after Ticket to Ride). Consequently, it has been a mainstay in my collection from the beginning.

Carcassonne is an excellent gateway game for a couple of reasons--the rules are simple and straightforward, and a turn consists of simply placing a tile, and optionally sticking a meeple on it. It can be played very politely, or incredibly cutthroat. It's a great two player game, but plays well up to four as well. And finally, the result of the game is a very attractive map that everyone has worked on together--there's something rewarding about that.

If you plan on playing this with any regularity and with any desire to add some strategy, then the Inns and Cathedrals expansion is essential.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This was one of the 2 first games I purchased when i got into the whole board game craze. I loved this game and played the heck out of it. Now 200+ games later this rarely finds the table. My GF still plays it online and asks to play so I play with her but have no strong desire to play it any other time. Not that I don't enjoy or like the game...it is just played out. As such I have rated it a 7 but I highly recommend it to anyone new to games and couples. I did rate this a strong 8 before.

Overall Score 7, Appearence 8, Components 8, The Box (storage) 7, Rulebook 8, Ease of Play 8, Mechanics 8, Involvment 7, Replayability 8, Uniqueness 9, Luck 3 v Strategy 7 (The higher the number the more it leans that way.)

RATING: 7.5
Of all my games, Carc has probably seen the most table time.  The beauty of this simple tile laying game is the mixture of short term tactics and the long term strategy of farm building.  On top of that is the immense replay ability Carc possesses and the scalability from many players to only two.  I do believe the sweet spot is four though.  Although I'm a little burned out currently by Carc, I will always bring this one to the table with new gamers.  Should I venture, "Gateway Game."?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What a delightful game!  This is my favorite light Euro.  It is easily accessible to newcomers yet varied and strategic enough for frequent gamers.  Each expansion also seems to add and enrich the game.

To be fair though, the base game all alone has a few shortcomings for me: the lack of a 6th player, the incomplete feel of a total package, and too short.  Inns & Cathedrals make up the first two points while Traders and Builders takes care of the last 2 points.  I rarely play the game without at least these two expansions.  Even if I don't use all the rules, I keep all the tiles in the game.

So basic vanilla Carc probably deserves a score of an 8 for me.  Hunters & Gatherers and Ark of the Covenant are the better basic games.  But with the expansions, Carcassonne is impossible to beat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I had heard so many good things about this, but every time I looked at pictures or reviews I thought "this is so bland." How in the world could you have an enjoyable game by placing a tile, and then claiming it by deciding to put a little man on it or not? I got into modern board games to get away from chess-like abstract things like this.

Someone at work was having a moving sale, and had this up for grabs for $10 or so. I figured what the heck, for $10 I can at least say I've tried a classic. And man was I wrong.

This game IS an absolute classic and deserves all the praise its had heaped upon it over the years. It's charming in its simplicity - to me, it's the perfect "play on a lazy summer afternoon, drinking iced tea on a patio with the sound of droning lawnmowers in the background" game, but it also has a deceptively deep level of strategy that may not be apparent your first play or two. I've heard that the earlier big box expansions are pretty good, but honestly? I don't want to try them just yet. Carcassonne in its base form has a purity that I don't want to risk tarnishing with needless additions.

If there's one thing I could ding it for, its that it might be too lightweight for me to play over and over again in a short period of time, but it's a minor complaint. What a great way to have my expectations broken.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Excellent game for new entrants as well as my wife and I. Light strategy, but entertaining nonetheless.

RATING: 7.5
I've seen this one in action a few times and played one game, which I won overwhelmingly against an experienced opponent and another newbie. What this tells me is that the mechanics are easy to grasp, there's just enough luck involved yet you still feel rewarded by your moves and decisions. It's not super deep but one way to describe Carcassonne is that it is much more complex than it is difficult. Great game to teach and to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Noviembre 07. Primer juego, 22€.

Uno de los clasicos para introducirse en los Eurogames. Los jugadores cogen una baldosa de la bolsa y la colocan pegada a otra de manera que continue el dibujo de la anterior. Cuando la coloque puede situar un 'meeple' y tomar control del camino, la ciudad, el monasterio o el campo dibujado en esa baldosa, siempre y cuando no continue algo que ya controle otro jugador. Segun va creciendo el tablero los objetos se hacen mas grandes o incluso se fusionan. Al terminar un camino o cerrar una ciudad, se devuelven los seguidores alli colocados y el que dominaba cobra sus puntos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Carcassonne went through a "dark age" for me after intially being very interested in it as a two player game...it got a little old, mainly because I played it a lot.  Then the newbie flux of 2002-onward started happening and it seemed like it's all anyone wanted to play.  Some bad experiences with 4-6 player games put me off.  Lately, I've been playing the game again and I realize that it's a genuine classic- a game that will truly stand the test of time.  It's one of the best casual games and one of the rare games where accessibility and ease of play don't foreclose on fun.  It's essentially abstract, but the sense of building and "project management" makes up for that.  With all expansions (the Carcassonne Big Box), it's a 9 all the way...without expansions, it's more like a 7 so I'll split the difference and give it an 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 5

I think I would enjoy it more if I had a group of committed people all playing for keeps but whenever it hits the table it seems like at least 1 or 2 people are still learning the game and make sub optimal moves which results in a predictable outcome.  There is nothing inherently exciting about drawing a tile or placing your meeple down.  Farmers are very important but are very confusing to new players.

RATING: 7
A clever tile-laying game. The southern French city of Carcassonne is famous for its unique Roman and Medieval fortifications. The players develop the area around Carcassonne and deploy their followers on the roads, in the cities, in the cloisters, and in the fields. The skill of the players to develop the area will determine who is victorious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
check version
Wienerbruck
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Always fun to play, simple to learn, but lacks a little bit of cutting edge.  It's a tile laying game where you match the borders of each tile to ones already played and score points by investing a worker in ownership or attempted ownership over some feature of the map you're creating.  The strategy is to score as many points as you can, while making it difficult on your opponent(s) to score points on whatever they have invested or are trying to invest their small finite source of workers on. It's a high luck based game where it's difficult for anyone to be truly out of it.  Experience is important, but two people of equal experience will generally always have a competitive game due to the high amount of luck involved.  The best moments in the game are in completing massive cities, sneaking in and taking over someone else's massive city, getting massive points off of farms, and blocking off opponents from completing construction of something and thus taking away their workers from helping them to score points for them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Base game is great for beginning gamers, but really needs the expansions after a few plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ótimo jogo introdutório ao mundo de boardgames. Ou para quando se quer algo simples e rápido, sem necessidade de setup algum.
Estamos desbravando Carcassonne, uma província francesa, e a cada turno, ao acrescentar um pedaço ao mapa, devemos escolher se daremos uma atribuição a um dos nossos limitados Meeples, seja de Ladrão nas estradas, de Monge nos monastérios, de Cavaleiro nas cidades ou Fazendeiro nos campos. Quando o tile que completa a área que o meeple está é colocado, recebemos o meeple de volta e pontuamos. A loucura da contagem final de pontos pode gerar uma boa reviravolta, principalmente com muitos fazendeiros!

Az elmúlt 2-3 évben elég sok játékkal ismerkedtem meg, elég sok játékot készítettem és szereztem be, de ez... ez viszi el a pálmát mind közül. FANTASZTIKUS játék, sohasem lehet megunni! (na jó, van amikor felkerül 1 hónapra a polcra, de szeretjük onnan levenni :) )

A kiegészítők nagyon jók, de vigyázni velük, mert nagyon megnöveli a játék idejét (nem csak a több lapka hanem a gondolkodás miatt is, főleg ha a grófos kieg. is használatban van) és ha mindet egyszerre használjuk akkor nagyon nehéz minden apró dologra figyelni és így kiválasztani a lehető legjobb döntést a lépésünk előtt.

A legjobb alapjátéknak tartom (én is ezzel a játékkal léptem be ebbe a társasjáték világba), szuper játék!

Update, 2011: gyakorlott gémerként már kevésbé tetszik és ritkábban kerül elő, de továbbra is állítom, hogy remek JÁTÉK! :) A szívem pedig nem engedi, hogy lejjebb vegyem a pontozását! :)

RATING: 7.5
This is a staple classic I had to add to my collection. I have only played it once so far and we just played the bare minimum so we will be adding in the rivers the next time. I think so far it is a good gateway game or a filler game. There isn't a lot of depth to it or strategy. Sharing something someone else has started building almost seems really cheap but it gets you those points you need. 

It doesn't take up a lot of room on the table which is always nice for a gateway game. It doesn't seem as overwhelming that way. I feel like expansions or variants of this game are definitely needed for me to enjoy it but it is a simple enough game to teach and for people to understand so it will be hitting the table again soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Carcassonne... This game is only in my collection because my girlfriend was of the opinion we should have a small set of 'classics'. I am not particularly fond of buying multiple copies of slightly altered games unless there is good reason to. Since I started out with 'De Burcht' en 'Jagers & Verzamelaars' I really saw no need to own original Caracassonne too. But the ways of women are shrouded in mystery for mere males, of course.

The funny thing is that this game did not once come out of its box, too. We always play one of the other titles I already mentioned: they provide sufficient variation and fun. The somewhat strange rules governing the original (what's up with those hard to form churches??) have been replaced by much more fun and workable variants in the other titles. I really ought to 'lose' this title, but I'm afraid then I'll 'lose' several body parts too.

[b]Update[/b] In the end I did play the original a few more times, but everytime we agreed that the other variant Carcassonnes in our possession did a better job. So eventually the game was let go.

RATING: 9.5
The pinnacle of tile laying pattern making area control. My Dad likes this, and we play the app all the time. I like it too as a solid dueling challenge. Our battles are always tense, even after not playing for a while. 
Rules are easy to pick up and recall, yet there is a great depth in strategy and room for high level plays.  On top of that, there is room for more players to make it more relaxed and randomised with more varied playstates.  It's a game for almost anyone I think.

As a wise man once said: "Just play Carcassonne" - you won't regret it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bought the Big Box and recommend that approach to anyone wanting to get into Carcassonne.  The Big Box has all the important expansions and provides a good way of storing the whole game.

Best combination seems to be base set, inns & cathedrals, and traders.  However, my kids like the tower and the dragon/princess combo the best.

Less is more with this game.  Meaning, don't over do it with the all the expansions at once.  It makes for a very, very long game if you do it that way.

Less players is more too.  Too much down time if you have too many players.  Three  or four is max.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A superb game with loads of subtle strategies to keep track of, but won't induce headaches.  Probably one of the finest games to actually play so quickly; light yet not.  I highly recommend this as an introduction into European gaming for those not experienced with the current generation of board/card games.  Brief suggestion, though, invest in a small, opaque bag of some kind to store the tiles; mixing them up that way and drawing blindly saves the overly long set-up time of shuffling and places the tiles face down.

RATING: 6.5

Where Carcassonne really shines for me is as an "adult" game that my son (age 5) can play.  It is really nice to be able to add a child to a game without impacting the enjoyment of the adults playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Board Game Revolution - ~2005[/b] 
One of the first games my wife and I bought when we got married.  I still enjoy the puzzle like feel of building the city of Carcassonne.  Since then we've added most of the base game's expansions to our collection.  Easy game to teach and play with the kids.

[b]Expansions owned:[/b]
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/2591/carcassonne-river][i]The River[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2005[/b] 
I don't know if I'd consider this an "expansion" as it came with the base game.  But the added river through the countryside visually adds to the game and helps spread out all the players so we're not quite so congested.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/18836/carcassonne-river-ii][i]The River II[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2007[/b] 
Starting out with an extra long river adds to the game.  We like to mix all the river tiles together.  I like to include the lake (end) in the bag so that we never know if we'll have a long river or a short one.  This house rule adds to the replay-ability of this expansion.
-------[b]Update 1/13/15: New idea for use of the river tiles[/b]
Start with all the tiles in the bag except one spring tile and the plain lake tile.  When/if the lake tile gets drawn.  The next player adds the spring (river starting) tile where applicable and continue drawing river tiles adding to the new river. At end cap off the river with the lake tile set aside.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/12903/count-carcassonne][i]The Count of Carcassonne[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2008[/b] - Just don't think it adds too much to the game.  It's nice to share points with another player, but I'd rather work on expanding my own city/road/abbey.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/5405/carcassonne-expansion-2-traders-builders][i]Traders & Builders[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2011[/b] 
The builder meeple adds A LOT to the game.  Being able to draw two tiles at a time is great!  Just be sure to not trap your builder into a city/road that cannot be expanded.  It is near impossible to get him back otherwise, unless you're playing with the dragon.  BUAH HA HA!  :)
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/2993/carcassonne-expansion-1-inns-cathedrals][i]Inns & Cathedrals[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2006[/b] 
I think the best addition this expansion adds to the game are the Inns allowing players to double the points of their roads from 1/tile to 2/tile.  The two cathedrals are nice to get early on in the game for bookoo points; but drawn later on in the game they become more of a nuisance. Great idea to "force" players to finish their bonus building/road, otherwise all that time was wasted and you don't get any points for any of those tiles.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/31784/carcassonne-abbey-mayor][i]Abbey & Mayor[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution[/b] - [b]~2013[/b]
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/35666/carcassonne-cult-siege-and-creativity][i]Cult, Siege and Creativity[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2007[/b] 
It's an alright expansion.  My wife doesn't like being able to take points away from another, so this doesn't get played all that often.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/7707/carcassonne-king-scout][i]King & Scout[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2007[/b] 
Couple of end of game bonuses for largest city/road.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/15158/carcassonne-princess-dragon][i]The Princess & the Dragon[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2012[/b] 
This is by far our family's favorite expansion to the base game.  We all try to keep the dragon away from us, but love eating the other's meeples!  My youngest son will often eat his own meeples simply because he can.  We do, however, often forget to give the bonus point for the fairy, so we usually leave that part out.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/26615/carcassonne-mini-expansion][i]The Mini Expansion[/i][/geekurl] - [b]eBay - ~2007[/b] 
Bunch of new/unique tiles added to the game found in the Games Quarterly magazine, Issue #11 (2006).  I found this item on eBay.
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/21385/carcassonne-tower][i]The Tower[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - ~2012[/b] 
At first I was skeptical about this expansion, but being able to take other player's meeples prisoner is awesome!  The only downside is when you are unable to capture the other person's meeple and do a prisoner exchange.  :(  But you can always award that player 3 points to get it back.  By the way, my family tends to gang up on me...something to do with me always winning. :D
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/38855/carcassonne-catapult][i]Catapult[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution - Christmas 2014[/b] 
The idea of this expansion is fun.  Does it really work? My kids think so!  They ask for it every time we play Carcassonne.  Me? Well, let's just say I understand why this microbadge exists [microbadge=11942].
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/118615/carcassonne-flying-machines][i]The Flying Machines[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution[/b] - 
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/118619/carcassonne-messengers][i]The Messengers[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution[/b] - 
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/118614/carcassonne-ferries][i]The Ferries[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution[/b] - 
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/118617/carcassonne-gold-mines][i]The Gold Mines[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution[/b] - 
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/118618/carcassonne-mage-witch][i]Mage & Witch[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution[/b] - 
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/118616/carcassonne-robbers][i]The Robbers[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Board Game Revolution[/b] - 
- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/66646/carcassonne-bridges-castles-and-bazaars][i]Bridges, Castles, and Bazaars[/i][/geekurl] - [b]Miniature Market - Christmas 2016[/b]

RATING: 8
Very solid tile laying euro style game.  Great replayability.  Lots of expansions now out. Because each tile lay is important, and so much is going on with each tile lay, this is a thinker's game with lots of strategy angles to contemplate each turn.  The board grows freely outward, so there is a lot to examine and decipher each turn.  Most of my games seem to have players over thinking and therefore our games take a few hours to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I must say that this is a little gem and because om the short playtime it comes to the table quite often. At first my girlfriend was a bit sceptical of my pretty hard gaming style, screwing up her castles and such, but with time she grew fond of that style of play and now we have a real hard showdown every time we play. I can also add that this review is seen out of a 2 player perspective altough ive also played a few 3 player and 4 player games and really liked those aswell.

RATING: 8
A fantastic game for 2-5 players. The base game can last anywhere from 30-50 minutes depending on the size of the group.  Adding more expansions can increase the time required.

Pros:
+Simple to learn
+Requires no reading making it a game for the entire family
+Many expansions to mix and match to change the game to your preference

Cons:
-Requires a large play space
-The number of expansions can get costly and might scare away potential groups

RATING: 9
This is the game that brought me back into boardgaming, and it will always have a place in my heart. Everyone loves playing with the meeples, and the game is a nice mix of strategy and tactics, improved with expansions. I also like that it plays up to 5, as a variable number of players is important to me. It's not perfect, as luck can really go a long way in determining the winner, but in my opinion it's the best gateway game - better than Catan or TtR.

RATING: 7.5
I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun Carcassonne is to play.  It's a light, quick game that's fun to play with family.

Further plays have revealed to me that you can be a bit mean and try to sabotage your opponents efforts with strategic placement of your tiles.  Perhaps not always such a family friendly game after all! ;-)

It's still a great classic that is a perfect gateway game, but also is fun and quick enough to be enjoyed by more experienced gamers who want to play a light filler.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Components: Beautiful soft-edged art style. By the end of the game, we've formed a unique map that's fun to look at just for its own sake.

Experience: Matching up the tiles is a process I find deeply satisfying. There are fun scoring opportunities, chances to horn in on someone else's hard work (or prevent someone else from doing the same), and lots of meeple-management decisions to be made, to keep a steady stream of meeples cycling through my reserve to the board and back again. Controlling a dominant field (if one exists) can be crucial to success, depending on which scoring rules are being used.

First Played: 2002-01-01
Last Played: 2015-02-01
Plays (23):
? players: 12
2 players: 5
3 players: 3
4 players: 3

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
This was my original Most Overhyped Game award winner... then I played Balloon Cup.  Now as you can see from the 6 rating, I don't dislike Carc but it's not nearly as good as everyone led me to believe.  I love tile laying games but straight up vanilla Carc is a "nice" game - you draw a tile and then it's usually pretty obvious where to place it (or at least you can see what the obvious options are and then it's all hoping you get the right tile to match your choice).  Having a "hand" of two tiles added a little something for me but if you really want the good stuff just play Carc: Hunters and Gatherers (a much better game).

RATING: 9
An excellent game that was my gateway into the world of Euro gaming. It contains a good balance of length, complexity, and accessibility. On the surface it appears that the game requires a fair amount of luck, but repeated plays reveal the strategic nuances that give skilled, experienced players the upper hand. I'm looking forward to purchasing the expansions.

Update: The "Inns and Cathedrals" and "Traders and Builders" expansions really complete this game. Though it requires extra outlay, I would consider them essential and with them the game is a 9 for sure.

UT
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
While very simple to play, this game can be very difficult to master.  You are essentially building a puzzle, where you can create castles, roads, churches, and farms.  Place your marker to gain points of those areas, get them back if completed.

It is so simple just about everyone I know figured it out in about 3 minutes (including a 5 year old) and enjoyed it.

Unfortunately this game suffers the same flaw as card games; card/tile counting.  To actually compete in this game you need to remember how many of each tile exists, build yourself structures that are likely to get finished, and disrupt the building of opponents structures.  It is a real bummer to "walk yourself" into a "dead end" in this game.  

The other downside of this game is that luck takes a large part in the game play.  Each player pulls cards at random to complete their structures.  It is possible that you will simply pull the right tile and never get to finish your building/road/farm.  Now over an infinite number of trials this probability drops to zero, but that doesn't mean that you will ever get to finish your castle this game. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Carc H&G warrants an 8, as I like it more than the basic Carcasonne.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The rules are fantastically simple to pick up or explain. Laying down the tiles is an aesthetic joy as the map is created. Though the randomness is inherent to the game, skill will prevail as the 'cheat-sheet' makes it relatively easy to calculate the probabilities of drawing a particular card - weighing up the likelihood of your farmer being connected to a contested field or of your ability to successfully block an opponent's city makes for some interesting decisions.

Ultimately about balancing immediate and eventual rewards, whilst trying to connect cities or farms in your favour, this seems like the ultimate family game - simple enough to explain, enough randomness to give everyone a chance, enough skill to reward playing well and fairly universal instant appeal.

Played with Joel 4x, since we both enjoyed it so much and it seemed a quick game.

-----------------------------------
2008-04-05
Against Dave and Barry, the game dragged on a lot more. I don't know if this was because of the over-analysis or because of the 3-player nature. 

Maybe just a case of improper game/group matching?

Still, I'm now a bit more cautious about how it'll perform with the family.

-------------------------
2010-01-03

Finally played with Family. Played 3x (5p,5p,7p). First 2 times, played without famers or crests. 3rd time, introduced the farmer rule.

Afs took long enough to get a complaint from everyone else. He also (correctly) decreed that only the farm mattered. Indeed, most of the map was a single farm and I won by having 4 farmers. 

Not sure if the single-big-farm was because we didn't play with the river tiles or because of chance.

Still a great game. Works fine with 7. (We used Go stones for dad/I).

RATING: 8
It takes a tiled to build a village: What can I say it's, 'Carcassonne'. It plays good with any number and it is simple to learn. Children will enjoy the ever expanding landscape and can easily understand the concepts of the game. An excellent game to start out with to transition them from, Candyland to real games. I have played this game with scores of individuals and the only people that didn't seem to enjoy it were beer drinking, 'the cheaper the better', pretzel chewing, every sports game watching, reliving high school days type of people. I am sure they would have enjoyed chugging a beer and playing a sports type game. Highly Recommended.

RATING: 8.5

Plus the production values are excellent.  No complaints at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Date approximative du texte: 2003

Lauréat du Spiel des Jahres 2001, un prix qui couronne plutôt des jeux grand public, Carcassonne est un jeu qui a rencontré un grand succès commercial. L’auteur et l’éditeur ont donc continué à exploiter ce remarquable filon en sortant des extensions pas toujours indispensables. D’autres jeux ont été commercialisés sous la bannière de Carcassonne et aujourd’hui le logo du jeu est quasiment une marque en soi.

Le jeu

Il se compose d’un jeu de 72 tuiles paysage. Ce sont des carrés où peuvent figurer des portions de ville, de route, de champs ou des abbayes.
Chaque joueur reçoit 8 pions d’une couleur.
Une tuile de départ (dos grisé) est posé au centre de la table.
A son tour un joueur doit piocher une tuile à l’aveuglette et la placer de façon à agrandir la cité. Il est nécessaire d’observer une cohérence dans la pose et de respecter les continuités des routes, des villes etc.…
Le joueur peut également s’il le désire poser un de ses partisans sur la tuile qu’il vient de poser. Le pion peut être posé soit sur la route, c’est alors un brigand, sur la ville, c’est alors un chevalier, sur une abbaye, c’est un moine et sur un champs c’est un paysan. Il est interdit de placer un pion sur une unité géographique qui en contient déjà un. Il est par contre tout à fait possible de réunir deux éléments distincts avec chacun un pion et d’obtenir un élément avec plus d’un pion ( par ex. réunir deux routes avec chacune un brigand par une autre tuile route).

En cours de partie il peut y avoir des attributions de point :
Dans tous les cas les points sont donnés au joueur qui a une majorité de pion sur l’élément géographique décompté. En cas d’égalité tous les joueurs majoritaires gagnent des points.
Si une ville est terminée (elle doit être complètement ceinturée de remparts) :2 points pour chaque tuile de la ville plus 2 points par blason. Une exception : une ville de deux tuiles ne rapporte que 2 points.
Si une route est terminée (elle est délimitée de chaque coté par un carrefour, ou une construction) :1 point pour chaque tuile de la route.
Lorsqu’une abbaye est complétée (quand la 8eme tuile qui l’entoure est posée), le joueur qui a posé un moine dessus gagne 9 points.
Quand une unité est achevée en cours de partie et qu’elle décomptée les joueurs récupèrent dans leur main les pions qu’ils y avaient placés.

Fin du jeu : quand la dernière tuile est posée.
Les paysans dans les champs : pour le ou les joueurs majoritaires, chaque ville terminée qui borde ou qui se trouve à l’intérieur du champs rapporte 3 points (et pas 4 comme indiqué dans la première version des règles). Un champs est délimité par le vide autour des tuiles, les routes, les villes.
Pour un abbaye : 9- le nombre de tuiles manquantes pour l’entourer complètement.
Route inachevée : 1 point/ tuile ( autant qu’une route achevée, ça sent le bug !)
Ville inachevée : 1 point/tuile

Variantes
La règle n’est pas vraiment jouable en l’état, heureusement elle se prête bien aux variantes, en voici quelques unes les plus indispensables en tête :

- Le jeu compte en réalité 71 tuiles, car il y a une tuile de départ. Pour que chaque joueur placent le même nombre de tuile, il faut retirer face visible 1 tuile à 2 joueurs, 2 tuiles à 3 joueurs, 3 tuiles à 4 joueurs, 4 tuiles à 5 joueurs.
- Les routes, les villes inachevées et les abbayes incomplètement entourées ne rapportent aucun point en fin de partie. Cela encourage les joueurs à entreprendre des constructions de taille réaliste.
- Le premier joueur ne tire pas une tuile mais deux, il en choisit une pour la placer et passe celle qui reste au prochain joueur qui en tirera une nouvelle. Ainsi chaque joueur à le choix entre deux tuiles.
- Interdiction de créer des zones vides entourées de tuiles.
- En début de partie chaque joueur reçoit une abbaye, puis toutes les tuiles sont distribuées de façon à ce que les joueurs aient connaissance de tout leur jeu.
- En début de partie chaque joueur reçoit une abbaye qui si elle est inachevée rapportera des points négatifs.

Mon opinion

Carcassonne est l’exemple même du jeu convivial, à la fois plaisant et intéressant. Les joueurs prennent des décisions sans sombrer dans la reflexionite aiguë qui plombe l’ambiance. Carcassonne à eu un succès mérité, le problème est de savoir si tout le monde joue bien au même jeu. Avec toutes les variantes qui circulent, je me suis aperçu que chacun se fait une opinion du jeu en se basant sur des règles différentes. C’est un peu ennuyeux d’expliquer les règles à chaque fois qu’il y a un nouveau joueur. Je regrette que l’éditeur n’ait pas proposé une aide de jeu reprenant la distribution numérique des différents types de tuile. Qui d’entre vous serai intéressé à jouer aux dominos sans les connaître ? L’évaluation des probabilités de sortie me semble indispensable pour avoir un peu de contrôle sur la partie.
Le jeu se positionne bien, avec une durée inférieure à une heure et il est courrant d’enchaîner deux ou trois parties à la suite. Il y a plein de moyens pour arriver à la victoire et il est possible de jouer aussi bien en père de famille (des petits scores en continu), en constructeur mégalo ou en saboteur sournois.
Le jeu du pion est une facette du jeu il autorise des tas de coups pendables si on anticipe une probable connections avec une construction lucrative jouée par vos adversaires. Il faut penser à toujours avoir un deux pions disponibles en main pour les bons coups mais ce n’est pas toujours facile de ménager sa main. Les paysans par exemple restent définitivement en jeu.
Carcassonne n’est donc pas un simple puzzle, c’est un jeu plein de surprises qui peut se jouer de nombreuses fois et ce avec tous les publics. Un bon choix dans la catégorie des poids moyens.

RATING: 9
What I liked
* The game has few rules and is reasonably easy to teach
* The game plays fast and is easy to score
* While it plays slightly different it is still fun with any number of players.
* Game plays different each time
* Can play to be cruel or kind to the other players.

What I didn't like
* Fields seem a bit overpowered point wise compared to the roads and cities. Doesn't detract a great deal from the game though.
* Graphics are nice but I feel they could have been better.

RATING: 8.5
[April 2017 - 8.5]
I'm still enamored by this game. 

[June 2016 - 8.2]
Another bump up in the ranking thanks to the expansions (Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders), which add a little more interaction and thought about placement.

[October 2015 - 7.8]
Continues to be a winner when I introduce it to people. I really enjoy it with four people. 

[January 2015 - 7.6] 
I've been playing a little more and it gets a nudge up in the ratings. People really enjoy it, its wonderful to look at and it's fun. I reiterate though, that this needs to be the first or second game of the night, it can't come after a boisterous game, or else it falls flat. 

[August 2014 - 7.5]
Classic game and I enjoy playing it, but sometimes it's actually a tough one to bring out to the table with new players. The "fields" rule (which many times determines the winner) can take a full game to understand and sometimes the game can bog down. Tip: Flip your next tile over immediately after playing to contemplate your next move when your turn comes around. It's a game, I've come to discover, good to play as the first one of the evening, then ramp things up with something a bit more interactive and boisterous. If you do the reverse (eg. play The Resistance before Carcassonne), then it feels a bit dull. I still give it 7.5 though, because it's a GOOD game on its own and given the right time, I want to play it.

RATING: 7
One of my first 'modern' games. I remember hunting around for a copy with the SO for several months trying to find a copy at a retail store (this was before we knew of the plethora of online shops).

Carcassone is a wonderfully simple tile-laying game. It can be as leisurely or as cutthroat as your group wants it to be. The rules are easy to teach and it's fun to watch the countryside unfold before you. The plethora of expansions available also kept the game fresh for a long time.

My only gripe with the game is that your decisions can sometimes feel a bit pre-destined since you only draw one tile. If that tile doesn't help any of your ongoing projects, it feels a bit like a wasted turn. Luckily, playing with a hand of 3 (or more) tiles fixes this problem for us and creates a larger decision space.

Carcasonne doesn't see a lot of table time anymore as we've moved on to more complex games (and we've played it to death), but it still holds a special place in my heart and it's one of the first things I'll pull out if anyone ever says "Boardgames? You mean like Monopoly?".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

- Builders and Traders (I find it is a must now) and king expansions.
- No more than 5 people, even better with less

To reduce the amount of luck and significantly improve the strategy aspect of the game:

- Either with 3 tiles in hand or 4 open tiles (to all players)


I am always tempted to take a picture at the end of each game a build a playing library (but fnally found more useful things to do!)

RATING: N/A
カルカソンヌ
２～５人
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is another early game that I taught my girlfriend and one that remains as one of her favorites to this day. 

I went through a period where I was cool to this game. It seemed a little too random to be really interesting, and I was busy with investigating other games. Since then, my opinion of the game has improved quite a bit. 

At its core Carcassonne is an investment game. It isn't about investing in stocks, or countries, or railroads but about investing in particular landscape developments. Now, these investments may not pay off. You may end up failing to get the tiles you need to get the really high dividends. You must also manage your resources (actions and meepless both) in order to take true advantage of your existing investments without ignoring emergent possibilities. You have to watch out for hostile take-overs from other individuals who have decided they liked what you have built up and want to take it over.

So now I am quite fond of it, particularly with the various expansions both big (Traders & Builder plus Inns & Cathedral) and small (The River II; King & Scout; Cults, Creativity, Siege). It will never be a Top 10 game for me, but it is a game that has earned a definite place in my collection. 

Best with 2>3>Anything else
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
extremely simplistic. Good for a younger crowd. But strategy can make or break your success.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very clean and elegant tile laying game from Hans im Glueck. The city of Carcassonne is constructed by simply drawing a tile and positioning it on the ever increasing game "board". Players score points by playing their coloured pieces onto the played tile as a knight (in cities), farmers (on the green stuff), robbers (on roads) and clergyman (on monasteries). Points are maximised by enlarging the sphere of your piece. Timing is everything, as you only get your pieces back when you complete a sphere. Excellent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Ma come mai Carcassonne tira così tanto al gentil sesso? 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Tipo:[/b] Competitivo // [b]Interacción:[/b] Baja // [b]Azar:[/b] Alto // [b]Rejugabilidad:[/b] Media
[b]Cartas:[/b] No



[b]OPINIÓN PERSONAL:[/b]
El padre de todos los juegos de colocación de losetas, estupendo para iniciar a alguien en los juegos de mesa (aunque para la primera partida recomiendo encarecidamente hacerle caso a las instrucciones y jugar SIN granjeros).

Es un juego que a primera vista parece no tener casi interacción entre jugadores, pero según vas jugando te das cuenta de que (aun sin ser su fuerte) sí que hay "puteo"... y es que no hay nada como ir ampliando una y otra vez la ciudad del rival para que nunca llegue a terminarla, o quitarle una gran urbe/camino colocando estratégicamente a tus meeples. Se podría decir que la interacción es un poco sutil, pero desde luego es un punto clave para alzarte con la victoria (un jugador que nunca fastidie a su rival no tiene nada que hacer contra un oponente más "agresivo").

En cuanto al azar, está claro que tiene un peso importante, pero los grandes jugadores pueden llegar a controlarlo (memorizando cuántas losetas hay de cada tipo y calculando cuántas quedan por salir/qué probabilidad hay de que salga una en concreto). Si no tienes una mente superdotada, siempre puedes añadir alguna regla casera para limitar un poco el azar (como la de tener una mano de dos losetas, y que en tu turno robes una y elijas cual echar de entre las tres)... aunque personalmente creo que para este juego concreto, el azar (y saber cómo adaptarte a él) es uno de sus encantos. Y eso que a mí no suele gustarme nada el azar.

No recomiendo comprar demasiadas expansiones, pues me parece que solo complican (innecesariamente) el juego con miles y miles de pequeñas reglas, pero si se hace quizás sea recomendable quitar unas cuantas losetas antes de empezar a jugar para que la partida no se alargue demasiado (cada ampliación suele añadir unas cuantas losetas, y la partida no se termina hasta que se colocan todas).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I play w/ river & Inns/Cathedrals. This feels pretty good to me. I may add Princess/Dragon at some point.

RATING: 7
One of the games, that you can play with almost everyone, and almost everyone will enjoy the game. I especially like the aesthetics of the game, the slowly growing and meandering landscape. It's somehow hypnotizing. The level of thinking involved is also nice, not too hard, not too easy. The sweet spot. However, this game can be quite vicious, when played aggressively, and some people might get frustrated, or even run crying in their room, just to reappear after 10 min with a hand-crafted piece of exactly the missing shape to fit in their enormous giant caste and filling up the last spot on their monastery ;)

RATING: 8
I was introduced to the world of board gaming with this game.  I fell in love with Carcassonne then and still leap at every chance to play it.  It's quick, strategic, fun, and every game is a little different. Just the look of the board as it grows tile by tile is intriguing.  Though my favorite game may now be far more "hard core", I play this one more often then any other I own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There's little that can be said that hasn't been said a thousand times already, but in any case: 

Carcassonne is a simple, elegant, preeminent example of a German family game. It can be played friendly, or incredibly cutthroat. The game rewards skill to a great degree; there's no need for a hand of tiles. Such a variant is for people who haven't realized the power of blocking and stealing.

The game also works surprisingly well with 2 and greater player counts. The ability to share features becomes something to watch out for and help with or hurt.

The expansions add interest, too. There's certainly enough there to interest both a new and experienced player. Carcassonne is well worth your time, if you haven't yet played it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
I'm constantly surprised bu how many people dismiss this game.  The core game itself is one of the best tile laying games out there. Obviously, expansions just make counting more difficult. Certainly popular with the masses but underrated by hardcore gamers...shame

RATING: 6
While I'd never break it out with the main group, this is an easy choice if I've got anyone fresh to gaming. Turns are simple, strategy is clear, and a lot of luck on the tile draw to even out chances of victory.

New players tend to really appreciate the end result, looking at the map that has been created as a result of the competition. Pick up the Tower expansion for extra gimmicky fun (I can't help it, the tile-draw tower looks great.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The classic game that popularized tile-laying.  There are a lot of factors involved in winning the game: there is the luck of drawing the right tile you need, there is strategy of seeing the best option amongst many on the board; there is also a push-your-luck aspect when you decide if you should finish off a castle or keep going.  Very experienced players may often have an advantage as they’ve already seen all the possible tiles that exist and can even judge the probability of drawing the one they need.  However luck is still a mitigating factor to keep new players involved and usually scores are always very close amongst all players.  
The only cons I can think of is that the scoring session at the end is can be a bit involved, and scoring for the farmers in particular can be a bit of a pain.  There can also be a bit of downtime between turns when playing with five or six players (expansion for sixth player sold separately) especially with players prone to Analysis Paralysis.   The popular house-rule of drawing a tile for your next turn at the end of your current turn is recommended for faster play.   
Overall, this game holds up very well over the years and makes an excellent gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
We found this to be a very enjoyable map building exercise. heh

The game moves briskly with not too much in the way of brain lock.  There are many paths to victory, and it isn't always certain that the same path will work from one game to the next.  Nice, that.

Laying the tiles is fun, running out of meeple workers is not. *grumble*  But therein lies the challenge.  Spend your meeples and plan your tile placements well (AND sprinkle in a bit of luck), you'll emerge the victor.

Easy game to run off two or so in an evening if the motivation is right.

RATING: 10
People say this game has too much luck. After playing it many, many times online and in person, I have to disagree. It's no chess or go, but you definitely need to think and plan. Should I build alone? Should I horn in on another person's city or road? I drew a bad tile, what should I do? 

There is so much tension and so many decision that I think the best players are the ones who can be flexible.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It grows on you like mold.  Slow, fuzzy, and not too offensive smelling.  In fact, for some reason, you keep coming back to smell it.  It actually smells pretty good.  Wait, did I say mold?  I meant moss.  Moss!

The awesome part about this game is that it lets you think with your eyes.  With most Euros I'm crunching numbers in my head and trying to figure out what the other players want to do.  With Carcassonne, I'm visualizing what shape the board can potentially take, and the position of your opponents' pieces flat out tell you what they're thinking.  There's no hidden information here, the board is easy to look at, the scoring options are very straight forward, and they're nicely tied to the layout of the board.  Looking at the board tells you everything you need to know in order to make good decisions.  

This game is really about visualizing what shape you want the board to take and working your darndest to make it happen.  The catch is that everyone else at the table has a vision for the board as well and their visions probably don't match yours.  Fantastic game! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

Not always super interactive, but I think it usually feels competitive in a way that keeps things going. There are a lot of expansions although I rarely bother with them.

RATING: 8
UPDATE: We rarely play this but I think it’s still a good game once you get over the “which version of the city/farmer rules are we using” issue. Get this, get Inns and Cathedrals, then stop.

I think this is still one of the best light games out there. It hits that sweet spot that there is just enough strategy that you can play it as a really light "passing the time" game or as a deeper one (but not too deep). We usually play with a hand of two tiles (play one, then draw) which allows for a more flexible game.

One of my first board game purchases.  Was introduced by the XBox version and bought the physical version because I enjoyed it so much.  A great gateway game.  My family enjoys it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of the few games that simultaneously offers interesting strategy and ease of learning. The mechanics are fairly simple, and can be taught to anyone in about 5-10 minutes, with similarly quick setup and take down times. Game play is fairly fast, and the way the board is constructed greatly increases replay value. 

It scales well too, which comes in handy when you are bringing games for a group and don't know in advance how many people you will have. It is good as an entry game, which is useful to have if your group likes to recruit people who pass by and express interest. 

The only downside is that it does need a fairly large table, which can sometimes be hard to find if you play in stores or coffee shops.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I don't enjoy most tile-placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Bought this for my wife for Christmas, one of my favourites now! Great game.

Ok game but not really that much fun when it's just the wife and I.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Superb.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Carcassonne is the epitome of a gateway experience.  You simply draw a tile and choose a legal location to place it.  After that you can lay a meeple on one of the tiles features for scoring possibilities.  Opponents may try to force there way into your scoring opportunities and then points are given based on majority.  The game works and is alright but I think I would rather play other gateway games like Pandemic or some easy card games with non-gamers.

Edit: This game has been replaced for me by Isle of Skye.

Digital Alert:

I've recently started playing this through iOS and played that way I would rate it an 7 as the benefit of a digital format is the enforced rules, it has a nice tutorial, and the randomization of tiles is done by the computer.  In addition the game is played much faster.  I think playing the physical copy of the game would result in a 5 rating.  So my 6 rating is an average of digital and physical.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great game for all ages. All around fun for the whole family.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love this game, the wife loves it, it is loved.  Definitely play with a 2 or 3 card hand variation.  Also, instead of "draw a tile and play it" draw a new tile at the end of the turn, so you can think about your next move while everyone else is going.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good starting place for newer games. Simple rules with enough decisions to keep at least new people interested. I like the fact that you can block other players if you want to.

Feeling however is a bit bland and the game gets a bit boring after a while and therefore I nowadays prefer Hunter&Gatherers as the one box Carcassonne-solution. The other option is to use expansions with the original.

RATING: 7
Some people have complained about randomness in this game, but I don't care.  The game doesn't last long enough (usually less than an hour) for it to really matter.  It's fun to draw a tile, and figure out the best placement.  There's more strategy to this game than you may initially think; players tend to overlook the ability to frustrate another player's game, and automatically play a tile in the best possible position for themselves.  The game definitely improves with expansions, although each one adds to the playing time.

RATING: 8
This is a really lovely game. First, minimal set up time. Second, the bits are of good quality and the meeples are iconic. Third, the game play is satisfying and really shines as a cut-throat two player game. Fourth, the time to play is the same for any number of players. I suggest you invest in some expansion right away, you'll probably only use the base game as an introduction for new players. After that you'll be looking for more variety and depth very soon after. 

Includes I&C, T&B, Phantom, and Mini Expansion #1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love Carcassonne and can play 4 or 5 games in a row.  We usually always add an expansion or two since each expansion changes your strategy.  But sometimes we will play with just the base game for a quick 10 minute game.  Each expansion adds its own uniqueness to the game and causes you to alter your plan accordingly.  

*Note: I would rate just the base game with no expansions an 8, but with the ability to change the game each time it is played it is a perfect game that does not take too long to play.

I would rank the expansions as follows:
1. Inns & Cathedras
2. Traders & Builers
3. The Tower
4. Abbey & Mayor
5. Wheel of Fortune
6. Princess & Dragon
7. Castles, Bridges & Bazaars

I would rank the mini-expansions as follows:
1. Phantom
2. Plague
3. Festival
4. Tunnels
5. River II
6. Die Schule
7. Crop Circles
8. Count
9. Cult, Siege and Creativity
10. River I
11. Mini-Expansion
12. King & Scout

Construye cosas rápidas para poder recuperar a tus hombrecitos y al mismo tiempo intenta cerrar una gran ciudad; los monasterios son puntos seguros y las granjas.... en las granjas está la clave, pero si te sale mal puedes perder la partida por tener a los muñequitas en las granjas y sin producir en otro lado. De las cosas más divertidas es intentar robar ciudades o caminos largos a otros jugadores.

RATING: 8
[b][thread=472221]The PLAYMOBIL® Legion reviews "Carcassonne"[/thread][/b]

(As of [b]11+[/b] plays) The classic tile-laying game. The concept and basic rules are easy to explain, while the strategy involved can be picked up relatively quickly by new players. The [GAMEID=2993] expansion is not necessary, but rounds things out nicely. Another game that, while no longer at the front of my play queue, will always have a place in my collection.

[b]3 year verdict:[/b] Hasn't had much play recently, but I would never turn down a game and would love to revisit it. A classic for a reason.

RATING: 5
[b]Update[/b]
Having since played it in person, it feels like a very average game. Had no desire at all to return to the app. Uninstalled.

-------------Original rating 25/03/16 Score:6
[b]Rating based on - 25+ plays, 1 player vs AI and 2 player Android app[/b]
I avoided this game for a long time because it is popular and a household name. I don't usually go for the mainstream and in fact (after now owning more than 100 games) I am only just getting to what are the major 'gateway' games. In addition, looking at how the game played 'draw one tile, place that tile' it seemed quite limited and not very strategic. How can you make a long term decision with drawing just one tile? Where is the strategy in that? Would it not be better to have 2 tiles in hand and choose one? How do you mitigate bad tile draws? Are you not then at the mercy of the game?

Many, many months ago I got this as the Amazon free app of the day and still had not played it until recently. Since tile placement is my favourite game mechanism I decided it was finally worth a try. I was pleasantly surprised. It's more fun than I thought it would be. Although, how much of that is the cute graphical interface and how much of it is 'new game haze' I'm not sure. The game is OK. Sometimes tile draws are crap. A lot of the time the other person gets what you need. I'm not looking to rush out and get a copy any time soon but it's kind of addictive. The app finds matches for you to play and playing against humans instead of the AI is a real eye opener. It's interesting to see how some people play this game. Even when they can score for themselves they are looking to screw you over :D I like the fact that it's just a faceless person you game with. I see no need for 'chat' options in games. I am not looking to make new online friends. I'm looking to play games and have fun!
[b]Status: UNINSTALLED[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.7
This is another go-to game that is light but also provides opportunity for strategy. It's great for a quick game and especially for new players or players who cant take in a lot of rules or before mentally checking out before the game even begins. Each player draws tiles and the anticipation of the draw is what makes the game fun. It's a fantastic feeling of accomplishment when you finally draw that one piece you've been waiting for the whole game and you circle the point board twice because of the massive area you just finished. Points go fast in this game and a player who is far behind may suddenly catch up and pass the player after a single tile draw that changes the game. Great time for anyone

RATING: 8
lent to ON
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
An excellent tile-laying game, children also enjoy the game play and medieval theme immensely.  2001 SDJ winner.  Best with just two players.  House-rule of having three tiles in hand is worth considering when playing with more than two players, to make the game more strategic and less dependent on luck-of-the-draw.  At the very least, draw your tile after your turn, so that players can plan their move and avoid downtime.  

Recommended: play with [url=http://www.riograndegames.com/uploads/Game/Game_48_gameRules.pdf]third edition rules[/url], where scoring is more consistent:
- 2 tile cities are worth 4 points (i.e. all cities and pennants score 2 points per tile)
- farmers scoring works by scoring each field, not each city (i.e. calculate which farmers control a field, and then that field scores 3 points per completed city touching that field)
These 3rd Edition rules score fields just like all other features: (a) points go to the players with the most followers in the feature; (b) remove followers, score next.  
See [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/319545]here[/url] for discussion on 1st vs 3rd edition rules.

Expansions I own:
[gameid=2993] - Unlike the other Carcassonne expansions, this doesn't change the game as dramatically, and makes it work better with up to six players.  Inns: increase point scoring opportunities; Cathedrals: can make for massive point-swing cities, not sure how good they are; Large follower: having an 8th meeple is good, but one worth 2x can make the game more vicious because when you sneak in a field or city you don't just share points but can actually steal them. 
[gameid=7707] - Mini-expansion, worth trying, the seven "King" tiles are for regular Carcassonne.  King/Robber: fiddly for point scoring and too big swings when playing with expansions; Extra tiles: good.
[gameid=12903] - Small expansion which gives the game an interesting twist.
[gameid=2591] - Came as part of my Carcassonne game.  Starting with the River tiles gives a good, broad starting area with more choices, and helps break up fields. (note: the farm goes around the spring, as discussed [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/383180]here[/url]).
Have also upgraded the meeples with Spielbox stickers.

Marred by having a high degree of randomness (e.g. no hand to work with, but just a draw each time).  Open discussion of each tile is a mixed blessing, keeping weaker players in the game, but sometimes equalizing the game within the margin of randomness.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the most noteworthy aspects of this game is that since there is no resources saved between the turns, there cannot be a lot of thinking of what to do next - it is all decided by what tile is drawn. This limits the amount of strategy that can be employed, but it also has a very positive effect - you can sit back and enjoy your beer while the other players take their turns!

RATING: 9
Egyszerű szabályok (túl sok kiegészítővel már azért nem annyira), hihetetlen interaktivitás, szórakoztató játékmenet. Nagy előnye, hogy két fővel, illetve max. fővel is játszható, de ez esetben azért számítani lehet a hosszabb holtidőre. Tökéletes családi játék, illetve tökéletes játék arra, hogy a nem társasjátékozó ismerőseinknek bemutassuk ezt a világot! Az első két kiegészítőt mindenképpen érdemes beszerezni, mert nagyon sokat adnak hozzá a játékélményhez! De túlzásokba nem érdemes esni a kiegészítőket illetően, mert mind összetettség, mind játékidő szempontjából nagyon meg tudja nyújtani a játékot. Bár az utóbbi időben háttérbe szorult a sok újabb játékunk miatt, de azért elő-elő kerül időként.

RATING: 6

+ Easily accessible.
+ Low price.
> I'm not interested in the expansions out there. I feel that playing with more than one expansion increases the playing time significantly, while not adding much to gameplay.
- Not as balanced as I was hoping for -- it seems that playing followers on roads is inferior to playing them on cities or fields. (A quick fix might work: each road tile is worth 2 points except the ends?)

RATING: 7
[2014 July 06; 21 plays; 7/10]
I think this game plays best with 2 players, but will typically look for a different game if there are more than that.

Most plays have been 2-player games with my girlfriend. She loves the simple strategy and how well it balances the skill gap, but she really doesn't like us to be cutthroat; this puts us both in an awkward position of trying to figure out how the other will take our more aggressive tiles.

Regardless, even playing with others where I can play freely, I've just played this game too much since I got it (February, 2014). I'm bored of it.

RATING: 9
One of the best games ever played.

* Enjoyed by people that have never played board games before as well as veterans.
* Good for families with kids 6+ years old.
* Easy to teach.
* Open to house rules to make it easier or harder (like no farmers, less/more workers to use etc).
* Tons of expansions (with the first one pushing the game to 10/10 for me, the rest are up to personal preference).
* Fine art (i enjoy the reprint a lot).
* Cheap game and very cheap expansions.
* Huge replayability.

Lost one point because i think the game goes to 10/10 with some expansions : river for a better start and inns&cathedrals for some tile diversity even if you don't use the additional rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
[COLOR=#FF0000][b]2-5 players[/b][/COLOR]

[b]Best w/ 2[/b], ok w/ 3, not so keen on more

With competitive players, too much of game hinges on "Will I draw the tile I need to connect me up or will you draw the one that closes me out first?".

Play almost daily on Asobrain:

Me vs. 1 bot
Inns & Cathedrals
Traders & Builders

Try to break 300 points (do it maybe 1 or 2 in 10 games).

Games played like that take me about 10 minutes, playing against even one other human player takes 40 minutes.

RATING: 7
Can be cutthroat or just a nice relaxing game depending on how you play it. I enjoy the map that is created at the end of each game. There are interesting risks to take depending on where you place your meeples, and you need to be sure you actually complete some of them so you can reuse them for more scoring opportunities.

Worth noting, this is the first game to get my wife interested in the hobby!

RATING: 9
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ easy to learn (you can play it with your kids, your mom, or even with your gf or wife :P)
+ nicely printed elements
+ solid base for expansions
+ great fun for several matches before you know what elements are included in the game
+ relatively cheap game

[b]Cons:[/b]
- definitely needs exapnsions to make a play more diversified and less boring
- downtimes at a later stage of a match (especialy if u play with expansions)
- if this game didn't provide any expansions, I would probably downgrade it to 6 or so...

RATING: 9
A perennial favorite.  Simple game and we enjoy table talk during tile placement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played with 4. 
Used Rivers Expansion.

One of the easiest games to introduce new players to.  I would explain the basics of scoring but not get too long in explaining as the games end fairly quickly.  After a game or two most people will understand the scoring and city mechanics.  The game is played by laying down tiles and placing meeples on different parts of said tile to create roads, cities, monasteries and other scoring areas on the board.  

I enjoy this game a lot more than Settlers of Catan if only because you do not have the resource trading that can agitate players, nor do you have the streak of really bad rolls or unlucky pick order.  I would score it an 8 if you are playing with the "competition" rule of drawing 3 tiles initially and redrawing one after each tile played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
