RATING: 7
An excellent short game that is just the right blend of luck, strategy, and opportunism, Carcassonne works best when you want to kill half an hour to forty-five minutes with a friend or two.  Involves just enough planning to keep you thinking, but is simple enough that you never feel intimidated or stressed while playing; I've avoided expansions (for the time being) specifically because the simplicity is integral to the enjoyment my friends and I get out of this game.  One of my personal favorite lighter fare games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
* Played 50+ times. GREAT "GATEWAY" GAME! "Non-gamers" really like this. It's simple (draw a tile, and decide whether or not to put a follower on one of the tiles). I think that Carcassonne Hunters & Gatherers (a standalone sequel) is a better game than Carcassonne by itself, but the expansions for Carcassonne are so good (Inns & Cathedrals should be standard with this game; Traders & Builders is a fun way to mix it up; Princess & Dragon adds more randomness but is a lot of fun with more players and families...) So if you only play 2-players, you might want Carassonne the City; if you will never buy any expansions, you might want Carcassonne Hunters & Gatherers or Carcassonne Discovery); but if you are willing to shell out a bit more money for one or two expansions, Carcassonne is the way to go. *** I highly recommend using the 3rd Edition scoring rules for farmers. [o/s/o/g/o]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the first Euro my wife and I tackled, and it remains our favorite.  We prefer to play with lots of expansions (my rating to the left is for the base game with no expansions), so all of the extra tiles and rules mean we pretty much only play original Carc together or with our friends who are as obsessed as we are. Even for us, though, expansion fatigue has kicked in, and we're finally done buying them. (This was after The Catapult, around the time Z-Man acquired the game.) Out of what we own, here's my take on what you need and what you can do without:    

[u]Essential expansions:[/u] [thing=2993]Inns & Cathedrals,[/thing] [thing=5405]Traders & Builders[/thing]

[u]Strongly suggested for experienced players:[/u] [thing=31784]Abbey & Mayor,[/thing] [thing=35666]Cult, Siege & Creativity,[/thing] the King portion of the [thing=7707]King & Scout[/thing] expansion, [thing=92332]The Phantom[/thing]

[u]Nice to have, but entirely optional:[/u] [thing=2591]The River[/thing] (included in our copy of the base game), [thing=18836]The River II,[/thing] [thing=26615]The Mini-Expansion[/thing]

[u]Recommended for the hardcore only, or those wanting more direct screwage:[/u] [thing=12903]The Count,[/thing] [thing=21385]The Tower,[/thing] [thing=15158]The Princess & the Dragon[/thing]

[u]Objectively silly, but we couldn't resist:[/u] [thing=38855]The Catapult[/thing]

I would advise those looking for a complete Carc experience in a single purchase to check out [thing=4390]Hunters & Gatherers[/thing] or [thing=6779]The Ark Of the Covenant,[/thing] or even [thing=12902]The City[/thing] if you want more of a "gamer" version.

My recorded plays include all expansions except for The Count, The Tower, and The Princess & The Dragon, which are all recorded separately.

RATING: 8
This was the German game that got me hooked so what can I say?  It will always be a favorite.  The whole idea of creating a board as you play combined with the short rules and cool bits just blew my mind.  Putting the tiles out always feels creative to me.  Whimsical, light and happy, this is a game that makes me smile.  I love the artwork. I recommend it for kids and adults. We always draw one tile ahead to keep the turns moving.  We don't use the river expansion but do use Inns and Cathedrals.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like Alhambra, this game should not be played with more than three players, otherwise it will get too chaotic. I think the reason why this game has been so successful is that it (like PR) can be played on many different levels, both laidback and very cutthroat. I quite like the vanilla version, because it makes it easier to keep track of the tile distribution and gives the players more chances to block each other. With two good players that know the tiles well this can be an almost chess-like experience. And if you are concerned about the luck of draw there are many variants out there to mitigate that as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think the strong points of this game are it's scalablity in players from 2-6 as well as complexity and time with the expansions.  There's few games that are so versatile.  It can be extremely easy and light, or long and somewhat complex.  I suggest anyone look at the variants who haven't.  It pretty much appeals to everyone as well.  No one can resist a meeple I guess.

RATING: 3
[Tile-laying] [2P:4, 3P:3, 4P:3] How in the world did Carcassonne win the DSP? It's so fluffy and random, makes Puerto Rico a computational monster. It's still a decent gateway game to introduce the non-gamers to German-style boardgames, but more than three players increases the downtime (and the already-limited pleasure of putting tiles down) too much. The expansions don't do anything to improve this simple, rather boring game. Carc is most suited for children and non-gamer family and friends. *** UPDATE: Revisited the game to give it another chance, and it fell flat on its face with two newbies. It also bored me three-quarters to death. I really do not understand the appeal, but I'm not playing this or any of its non-Knizia derivatives ever again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My first Euro-style game. I really like it so far, and enjoy the mechanic. It's relaxing and fun, with enough depth to keep you interested and guessing the whole game.

Pros:

*Simple on the outside, deep on the inside. 
*Long term strategy. If you only plan a couple turns ahead, you loose. 
*City building is a great theme and makes the game as interesting as it is.
*Meeples
*Short turns, fairly quick yet very satisfying game.
*Good quality bits, and plain old fun

Cons:
*I love expansions, but man... too many. 
*Expansions needed to keep the game interesting (after a good 15 plays or so, imo), which means lots of moneys. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I'm actually enjoying it less with more plays (and with more players) and haven't felt the remotest desire to pull this out in a long, long time. I feel like I'm missing something as for some reason, I'm just not as into it as most other people are. 

It's a good 2-player option to have around and an easy to explain/play gateway game, though I have to admit, no non-gamer I've taught has really fallen in love with this game unlike Settlers, TTR or Pandemic. As games go quick, I'm always happy to play this to teach and am glad I own it even if I'd rather play other games.

RATING: 9
While not the perfect game, I do love Carcassonne.

As with all games where you draw a single tile or card blindly, you are at the mercy of luck.  But a fair bit of this game's strategy is ensuring you don't need to rely on luck, and making the best with what you get.

Lots and lots of expansions make Carcassonne quite customizable, though some expansions are better than others.  Buying a couple of the large expansions or a Big Box is almost obligatory.

Of all the games I own, this is in my top 3.

RATING: 7
Possibly my favorite gateway game thanks to the straightforward rules and lack of setup time.

I recommend playing without the farmer when teaching it to people new to modern board games. It's also worth noting that some people just flat out struggle to "get" farms. Some people I've played with really enjoy the game but fail to visualize the farms, making it difficult for them to keep up and compete.

Nowadays, we don't play without The River, Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders.

RATING: 10
This one comes out with the family a lot. Lot's of people think of it as a gateway game, but I have trouble teaching it. I have had success teaching the first game without farms, then adding farms the second game.

It also makes a great lunchtime game.
-----------------------------
[Update] This will probably continue to be the family's most played game for a while. It has enough elements for my wife, who likes an asthetically pleasing result, and finds that more important than a win. It has enough tactically to satisfy my son and I, who are a little more cutthroat. Actually, we have a friend who wins regularly by playing a low key, opportunistic game while the sharks are out eating each other, so there are lots of routes to success.

The basic game plays quickly, particularly if you take the next tile at the end of your turn, giving you a "hand" of one tile. That gives everyone a chance to think a little before their turn arrives. The end result is a game with strategically solid game played in roughly an hour.

Carefull with expansions.  I think it would be pretty easy to have a pretty chaotic experience if one tried to play too many expansions at once.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great modern classic with a split personality: it is accessible and friendly, making it the perfect gateway to the hobby; but also strategic and cutthroat, to keep veterans coming back. Tweak it to best suit the occasion; from a fast, laid-back, cooperative-feeling experience for beginners; to a multi-layered, competitive epic (by throwing in some of the many available expansions and house rules). You can't go wrong with this one.

RATING: 8
Played first game of this today (6-28-2012) with Mr. Billington.  I lost, but we both had fun.  He wants to play it again, and so do I.  Played second game of this today (7-7-2012) with Mr. Billington.  This time I won (114-112, I think).  We're getting better at it (especially learning which scores are worth going after at which times during the game, and how to score for various parts) and enjoying it more.  Wish there were more tiles in each copy of the game.  The game seems to end so soon as is.  Maybe that's a good thing.  Regret that there wasn't more is always a plus.  Gott sei dank fur Herr Wrede!  Played two games of this today (7-8-2012) with Noelle; first game was interrupted halfway through by my mom's cat Tusk, but Noelle was winning; second game Noelle won (but had I finished my last (big) castle, I would've won, though not by a whole lot).  Another game of this today (7-13-2012) with Mr. Billington (I won; 85 or 95 to 75, I think), and we both discovered that more aggressive/back-stabbing games tend to have fewer points than non-aggressive/non-back-stabbing games.  Not sure if this is true for other players, though.  Now have 3 sets of the basic game, so that should make it even *more* fun to play (okay, and longer too).  Can't wait to play a three-set game!  Played incomplete 2-set game (plus River II expansion) today and definitely the hot weather didn't help either myself or my opponent.  But I think we liked the new setup.  At least I did.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Juegazo con el que me inicié, junto a Catán, pero que ha aguantado el paso del tiempo muchísimo mejor y aún hoy me apetece seguir jugándolo y expandiéndolo. Me parece que está infravalorado entre jugones. Sin dejar de ser un juego ligero de reglas, sí permite jugar estratégicamente y usar cada loseta y trabajador de manera muy meditada. Y lo mejor es el puteo de robar construcciones, que es la chicha que más gusta en partidas entre jugones y que genera piques revancheros.

Las ilustraciones de Doris Matthaus me parecen geniales y me hacen pensar que estoy jugando a un juego de mesa de los antiguos, añejo, de cuando era pequeño.

En cuanto a las expansiones, aconsejo jugar el base más dos expansiones grandes o el base más una expansión grande y otra pequeña. Si caemos en el error de incluir más expansiones de la cuenta, el juego se eterniza, ocupa demasiada mesa y además algunas mecánicas de expansiones quedan eclipsadas por otras que son más rentables.

RATING: 8
Easy to learn easy to play and there's something satisfying about seeing a little countryside constructed from nothing but a one tile seed.  

The game offers enough strategic variety to stay interesting over multiple plays, but the fact that you never know quite what to expect (unless you spend far more time counting tiles than I care to) leaves a bit of room for some good surprises and slightly tense bits.

Good fun all around!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The first game that I bought when I got back into board gaming.

I don't play it as much as I used to - there are just so many other great games competing for play time - but, I will always keep a copy in my collection.

I prefer it with 2 or 3 players as it keeps things tight and moving along. Would stretch to 4 but would avoid anything over that as the game can drag at that point.

The game has a bit more going on than it first seems which is great for players of different experience. You can build this landscape together and pick up your points or start to engineer geographical ambushes to hijack the points from rivals farms and cities.

It's a "gateway" game with legs.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A regular at our weekly board game sessions.

RATING: 7
I've played Carcassonne - Hunters and Gatherers before this one and rate it a solid 9. The original Carcassonne is much less interesting with the rules saying you score unfinished roads and towns. I think there are fixes and variants everywhere on the web but I don't care for them since H&G comes packed with a good and simple rule. Also, scoring meadows is simpler and more interesting in H&G.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like a lot about this game - competitive, probabilistic thinking, and interesting tension between short term, medium term, and long term point gains. My son started playing this when he was 4 (no farmers), and full rules by the age of 5 and he continues to like it.

However, my wife SO doesn't like the end-of-game importance of farmers (where everything you've worked towards all game can be undone by 1 or 2 skillful and/or lucky farmer placements) that it's hard to get her to play. The result is that we play this far less than comparable gateway games. That's what brings down the score for me - if it's hard to get my favorite game partner to play, then what good is it?

We tried the expansion Traders and Builders and that made it even more fun for me but less for my wife. Haven't used any of the other expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Carcassonne is one of my favourite games and one of the favourites of my group of players. Why? 1) Carcassonne has easy to learn rules, but not so easy to win strategic “tricks” (you can learn its rules in one hour but you can’t say you’re a good player after you have played this game at least ten or more times. 2) Thematic is very, very good appointed for a game like this; 3) All its components are well done and pretty look designed; 4) Mechanics are so simple (in appearance), but so brilliant and well balanced after all! I simply love Carcassonne and in my opinion this one must be ranked between the first twenty games in the BGG board games ranking scale.

RATING: 6

Unfortunately, a lot of the game is centered around stealing particularly valuable features which is basically luck based in effectiveness.

RATING: 6
Purchased 05/17/06--version with River expansion included


After one 2p play (w/o River)--nice, fast, fun filler.  Again, I'm not sure 2p is the best config for this (many games advertise 2p as an option, and I'm starting to think that's just pure marketing rather than any sort of truth).  Not "crowded" enough for 2p.  I did notice that due to farmers I totally destroyed my brother by over 40 points (and 36 of that came from farmers...)

Won't go expansion happy with this.  Will try soon with 3 or 4.  Might look into one or two of the more highly regarded expansions.


Rating certainly might go up after more plays.


EDIT:  This one is starting to drop faster than expected...last two plays have been sort of "meh".  Getting very samey.  I have a few expansions already but they only help a little.  Down from an 8 to a 7.


HAVE THESE SMALL EXPANSIONS:

The Mini Expansion
The River
The Count of Carcassonne

RATING: 8
Carcassonne with traders and builders expansion is tremendous fun.  I also recommend Inns and Cathedrals. It is fairly strategic (in a light, fun way) when you play with 2-3 players.  You can't use as much planning ahead when you play with more players, but it's just fun no matter what!  For someone who plays with light gamers or regular gamers, this game is just ideal.  I believe with the 2 mentioned expansions, this one goes way beyond what you expect.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.274
Brilliant as a first choice Eurogame when introducing a newbie; but probably a bit too too much luck over tactics to regularly sustain playing.  When 4 or 5 players, game starts to become too chaotic to be tactical. More a game for those who enjoy the journey rather than the destination (and hence for 5 players, would -1 from rating if not with newbies).  River expansion a mild diversion if you were a regular player, and you may need to clarify which edition rules you are using at the start of play, otherwise there will be argument over scoring of farmers (13/12/08).  UPDATE: the iPhone application has resulted in my rediscovery of how wonderful this game is, especially after I introduced it at work and with friends.  It really is an enjoyable classic, and I update the rating from 7 to 9, especially as the 4-5 player game starts introduction the concept of mini-alliances which can negate some of the luck of the cards (26/12/10).  UPDATE: To clarify rating, I have given vanilla Carc a rating of 7, but Inns & Cathedrals as a 9; hard to imagine not playing this with the expansion except when introducing the game to newbies - clearly an active game and a definite classic of Eurogaming (17/9/11). UPDATE: Vanilla Carc is still a great game (8.274; May 15).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For those who complain about how simple, random, and boring it is: play with smarter people. It's simplicity is deceptive, and while tile-draws are random and memorizing the deck helps, in the end it comes down to thinking ahead and cleverly positioning yourself for the future.

The balance is wonderful-- while cloisters seem hugely important for the first couple games, you will soon realize that a well thought-out farm or stolen city can be just as effective. This mixture of easy-to-grasp concepts paired with devious strategies make this one of the best games ever.

Everyone who I've taught it to, gamers and non alike, has loved it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic.  Relatively fast play, always different board.  An enjoyable balance between luck and forging your own destiny.  Lots of room for taking chances that work or fail.  Simple to learn.  A great tile-laying game.  Deserves to be considered one of the classics of modern board gaming.

RATING: 8

Adding tiles from other expansions is recommended, but most other rulesets just add cruft in my opinion.  The only extra rules that I think are worthwhile are the trading rules from Builders and Traders (the builder's C-C-C-Combo ability is ridiculous).

As a gateway, I haven't found this goes over as well as TTR or card games, but I don't recall anyone having poor opinions of it.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I find Carcassonne to be a wonderful game that can host a large number of people with varying difficulty.  As far as adding expansions I believe only Inns & Cathedrals, and Traders & Builders to be a must.  All others add their own little thing, but in many ways bog down this little gem.

Update:  the more I play games of Carc the more I find the things that make me truly recognize what a brilliant design this game is.  It may have the luck of the draw, but it offers a gateway experience, and light quick play that surpasses most other titles of similar ilk.  Although many new games have adopted the tile laying mechanic, I really think Wrede did it the most elegant.

RATING: 9
I carried this with me while backpacking: it's portable and can be played on any flat surface. It's rules are simple and don't take too long to explain (and I've explained them a few dozen times now), and yet those rules create a really fun and interesting game. The motif is well-chosen for the game mechanic and adds to the ease of learning and the fun. This is the game that brought me back into board gaming, and through it I've introduced many other people to the idea that board games are (so much) more than Scrabble and Monopoly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Truly excellent (light) game. Together with the expansions it's even better. The game can get aggressive and very exciting with experienced players and is not dull at all (like some misguided, inexperienced players claim). 

I prefer playing a variant in which every player has 4 tiles on his hand, plays a tile and replenishes the hand at the end of his/her turn. This way it's more strategic and tactical and less random. 

I also prefer the 3rd edition rules for scoring farms.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Carcassonne is a great game.  Since I do not own any expansions, I enjoy it best with 2 players.  More than that and the game goes a little too quickly since there are only so many tiles to go around with the base set.  I also prefer to play where you have two tiles in hand to choose from instead of just blindly drawing one.  It just gives you move options and it burns a little less when you draw 3 road tiles in a row.
It is pretty simple to teach and plays quickly, so people pick it up pretty quickly, but there is a ton of strategy built into this little game.  Especially true when you play with two tiles instead of one.
All around a solid game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Don't really like it, more as a puzzle than a game... 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Too much take that for my liking, however the game mechanics are fine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game on its own is alright. Just alright. Definite potential. But the game REALLY comes to life with the expansion 'Inns and Cathedrals'. As many say, it should have been part of the original game. After adding that expansion and 'Traders and Builders' it feels more rounded and robust in strategies.

Lots of people mention the luck factor in the game, but I think it's all about making the tiles you draw work for you. You have to be flexible and go with the flow in this game. There is limited planning ahead BECAUSE of the luck of the draw, but it doesn't dampen the strategy too much. Even so, you can make a slight rule modification that you can hold 2 or 3 tiles in your hand.

But all in all, I often wonder why this game is always in the top 15. I mean, it's not THAT good. It's an OK time passer, but not something I would consider spectacular enough to be among the top rated and most popular games. And when introducing this game to new players, it's hit or miss. Many don't seem to like it at all. So just keep that in mind.


For trade. In like new condition, also have the expansions Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, and The River II

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[Original comment] Great family game -- especially for folks who like a challenge, but who don't care for war games or themes of violence or mayhem. Can be played friendly or very competitive.

Update February 2006 -- We always play with three expansions: The River, Inns and Cathedrals, and Traders and Builders. The latter two add lots of scoring variables, which makes the game more challenging. Great for 5 or 6 players.

(December 2006) We've added some components, to allow for 7 players, and it works fine. This is a very popular game in our family group.

May 2009 -- This is still a favorite game for us, and we play it occasionally.

October 2011 -- We continue to play with the same expansions and thoroughly enjoy this game. It is one of my favorites.

November 2012 -- This game never grows old, and remains a family favorite. Recently, in a 3-player game, it appeared my son and I had tied (with over 300 points, each), until I noticed and told him that he had a few more points coming, with his pig in one of the fields he scored. Great game!

2013-November: Another year, and we still like this game very much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As time has gone by, my rating of this one has slowly dropped. When it was new, it was great! Innovative! Awesome!

But over time, other games have implemented or re-implemented elements of this game in a faster-playing way. And then this got bogged down by a steady churn of expansions (the first couple are really good, but the game really went downhill after that).

It started as a nine for our group, and is now a six.  It hasn't hit the table in ... a long while, actually, and I'll be surprised if it hits the table any time soon.

RATING: 9
Good by itself, but excellent with the T&B and I&C expansions added in. Plenty of tiles in the bag to generate some truly epic farming wars. Play the original farmer scoring (4 points per city) as our Creator intended.

For a shorter game, throw the 50/100 tiles into the bag and stop after a pre-agreed number have been drawn (thanks Richard Garfield).

RATING: 5
Entertaining.  Don't play it with too many players, and IMHO don't play it too often.  I rarely play it and I am just fine with that.  If someone wants to play it or bring it out, I'd be glad to play.  But I don't crave to play it or delight in games of Carcassonne.  It is an excellent starter Euro if that's your bag, once you get past the (often decisive) farmer scoring.

Incidentally, the Xbox Live implementation is quite good.  I grabbed it when it was free for Live's 5th birthday.

This is another good game, designwise, that I've worn out and is slightly boring to me.

RATING: 8
Very simple game (despite the intial description of rules and gameplay), may seem bland for some, scales very well, more strategy than it appears at first, but some luck in drawing the 'right' tiles.

Edit:
Of the 3 major gateways, this is probably (and unexplicably) my favorite. I believe it plays best with 2 players, and with more it does scale well but is a bit less strategic (but fun nonetheless). Additionally, I have yet to try it with any expansions, as the game seems fairly well balanced as it is and I'm afraid the expansions may change the gameplay a bit more than I would like.

RATING: 6
Difficult to rate accurately, to the extent that it matters. Carc has been so often expanded that what does it even mean to rate the base game alone any more?

This was one of my first euro-style games and thus has nostalgic value, but I'm trying to eliminate that from how I think of games. It is a very good 2p in general, significantly less interesting with more people.

A light sprinkling of expansions is probably best, preferably only River, I&C, and maaaybe T&B.

No dragons, no walls, no counts, no effing catapults.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Carcassonne[/b] [i]Klaus Jurgen Wrede 2000[/i] 
An excellent game for beginners, but also playable for gamers. This game is at its best when played with its first two expansions: Inns and Cathedrals and Traders and Builders. Abbey and Major is your third call, good expansion only if you own the other two as well. By its own, Carcassonne is a friendly game that usually is a hit with non gamers, but must be played at most with four players. More people around the table make and the game evolves to a festival of chaos. I dont like some of the newer expansions do, which add chaos, randomness and unnecessary complications. Otherwise is the only gateway game I own and a very clever design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
This is my girlfriend's favorite game (I think).  More often than not, if I ask whether she wants to play a game, this is it, although Touch of Evil might replace it.  This game is insanely easy to teach/learn and is just simply fun, you can be up and running in under 5 minutes.  This is still a fun game but I'm beginning to worry that I'm getting burned out on it.  This is such a standard "go-to" that I feel like that this is the only thing that gets play.  I'm tempted at times to pick up some expansions, but I really don't know how much it will affect the game as the base set seems extremely appealing to my girlfriend and I don't want to alter it to the point where she won't want to play.

RATING: 9
I'm a big fan of Carcassonne, like many other people I'm sure.  I find it very easy to teach, and when you pack the big box down into a Plano Box, it travels very well.

I don't love how much the beating someone by linking up fields can dictate things, but it's a minor quibble.  I know some people don't love the "big city wins" thing, so perhaps it's a matter of taste.

There isn't really an expansion I don't like.  Pretty much always play with traders and builders, and inns and cathedrals.  The rest are sort of hit and miss as to whether we play with them.

RATING: 7
Super fun game.  Actually HIGHLY recommend the Big Box 3.  Great value.  This game is a worker placement/tile layer that provides a quick set up and clean up with lots of strategy in the middle.  Becomes a 9 with Inns and Cathedrals and Traders and Builders. 

I only play the variant where you start with 3 tiles and then draw back up to three at the end of your turn.  This is as opposed to draw 1 tile at the beginning of the turn.  The variant is MUCH faster.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife and I truly love this game.  It works best as a 2 player, but doesn't suffer much in a 3 player game.  More than that and it weakens a bit because each player has fewer turns.

We often use this as one of our intro games to get non-gamers interested in playing board games with us.  The mechanics are super simple.  I've been able to teach my 5 year old niece and my in-laws to play.  

Simple mechanics, easy to grasp, very enjoyable.

UPDATE: after not playing it for almost a year, we got it out on a night we didn't have the energy for a longer / heavier game.  It's still refreshingly great.  It's light enough that we can have an interesting conversation while playing and it doesn't interfere with figuring out our moves, but it's not so light that it's boring.  I removed Traders & Builders and the River II, leaving only Inns & Cathedrals and it plays smoother and more elegantly.  What a great way to spend time together.  This game probably more than any other turned my wife and I into board gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Definitely worthy of its reputation and its popularity.  Carcassonne is one of those rare games that appeals to hobby gamers, families, and even non-gamers.  It has surpassed Bohnanza, Settlers of Catan, Daytona 500, Union Pacific, and Showmanager as my #1 game to pull out with non-gamers. [Edit: it has since been usurped in this capacity by Ticket to Ride.]  And among seasoned gamers, the game reveals a surprising level of depth.  By all means, use the original farmer scoring rules (4 points awarded per city to whomever has the most farmers touching the city).  It is better balanced, more intuitive, and easier to explain than the later revisions.  Carcassonne in its basic configuration rates at least an 8 with me, and judicious use of expansions knocks it to a solid 9 or even approaching 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The fact that I can play it with all members of my family and we all enjoy it is why its rated this high.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne is a fun, easy to learn game that supports a good number of players (up to 5 or 6 with expansions).

I played with slightly adjusted rules -- roads were worth 2 points if completed, just like castles. This made the game feel a little less luck based (sometimes you just don't draw any castle tiles).

There are plenty of important decisions to be made in game based only on the mechanics, but managing how you cooperate or compete with others is the real meat of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game is great in that its fast to teach and you can coach new players through their moves. It's a reasonable balance of luck and strategy. Expansions mean that you can really change the dynamics of the game to make it more competitive or cooperative. We started with the basic game which came with the river and have added the Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders expansions but I would have happily bought the biggest "Big Box" they made. This game has been such a good investment. It's not amazingly fun, but it's a solid game with great replay value and versatility.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Like too many people, one of my first Euro-games (after Settlers). I could not be happier. I return to Carcassonne again and again. Have found, however, that I get bored with too many people. Luck increases significantly with higher numbers. Prefer good 2-player cut-throat games. Inns & Cathedrals a must. Traders & Builders preferred. (Rest of the expansions? Meh.)

Good gateway but have found that the farm rules are confusing for many non-gamers the first time around. Also, regular players have a significant advantage because of knowledge of the tiles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Carcassonne was probably the game that introduced me to the hobby (and it was the first game I got as a gift) and I have introduced other players to the hobby with this game. And for that alone it has my greatest respect as a game. Later I played this game too much and my view of it has faded quite a bit. Usually I prefer to play games with players that are experienced in the game, but this is not true for this game, since I found that people that know too much about the distribution of tiles (and even tile counting). There are measures that can be made against it (by playing several expansions and remove tiles), but it is not what I usually do. With more plays, many moves seem to be automatic or random since you don’t know what will come up in the next tile draw.

There is a wide appeal for this game for mainly two reasons I think. First it looks stunning when completed. There is something satisfying building the landscape in the game and is something completely different from more traditional games. Secondly, the rules are quite simple, where you pick a tile, place it and if you want to place a follower on the tile.

Many expansions are available, but I prefer to not play with too many of them for the reason that it takes an elegant game and bloat it. I much like the simplicity of the main game.

I usually play this as a two player game with my girlfriend and it works great. You can choose to either build your own stuff or try to sabotage (something I rarely do however). It also works great with three or four players. With more players the game tends to be more chaotic and more competition and helping to completing large areas. I don’t recommend playing the game with five players, since I found it to be too chaotic.

[b]Last updated:[/b] October 2010

RATING: 8
Excelente juego, yo en un principio pensé que era sólo azar el juego, pero la colocación de las losetas es sumamente importante, al igual que ver en qué parte de la loseta uno coloca el meeple, además acá en Chile es uno de los 2 juegos que tiene campeonato nacional y el nivel es muy competitivo.
En cuanto a la cantidad de personas me entretiene más jugarlo de a 2 o 3, ya que uno coloca más losetas y el bloquear lugares del oponente se hace más importante que cuando se juega de 4 o 5, ya que uno tiene que colocar menos losetas y no siempre se puede dar ese lujo.
Recomiendo sí o sí tener este juego en cualquier colección, es fácil de jugar y no dura mucho.

RATING: 10
Played 10+ Scoring is contrived and the Meeple placement is often fiddly. I enjoy this game now I am familiar with the mechanics. How well you do is more influenced by your own play than the actions of the other players. A novice or even an intermediary player can be left feeling like a spectator when playing with experts, this is not a criticism, it is a joy to watch the pros at work, locking your meeples into unfinishable cities and worming into lucrative farms. I prefer Hunters & Gatherers but hats off to the original. *UPDATE* I am playing this game a lot at the moment with my gamer friends. The clean graphics and a better knowledge of the tile set have increased my rating. Sept 05

50th Face to face game and time to reflect on my rating. One of the first games I came across when I got into the hobby and I'm still playing it and enjoying it 13 years later. This has to rise to a 10. Aug 2015

RATING: 8
Very, very well constructed game. Other games may grab my attention more often, but I think this one will have a staying power matched by few. I really don't understand what others see as being so boring about it. A forgiving learning curve, elegant and deep game play, and a relatively short playtime make this an all-time classic. While I don't doubt some of the expansions are quite good, I really don't see them as being necessary. That said, the farmer scoring can be a little wonky, and Hunters and Gatherers is my preferred option, but the original is still one outstanding game.

RATING: N/A
LIBRARY
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
My first Euro.  Ironically, despite the seemingly benign geographic theme, this is one of the most cutthroat games that we have.  Stealing control of farms, making cities more difficult to complete, piggybacking on opponent's cities are all great ways of saying "take that."  

Downgraded my rating from 7 because I'd much rather play some of my higher rated games.

My 21 month old daughter loves to "play" this.  She asks for "Cahcahsonne" very frequently.  Typical turn consists of me asking her whose turn it is, then that person picking up one tile ("Just one tile, ok?").  If it's me, I play it somewhere.  If it's her, I give her a suggestion.  If it's Pooh Bear (a frequent Carcassonne partner around here), see previous.  She doesn't quite understand that tiles need to match on all side.  Game is over when she loses interest and stomps on the pieces (we play on the floor).  That's another positive...pieces are durable and setup/cleanup is quick!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
BR2 R3 R4 R5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun, light, easy to play but hard to win. I own the Big Box which came with Inns and Cathedrals, Traders and Builders, and some mini expansions, as well as Princess and the Dragon and the Tower. The game plays great without any expansions, and can change significantly depending on which ones get added in. I would advise against playing Princess and the Dragon and Tower in the same game; they greatly decrease scoring chances for everyone.

"Wanna play Carcassonne?"

RATING: 8

One of my favorite things about it is the absurdity that it creates.  You finally look at this medieval landscape and you see roads that just lead you in circles, cities that are the most strange creations, and 5 monasteries all side by side.  It's hilarious, but it lends itself to a strangely beautiful picture and I love it.

RATING: 10
The game that got this hobby started for me (bonus points!!). It led me to check out a nearby game group and discover many more great games. Carcassonne however, to me, is still as brilliant a game as ever...

It has simple, easy to grasp rules and scoring that are very intuitive. It has a quick set-up of really only two components: the board tiles and the meeples. Or, really, setting-up is the game.  

Note: Also taken into account are the expansions Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders, brilliant additions to a brialliant game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
カルカソンヌ
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excellent light tile-laying game.  Probably a better "gateway" game than Settlers of Catan since it plays great for two players and does not require bartering/negotiation.  

Not too complex in terms of strategy or analysis.  The land/tile placement and resulting player interaction are big draws.  Balance and luck quibbles is problematic only to more hardcore gamers.  

If you want to tweak this game for more complexity then buy some other expansions.  But know that with each one it bogs down slightly, and increases the fiddliness.  

Better yet, buy the stand-alone Hunters and Gatherers version of this game, which is deeper, more balanced, and more for a seasoned "gamer." 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Pretty good game and fun for families.  The ideas are fun and the design is nice.  The only complaint I have for this one is although there is it can be a little heavy on luck.  I believe the better play will win most games as there is strategy and luck evens out, BUT the church tiles (not sure if that is the proper name but its what we call em, the ones that get points for each neighbor tiles) are disproportionately powerful.  Say in a three person game one person gets 3 one 2 and one 1.  The person with 1 surely will have a hard time to win versus the player with 3 if both are equivalent skill.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An excellent game, at least for two players. Everyone loves the building aspects of the game and they hardly notice the genius inherent in the mechanics, which is genius in and of itself. Anyone who has played dominoes can learn how to play, but better, more experienced players always have an edge. I really like this one in two player because you don't have to worry about two other people sharing large cities or something, but even with 5 (or 6 with expansions) the strategies are very similar. Farming very often wins games, but the more you farm, the more you limit your options since you never get farmers back until the end of the game. And a single enormous completed city can net you many more points than one or even two farmers. Farming, unfortunately, is a bit too complicated and not visually intuitive, not to mention the 3 different sets of scoring rules based on the edition of the game. Lately, I have been less and less interested in playing this one though. It seems to really only shine in two-player as the more people you add, the more chaotic it gets. And there are just mechanics I like better than tile-laying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very enjoyable, simple game.  I get turned off by the sudden scoring swings that can occur when someone draws the perfect tile...  it makes the game *seem* more luck-based than perhaps it is.*** Updated (2008-05-28) - After playing a few hundred ranked games on XBox Live Arcade, I don't think I can fairly rate this anything lower than a 10, which is a significant jump from the 7 I had previously rated it.  There is a fair amount of strategic and tactical depth here that may not be apparent until you've played it several dozen times against some very good players.  I can't stress enough that this is my rating FOR 2 PLAYERS ONLY.  With three or more players my rating is significantly lower, starting at about a 7 and sliding downward as more players are added.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
Carcassonne was my first Euro (after Settlers), and it got played many times. Played nice, played mean. With 2, with 3, with 4, with 5 and 6 even. Always well enjoyed game by those participating. I eventually traded it away after it sitting in my collection unplayed for a a few years.

While it doesn't provide the type of depth that I usually look for in a game, the rule-to-depth ratio is generally nice (once everyone 'gets' the farming rules). It's fun, it's fast - and an aesthetically pleasant experience. Of all the Carcassonne versions that I have played so far, it has my favorite aesthetics for the tiles (with the City having my favorite overall aesthetics).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is one of the most balanced games I've ever played. By balanced I mean that it meets a lot of the criteria for being;

A. FUN!
B. Playable in a reasonable amount of time (if anything, a bit too short)
C. Playable from 2-5 without any major penalites
D. Highly variable between games
E. Easy rules but with ample room for strategies
F. Overall good balance between strategy and the luck factor. I say this because some have knocked it because of the luck of the tile draw, however, I feel if you don't limit yourself by focusing on completing one segment, or using one type of strategy, you can offset bad tile draw.

RATING: 10
One of, if not, my favorite game of all time.  This is the game that brought me back to board gaming and I will play this anytime I get the chance.

It is a simple game with a brilliant set of mechanics.  Anyone can pick this game up and have fun.  Some of the best games are those amongst new players (with an experienced player to guide the action).

Add in the dozens of expansions which all are compatible with the base game and this is just a masterpiece in my book.  I fully plan to play Carcassonne and it's expansions until the day I die.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne is a simple tile placing game to learn, but has some decent strategic depth at the same time (think Chess in this regard).  While there is certainly some luck involved regarding the tile you draw, it really comes down to what you *do* with that tile and how you use your followers that makes the difference.

Now that I have many of the expansions, I could never return to play this by itself, but at the same time, I do remember initially enjoying the game when we were first playing this by itself.

Note:  My wife normally plays all games with my son and I, but she was not into this one.  In fairness to the game, she did not give it a fair shake, as she only played one game (and we were learning as we went).  Still, this was one game that was not her cup of tea.  Therefore, I have only played this as a 2-player game, and very much enjoy it as 2-player (although I would think adding another player or two would make it that much more interesting).

In any case, overall, it is a game enjoyed by my son and I, but we now have included many of the expansions.

Super simple, super easy, nice artwork. I always like area control. Not too many decisions to overwhelm you & it even has a tad of theming.

I'd recommend to play with the rule that players can look at their next tile as soon as they placed theirs. That way downtime is reduced greatly.

RATING: 9
This game gets into the table quite often as a warmup or last game of the day. I like the mechanics as we are building the map and putting down some meeples on it. It can be very competitive towards the game end when we are fighting for fields. It can be played in a really aggressive manner where you are just like a parasite goes into the castles every time, that i love to do so.

Pros / Cons:
-Always different, it has huge replayability.
-Very good warm up game.
-Modified rules made the luck less important.
-It can be played around 30-45 minutes, good to play with 3-5 players.
-Price / Value is really great, it is hard to get bored with it.

-Without the modified rules the luck just kills the fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
1-3-09
Lowered from a 7 to a 5.  This change is mostly in light of finding Drakon.  Drakon has a similar feel - laying down tiles to make a modular board and using your player (meeple) to get coins (VPs) from said tiles.  Yes, this is only a fundamental similarity but it's a very strong one in my mind.  Drakon also lacks the stupid amount of randomness that Carcassone has - draw one tile and play it makes it difficult to formulate any plan.  Drakon's hands of 4 tiles that can do a variety of different things gives you a lot of room for planning/scheming.  I also hate the strategy of 'backdoor farming'.

Basically I suppose if I were offered the choice between Carcassone and Drakon, I'd pick Drakon hands down, every single time.  Also when talking gateway-level games, Ticket to Ride and Pandemic are far superior, really giving this game no place of particular interest for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This could be a truly great game, but it's almost totally ruined by the stupid Farmer scoring. I started with 1st ed. scoring rules in the RGG big box, which seemed unintuitive and easy to screw up. Knowing that I must be doing something wrong, I checked out BGG. I found that the farmer scoring in the US version of this game uses a methodology long discredited on the continent. So I moved on to 3rd ed. shortly thereafter. Although different, the kludgey farmer scoring is still counter-intuitive, easy to screw up, and very difficult to explain to casual gamers.

At first I rated this a "9", but it has steadily fallen each time I find myself muttering, "frakkin' farmers!"

traded July 2009

RATING: 8
This beautiful little game ends up with a pleasing map at the end of the game.  It is a great family game for all ages, and can be simplified for younger members (by leaving out the farmer).  

It is more an activity to have with conversation than a serious game. The expansions add a little more strategy, but the game still revolves around significant luck.  While I play it a lot, it is not a game I suggest when I am with serious gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
“If you build it, he will come.” - Shoeless Joe Jackson

GAMEPLAY
Player take turns laying connecting city, road and abbey tiles to build the city of Carcassonne. A player turn consists of laying a tile and deciding wether to place a meeple. As the city grows, the meeples claim cities(as knights), roads(as thieves), cloisters (as friars), and farms(as farmers). Completing each will give points during the game and return the meeple to the player’s hand. Unfinished areas are scored at the end of the game. Points are totaled and a winner declared.
COMPONENTS
The whole game consists of 72 tiles, 40 meeples, and the scoring track. All of the pieces are of high quality. The tiles are thick and hard which is important because they are handled so much. The meeples are painted wood and feel good in your hand.
THEME
Carcasonne is one of the important games of modern board gaming. Meeples have become an icon of gaming. The meeples and the art style work well together but this game could be re-themed to suit many eras.
WHO IS IT FOR?
This is a great game for families and is familiar to so many that its a good way to start your gaming session. Because there is little to keep track of, its fun for younger players from 8 and up. Games last from 30 to 45 minutes.

There is a wonderfully implemented ios version of Carcassone. Play locally or online. Also there is a solos version of the game with a set stack of tiles. Scores are based on how few tiles necessary to complete cities and roads.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The tile classic, with easy rules!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2 x (one from big box)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
this game is better than I first thought. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
One of my first Euro games. Too simple for my tastes. Couldn't convince my newbie friends either. Got them hooked with Power Grid and Puerto Rico instead. Probably time to find a new home for this copy...

Update (08/17/10): Found a gamer with 8 to 10 year old kids who LOVE this game. Glad it finally found a home to future gamers, where it will be loved.

Update (01/20/12): I'm never going to play this ever again. It may be an important and significant design, but I just don't care. There are much better gateway games than this, IMHO. Dropping it to a '2' from a '5'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne is a good addition to any board game collection because it's easy to learn, quick to play, and can be played with only two players. It fills a nice niche as something you can play on a whim when you've got some time to kill.

Unfortunately, I don't find the game itself to be that wonderful. The game is a mix of luck and strategy, but I find it's too far on the luck side. I also find that the game has balancing issues. I've played over ten times now and I still don't see any compelling reason to play robbers as a significant part of your strategy. The lack of penalty for not completing a road or cloister doesn't help the balancing issue in my opinion. 

I think the funnest part of the game for me is the cat-and-mouse game of trying to secure farm lands, but it's a strategy that more often than not does not pay off (even if you manage to secure them), so it's hard to justify engaging in it.

All in all the fact that the game fills a nice niche means that I'm rating it higher than I would just for the gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]tl;dr[/b] — Potentially light and mild, it's a great social game when played in 30ish minutes, but sags if it goes longer.  Expansions are the seasoning and so should be used sparingly to create the game that suits your current mood.  Terribly cruel when played to win, though.

[microbadge=10153]

Neat for what it is, a kids' game that can be played for blood (farm wars, anyone?).  The vanilla version is a pleasant-enough pastime.  Where [i]Carc[/i] really shines, though, is as a game system—the mix 'n match expansions allow you to complicate or flavor the game as you will.

UPDATE:  Revising down from a 7 to a 6.  This was shockingly novel at first, being only the second Eurogame I'd ever seen, but now...  And another thing:  The 8,000,000,000 different farm-scoring schema make for bizarre parallel-dimension gaming where some people at the table have evil goatees and some don't, leading to the disastrous overlay of competing realities, some where farmers lie on their backs and gaze at duck-shaped clouds scudding by and others where you can only get promoted by stabbing your boss in the neck.*

[size=7]*So, 12 years later, it looks like this has settled down—the standard seems to be German 3rd Edition rules with "farm-centric" scoring of cities for three points each.  I like the simplification—as well as the change making the tiny two-bit mini-cities worth four points instead of two, eliminating a rules exception, always a good thing.[/size]

UP-UPDATE:  This is the game that made me realize that most expansions are crap—they just add plaque that calcifies a decent game into an immobile, spiky mess.  (Or, to go to the other extreme, bloats it out so it can't even wear pants anymore.)   Expansions, in general, are a terrible idea unless:

a) It was a part of the original game (as designed) that got peeled off to make the base game simpler/cheaper,

b) Actually adds an element that enhances repeat plays, or

c) Fixes one or more broken elements that really shoulda been caught during playtesting.

Only three expansions for [i]Carc[/i] fit any of that—[thing=2591]The River[/thing], [thing=2993]Inns & Cathedrals[/thing] and [thing=5405]Traders & Builders[/thing].  Everything else is dessicated mummy-crap.

UP-UP-UPDATE:  Resurrecting this as a mild social activity; as a [i]game[/i] game it gets a 5, when consumed as a small bowl of whipped cream it's a 6.  The deal with the expansions is to understand that every tile added into the mix is another turn—and if you've got multiple axes to consider (with several expansions at once) then those turns can become very long indeed.  The game works best when it comes in well under an hour; it [i]wants[/i] to be short.**  I can honestly only see using one expansion at a time...

[size=7]**The closer to 30 minutes the better.[/size]

I forgot what an awful little game this can be:  so much grief, so many ambitious building projects that will never be completed, so many farmers stabbing each other in the tummy with pitchforks from the backs of rage-donkeys.

I'm not sure how the rest of world plays this, but man, we are just plain [i]mean[/i] to each other.

[i]Me likey.[/i]

UP-UP-UP-UPDATE:  Back up to a 7 where I expect it to stay.  When grokked and played accordingly—as a shortish social activity with one big and maaaybe one small expansion at a time it's a pip.

[b]CODA:  GROINS IMPLY BOOTS[/b]

The sheer ruthlessness required to play the game competitively is entirely at odds with the presentation:  cutesy li'l squares of bucolic cartoons, and the meeples themselves, adorable and nonthreatening, the very symbols of "points without pain" Eurogaming.  If the package reflected the truth of it the art would be dark and violent:  fields strewn with fresh grave-mounds, dangerous roads to nowhere festering with spleen-stabbing thieves, sprawling slums with gaping holes in the walls patrolled by gangs of baby-stomping kingsmen.

This is what you must do to win:  sucker your opponents into fights that you either dominate or walk away from (leaving them overextended), place tiles to ensure their followers are trapped in projects that will never be completed, and never share points unless you are so far ahead it doesn't matter... and even then, hook yourself in for +1 at the last minute to steal the "joint effort" for yourself.

You must crush dreams, snap their bones and suck the marrow.  You must be prepared to engineer fallen crests and hopelessness.  I'll be honest:  I felt like a complete jerk at first, as playing to win in [i]Carc[/i] is really about [i]making everyone else lose[/i], and the constant pooping in the punchbowl can suck the fun right out of the party.  But if you wish to do your best then that tile [i]must[/i] be placed where it maximizes both personal gain [i]and[/i] does the most harm to your opponents.

In the end the countryside puzzle we are constructing is a façade that does nothing to conceal the suffering of the nameless, numberless peasants who are too small to see from our lofty perches of intrigue.

[i]Carcassonne[/i] is an assassin in clown paint.

Rating bumped up to an 8.

PS.  A Geeklist that gathers all my [i]Carc[/i]omments into a single, writhing mass:

[b][geeklist=171161][/geeklist][/b]

And finally, I know what this next bit should be called, but can't bring myself to admit it without gagging:

[b][blogpost=28523][/blogpost][/b]

PPS.  DO NOT CLICK IT FOR YOU WILL NEVER FORGET IT

[o]"Meeple" sounds just like "meat-pole".[/o]

RATING: 8
This is really a great game.  It plays well with two and up to six (although it is a very different game at those two extremes).  You can play it conflict free or somewhat nastily (although you are never going to be able to wipe someone else out like some people want from a game).

It's a great game for playing with board game neophytes or with kids.

RATING: 7

So, what did I miss eventually? A damn fine little game. Carcassonne bounced right up to the top of my favorite games -list and I am so anxious to play it again... and again... and again.

개인적으로 가장 좋아하는 확장판은 "공주와 용" 이며, 
가장 좋아하는 외전은 "더 캐슬" (라이너 크니지아) / "뉴 랜드" (레오 콜로비니) 이다.

RATING: 9
Carcassonne is a great game.  It is the game that got me into playing games again.  I'm so glad the store owner recommended this one.  My 12 year old son especially loves this game.  It is a fantastic gateway game.  The tile laying is so unique, interesting, and fun.  It's kind of like a puzzle.  There are also plenty of opportunities to be "mean" in this game, stealing other players' cities.  Carcassonne plays best with two people.  The expansions make the game even better.  I would give it a 10, but I have grown tired of it.  I've played at least 20 or more games (before I started logging games played).

RATING: 7
This game is the reason I am back into board games.  While my GF (now wife) and I were traveling in Wales, we stopped by a game store to see if there was something we could play at night in the youth hostel we were staying at.  The store owner suggested Carcassonne and what a great suggestion it was.  We played it a lot for a couple of years until we started playing other games.  We don't play it very much at all any more, but I think we both would play it if asked.  I think I also killed it when for Christmas, I bought 4 different expansions all at once.  Now, when we do play, we generally only use one or two of them.

I prefer to reduce the farm scoring just because that to me is where analysis/paralysis comes into play.  It can get downright nasty and dreadful trying to work out the best way to take over the fields.  When introducing it to new players, I don't even do the farm scoring at all in the first game.

RATING: 8
Will play this anytime. Love the mechanics. This game started out in my gaming group as a friendly social game. No one played to hinder anyone else. If one person was in a city already, we tended to stay out. Then one day we saw one of our group play some meeples in some extremly hostile ways towards other people trying to gain points. When he won, everyone's eyes were opened and the game is now one of the most cut-throat games we play. It is in my opinion that most people who dislike this game or think that it is just ok, are still playing this way to friendly. Hunters and Gatherers is much tighter though, and makes it a better game than the original.

RATING: N/A
We play Carcassonne at lunch time when running our school holiday program, Kraftworks for Kids. The program is for kids aged 9 - 14. The kids really enjoy this game. We pair up the beginners with one of the Leaders while those who have played a few games are able to play without assistance. Sometimes we don't finish the game by the end of lunch but it can easily be resumed at the end of the day while waiting for parents to arrive. Sometimes we use the expansions but this tends to make the game go longer. Lots of fun -- probably our favourite game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
Easy to learn - more strategy than initially appears
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't know why, but I always find this game incredibly relaxing for some reason. As with all games based on a blind draw, you're restricted to using judgement to determine the best play. It helps to be thoroughly familiar with the tiles and winning a valuable feature is all about combining nearby tiles such that your men form the majority. Be sure to use the 3rd Edition rules as these balance the farmer scoring much better. In all, a pleasant light game that's undemanding enough to appeal to just about anyone. 
Be warned though, Carcassonne has been much diminished by over-expansion. One large or a couple of the smaller expansions are all that you need, anything more and what should be a pleasantly light diversion turns into an analysis-paralysis monster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A good gateway game, but quickly overstays its welcome.  Definitely a classic, just not one I would pick to play very often.

RATING: 7
Okay, new review time - old one below for posterity.

Yes, this game is okay for introducing new people to games, particularly if they are older. But the Farm scoring is a real issue in my mind, and these days I think the mass expansion sprawl probably makes it too long for the strategic depth it offers.

Iconic, but just buy a box then move on.
_____

The definitive game to introduce people to modern board games; it's a pity that the scoring is a little complex. It's actually great game with the dozen or so expansions thrown in, if you can sit through the time it takes to play that long.

My main gripe is that the 2nd edition farm scoring is a lot more balanced than the 3rd, but a fair bit more complex.

RATING: 9
I've only played this game once, but I completely understand the hype. The game is very simple -- flip a tile to create the board, place your Meeple on an incomplete road or fort, and claim your points. I usually like heavy, complex games, but this game was refreshingly simple but with enough strategy to keep the game on its toes. Will likely buy soon!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2/10/09
-------------------------------

[i]Carcassonne[/i] is a tile-laying game that plays in 45 minutes and is very easy to understand. You place a tile, and then you place a ‘follower’ on a feature on the tile, with the aim of ‘completing’ features to get points. The game plays 2-5 people, and is probably better with fewer players; achieving the best results at the minimum of 2. As you add more players, the ratio of decisions to time decreases dramatically, and can become quite boring, as this a game that can be prone to analysis paralysis.

I wouldn’t call this game for everyone, as it can wear out rather quickly I find. Even though the large amount of tiles and combinations seem exhaustive at first, the games seem to repeat themselves rather often, and by that I mean that they seem the same, even though they are not. This is due to the lack of interesting decisions in the game it around the 10-20 plays mark. Even the limited player conflict cannot prevent this from occurring. The one exception to this is the two player game, which I find to be rather tense under the circumstances; however it also feels rather repetitive.

The actual gameplay itself is dictated by luck, but sufficient contingency planning should be able to eliminate this, but it is still not uncommon for an experienced player to lose to a newer one on luck alone. For the first couple of plays, it may seem like there is little interaction, but many people discover the method of interfering with other people’s plans fairly soon. Towards the end of the game, the completion of your features and the placing of your farms gives the game a nice tense atmosphere, but as noted above, this does not remain for too many plays.

To conclude, [i]Carcassonne[/i] is a fun game for the first few times you play it, and is good for introducing new people to the world of gaming, but I would not dwell on it too long, at least, not without the expansions. Also, try to stay away from games with more than four players, as they can get boring very quickly unless someone is marching the game through at breakneck pace.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Simple to teach and learn
- Good gateway game
- Equal opportunity to win
- Plenty of expandability

[b]Cons[/b]
- Lacking in continued playability
- Analysis paralysis prone 
- Decisions lose interest after a while
- Games feel the same quite often
- Lack of accommodation for large numbers of players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I have the Big Box - comes with numerous expansions: Abbey & Mayor, Inns & Cathedrals, King & Scout, The Count, The Cult, Princess & the Dragon, The River II, Traders & Builders.  Figured it better to write them here than include ALL of the entries and clutter the list.

Really enjoy this game.  First game that hooked me into boardgames again (damn you, Tyler).  Consequently, I've used it to hook many others into a regular game and have probably helped put Klaus-Jürgen Wrede grandchildren through University as other friends have bought Carcassone, too.

My rating reflects how easy it is to teach & the appeal to a wide variety of players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I struggle to rate this higher since it has such a niche place in my collection. I've almost exclusively played it two player, and almost every play has been with my wife. I truly enjoy our games together as much as almost any other game experience I have, but I don't know how much of that is the game.

Carcassonne is beautiful, and it's a delightful experience to see the board slowly come together over the course of a match. The expansions are a lot of fun, and add some interesting wrinkles to the base game strategy.

Carcassonne can be annoyingly cutthroat. Optimal play can seem pretty brutal at times, and someone stealing a castle you worked on for many turns can feel pretty crappy. There is also a potential for large blowouts in cases of dissimilar skill. Thankfully not an issue I have much anymore, since my wife has learned the game well enough to routinely thump me.

All in all, I really enjoy Carcassonne, but I have such a narrow use for it that I'm not sure it deserves a higher grade. In the specific situation of two player games, with my wife, it's an 8 or a 9, but outside of that, I can't see it reaching that high.

No sleeves required.

RATING: 9

My friends have all sworn off of buying the thing (despite their rabid desire to play, and frequently!) and are each waiting semi-patiently for their hand-painted copy.  I'm sorry photos don't seem to be up yet, and that I'm neither a competent photographer nor much of a painter--but it didn't stop us from loving the homemade version of this game!  (Which, if you didn't know, is one of the best board games I know, ceramic or cardboard!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love the game.  A cornerstone piece of the game collection.

Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, and the River (or River II) are our preferred expansions.  I'm also quite partial to the Die Katharer expansion as well.

The Count expansion was OK, but added some confusion.  The "city" tiles from the Count expansion do make for a nice alternate starting set-up.  The King/Robber expansion scoring rules seemed superfluous, although we often use the tiles without the added rules.

Added note:  As much as I like this game, when you play with a full boat of people (i.e., 5 or 6 people) who all know how to play, it's more of an activity than a competitive endeavor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game was one of my first purchases when I started collecting modern board games. I initially got it because my spouse has an interest in patterns and puzzles so this was an easy favorite for her. It's also been a game that I'm proud to show off. It's been my go to "gateway" game and I've even encouraged friends to get it. That being said, I find this game fun but it does not have enough confrontation nor player interaction for me. There is a passive aggressive side of the game where one player can block another player's feature or extend it without hope of finishing to score but I think games play better when everyone works on their own little corners. Also, with expansions come new features or rules which is nice, but it causes a lot of bloat to the game and increases play time. A good game but definitely not great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Diverse with lots (8) of expansions and scenario's.

RATING: 9
This is the ideal game--if you only have two people, it&#039;s great, but it&#039;s probably best with three, and can play up to 5.  There&#039;s VERY LITTLE setup time involved, small amount of take-down, and requires a good amount of strategy with some luck.  It&#039;s fairly easy to learn, but a little bit tougher to learn the best strategy.  It&#039;s also quite affordable--I picked it up at a local game store for about $20.  I HIGHLY recommend this title.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the only game I've seen which focuses only on topology. It has simple rules, big amount of randomness, but still very little luck involved. Beginner will almost certainly loose to experienced player, especially in 2-players game, which is my favorite setup. Mastering of strategy takes time and it is not simple game at all. Actually, it is very hard game with very simple rules. From my point of view, this is the best game ever, and everybody should give it a shot. I am not expert in pedagogy, but I would guess that Carcassonne will boost kid's logical and spatial skills.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is an easy game to play with all of the kids, but we don't play it as much as we use to. I guess its replay value is not too high after so many years. The smaller children, who may not earn the points to win, have fun putting the pieces on the board. It definitively feels like the luck of the tile is more important then any tactics. Overall, I'd rather play something else. Infact- I have tossed out all of the expansion tiles and only have the base game and 2 of the expansions now. A Nice game to take to GMA's house for the evening without worring about a child breaking it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Highly recommended game and very fun. It's what got me going down the road of board gaming even further.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very nice game, I enjoy playing it with family and friends from all ages (10 up, of course).
Easy to explain to new players if you don't add in too many extensions (although I always add the Inns & Cathedrals + Traders & Builders).  The tougher rule to explain might be the farmers, as I find quite some people who would rather skip that rule, I think the different crossings, bridges, small gaps, etc. Make it difficult for new players to really get it the first few times.

If you feel like a long game, have many extensions, and don't want to explain too much you can always skip any 'non standard' rules that are added by the extensions (I.E. Ignore the tower bases, vulkans, etc). That way you might cover your whole table with carcassonne tiles! :D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love this game.  It's fast moving, simple in its concept yet very strategic, and doesn't take too long.

I bought it when my daughters were 5 and 7.  They both understood the basics of the game, so I was able to play with them but they didn't understand the strategy (understandably).  My 5 year old (now 7) didn't like it after the novelty wore off.  My 7 year old (now 9) still likes it. My wife doesn't like this game because of the "screwage" factor, but enjoys it if I promise to play nicely.

Some notes:
~ The water expansion that came with my version is pretty good
~ The Farms element of the game is something I haven't introduced to my kids...it's a bit too advanced for them I think.  The game plays fine without playing Farms.
~ The quality of the tiles is fantastic, have held up 100% after about 20 plays
~ I like it best with 2 players.

RATING: N/A
Carcassonne (Old edition).

Note: I own a second copy of 'Carcassonne: The Phantom' with 'Meeple Stickers' by which the phantoms can serve as abbots as in the new edition of Carcassonne. The faire tiles of 'Carcassonne: The Catapult' can additionally serve as garden tiles (as in the new edition), even though there are three more faire tiles than garden tiles.

For other information on playing Carcassone with and without expansions, I have made a short overview (in Dutch) by which the party has to decide what rules apply, and I have saved two pages of 'Carcassonne - Complete Annotated Rules (Version 4.0):

- Page 45: Summary of Rule Sets & Changes

- Page 47: Overview (Order of Play/Game Figures)

RATING: 5
This is one of the newer most hyped games I have tried that fell completely flat. No strategy due to one tile at a time and very little tactical choices and did not find it fun at all. 

Very dry and boring, strictly tile-laying. Still would get played over some other low-level games but it won't be suggested. Reminds me of "waterworks" from what I remember only I think I enjoyed that more, at least you could throw a wrench in the guy's plumbing...

To be fair I'm sure this is somewhat better with the expansions and maybe a house rule letting you hold 2 or 3 tiles and maybe even picking from an open pool like El Cab but El Cab is far better (although EC is NOT a gateway game so they are pretty different in that respect).

I'm waiting to try "The City" or "The Castle" which looks better and more involved as straight tile-laying doesn't excite me a whole bunch (at least in this form where as in T&E it is masterfully beautiful). 

I can see why people like it for its simplicity and as a Gateway, for me a little too simple but with some tweaks it would be another good gateway tool.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The tile laying mechanic is ingenious.  The jigsaw puzzle-like board is assembled as the game is played (it's different every time).  Watching the medieval city unfold--in sometimes very strange ways--is fun and a distinctive part of the experience.  But there is a good game here, too.  Despite the placid theme, play can get quite chippy: you are frequently better off trying to foil or rob an opponent than enhancing your own holdings.  The luck factor is on the high side and increases with the number of players.  Except for the farms (which often cause problems for newbies) the rules and scoring are straightforward.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Original. Very clean and elegant tile laying game from Hans im Glueck. The city of Carcassone is constructed by simply drawing a tile and positioning it on the ever increasing game "board". Players score points by playing their coloured pieces onto the played tile as a knight (in cities), farmers (on the green stuff), robbers (on roads) and clergyman (on monasteries). Points are maximised by enlarging the sphere of your piece. Timing is everything, as you only get your pieces back when you complete a sphere. Excellent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic euro game - lots of strategy. replayable. The theme is very Euro - no zombies, or aliens or movie tie-ins! If you like a sedate euro-type game then this is very easy to learn but hard to master. Also good app version available for solo play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my favorites.  This game is light and fun.  Its always quick to learn and new players often enjoy it.  

I've played this game so many times..that I have forgotten to record all plays...I'm not actually sure how many games I've played...

Update: Bought the Big Box version - which included all 5 expansions.  It was $35 at essex.
