RATING: 8
I'm a sucker for Carcassonne, but I usualy need at least the Inns & Cathedrals and/or Traders & Builders (preferably both) expansions in order to make the original game interesting enough to play these days. And the third edition German scoring rules are necessary to balance things out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In Carcassone, you take turns drawing tiles that you then place on the board to build up a map with roads and cities and so forth.  After you place a tile, you can decide whether to place one of your limited supply of men on it to score some points.  It's a challenging game that requires little advance planning and is pretty quick.  It makes for a nice filler game.  I don't seek it out but I enjoy it when I play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic!  Fun!  Simple!  Your mom might actually play this one with you!  Your non-geek friends might LIKE it.  A great game to show newbs the fun of games and remind vets why they play them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Most games start with high ratings from me, and decrease a point or so over time.  (Naturally - I'm always willing to play my newer games, and will usually suggest them, etc.)  This one, however, has creeped up slowly over time.  My first couple plays I was wholly unimpressed.  But the more I played it, the more I enjoyed the simple, clear-cut strategic decisions.  It might not be a brain-burner, but if I'm in the mood for something light that can be played in 15 minutes, this is probably what's going to hit the table (or floor, as the case may be.)

Update: back down to a 7.  Just not hitting the table much anymore . . .
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A really easy game to learn. Strategy is obvious in the base game and I prefer higher strategy games. Hence I bought a number of the expansions. 

If you like strategy I would advise to buy at least the biggest expansions - Inns and Cathedrals as well as Traders and Builders.

The flip side is that if you have friends that do not like strategy games this is a good intro game to see if you can hook them in....

RATING: 2.5
2012-04-12

Initial Rating: 5.0 (July 2010)

It is a simple game, easy to teach and very good to attract non gamers to our beloved hobby, HOWEVER I don’t know why but I feel a deep hate for the game, I HATE IT I HATE IT I HATE IT. There is no chemistry between us.

I know I´m being irrational but I have no desire to play this whatsoever. It is the only game I have vetoed in our game sessions and thus far I have not met other people who doesn’t like the game, guess I´m kind of alone on this one.

I feel the game is so boring (no theme at all) and it has annoyingly high luck. I KNOW there are a lot of variants and expansions that fix this but I will offer my utmost resistance against playing this again.

Current Rating: 2.5

I have at least 5 plays before 2010 thus I have not logged them.

RATING: 8
Fun game with easy rules.  Seemingly endless expansions keep Carcassonne fresh.

Update: So, I have pretty much all the expansions I'll get.  Carcassonne, while a good game in its own right, can bog down when expansions add tedium.  Carcassonne's strength was it's accessibility-newcomers could join and do pretty well.  But if you add Cult, Seige, Creativity, the King and Scout, the Count, the River I, the River II, Traders and Builders and Inns and Cathedrals . . . well, it gets to be too much.

That criticism aside; I still like Carcassonne.  I don't play it as much as I should.

RATING: 7.5
The game that got us into modern boardgaming. Classic, easy, fairly quick, but with tons of depth and replay-ability. The rules are clear and easy to understand (with the exception of farmers, those can be hard for people to grasp the complexities of), and the turns go quick so the play is fast and engaging. I grab it if an inexperience gamer is coming, if we want something to play while watching a movie or cooking dinner, or if we just want to play the old standby that everyone knows. 

My copy is super worn out, and I will definitely buy another copy when necessary.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The grandaddy of all tile placing games, it's survived for a reason: it's easy to learn, no two games are the same, and you can teach it easily to people of all ages. Simply draw a tile, place it where available, and choose whether to try and get points from it using your limited supply of meeples. Fun for the whole family!

BIG PLUS: relatively inexpensive for the amount of fun you get out of the box
BIGGER PLUS: big box editions contain mixtures of the expansions, many of which are worth playing
MINUS: eventually your gaming group will get bored with this game and move on.

SUPER PLUS: the iOS version of this game is well worth it as well. :D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Original game concept, I think this game deserves the attention that it gets.  There is a large luck component, but there is enough skill to keep it interesting.  Good strategic advice in this game cannot be easily communicated, it has more to do with 'feel'.  Two things I don't like about this game are the game length (especially when you add expansions), and the amount of table space required.  I suppose that Arkham Horror, which I rated an 8, suffers from these problems a lot more (even though it has no similarities to Carc.), but unlike AH, Carcassonne doesn't have enough character to make up for its deficiencies.  Still a good game, and great for beginners.

RATING: 7
This is a classic gateway game that has stayed fresh with some good expansions. Though there are many expansions and not all are worth incorporating into the game. Game play can be fairly casual or more cutthroat. We play a blend, block each other and extend cities to be unfinishable without getting worked up about anything. We started playing the variant of having two tiles to choose from and play with one blank tile that can fit anywhere, but has to be played in a completely surrounded hole - a get out of jail free tile. I've never had anyone struggle with the farmer scoring (anymore than anything else), so have never left it out.

RATING: 10
This was my first euro/modern boardgame purchase ever... Fall 2004, I remember well the moment.  I dig the strategy involved, and also the "art" that emerges during gameplay.  I love the process of laying the tiles.  The French medieval theme is perfect for me!  I really like how Carc is so flexible based on who you're playing, and what mood you're in - it works equally well in a cut-throat, strategic battle between two buddy gamers as it does a peaceful meditative session with family or less aggressive friends. It's thanks to this game that I discovered BGG and the wonderful universe of modern boardgames.
Got at Go! The Game Store at Oaks Mall ~Christmas 2004.  My first modern boardgame purchase!

RATING: 7
Prefer The City (Stadt) variant, but otherwise this is a great gateway game, which I would recommend over Settlers.  Player interaction is both competitive and cooperative, a dynamic which very few games can generate.  First-time players area little disadvantaged by not knowing the possible tile draws, but this is overcome in a few plays.  The thinking required is not highly intuitive at first (i.e. you need to master the concept of "getting in on" a feature by playing a meeple to an unconnected tile with the hope to connect later), but most players get there in time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Carcassonnne is a fantastic game and a true classic, but there are many ways to get a bad impression:

- Playing with too few expansions. You need Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders to increase strategic options, balance scoring elements, and reduce luck.

- Playing with too many expansions. The River is the biggest offender as it comes with the game and encourages boring, non-interactive play. It also increases random luck and unduly increases playing time, which is the problem with several other expansions.

- Playing with too many people. It's best with 2 and not very good with 4 or more.

- Playing non-competitively. It's not a jigsaw puzzle. If you're not trying to trap enemy meeples, you won't win against someone who is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
The very first game I bought after discovering the new generation of games.  Have since bought all of the expansions.  an absolutely wonderful game.  Not hard to learn.  Very strategic.  The first game I play with my friends to introduce them to board games.

Edit 12/5/08 - I've upgraded my rating of this game to a 10 after playing it quite a few times in the past couple weeks.  It's been gathering dust in the corner for a while now since I've been eagerly building up the collection and it's been ignored in favour of all the new games.  However, now that I've rediscovered it, I have to say it's a perfect game.  Especially when combined with one or all of the expansions.  We always play with "Inns & Cathedrals" and I would even recommend that "Traders & Builders" be used always as well.  I can't say enough good things about Carc's.  There's ZERO setup, quick game play.  Lots of tension and strategy.  Very easy to teach to new people.  And the more you play, the more cut throat it becomes.  
    The greatest game for so many reasons.  Better than Catan - too much luck, better than RRTycoon - too long to play and too long to setup.  A beauty.  It should be higher ranked on the geek.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Our other go-to gateway game. Rarely gets played when it's a group of 'gamers', as there always seem to be other games which are more attractive at the time. But when put in a social situation with people who haven't played many games beyond Monopoly, it still manages to please. Simple but still strategic in gameplay, scoring somehow manages to bewilder those new to the game; to the point that we essentially ignore the farmers unless we're playing with those who have played the game before.

Despite the fact that we rarely bring it out on its own, the plethora of expansions keep extending Carcassonne's life - breathing fresh air each time. As of this writing, we've only scratched the surface with one expansion. But it's nice to know that as time goes by, we can quickly and easily (and cheaply) keep the Carcassonne love going for a while to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
50+ plays.

At first I was underwhelmed. Time has changed my mind: this game deserves its popularity. Though the luck of the draw can be maddening at times.

RATING: 5
Carcassone is really just Dominoes with pretty scenic tiles instead of numbers, but Carc deceptively has more complicated scoring.

I like Dominoes because it makes no bones about the fact that it is a math game. And I like it because the math is simpler.

I will confess that I just don't like Carc, and might just be looking for reasons to not like it.

RATING: 8
A fun, colorful, thought-provoking-but-not-too-daunting game. It's popular with a few of my workmates, too, which helps.

My interest in Carc has declined somewhat as other games have taken the fore, hence my initial 9 has slid to an 8. Nonetheless, Carc is among my most-played games of "all time" and retains a good deal of its appeal for me. The best way to play, I think, is with both I&C and T&B, although together they extend the game perhaps just a little, time wise, beyond its welcome.

There are 3 games I avoid like the plague - Catan, Puerto Rico and Carcassonne. The pieces are crap, the gameplay stunted and the game objective a joke. I mean, what&#039;s the significance of a place like Carcassonne in human history that they gotta make a game about it? A real waste of time, and completely pointless to boot. Even when you&#039;ve emerged victorious, you don&#039;t feel like you actually did anything to deserve victory. I know the Germans are trying hard to stay away from violent themes in boardgaming, but this is absolutely ridiculous. Watching paint dry might be more fun by comparson.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Carcassonne is one of those games that I'm not quite sure why I love it so much. It's easy to teach, and almost everyone I've played it with loves it. It seems to scratch an OCD itch that I didn't think I had. I've never been into puzzles, but I love laying the tiles, lining them up, and completing features, and a lot of people seem to love that about Carcassonne, as well. I love that you're doing one thing per turn, and there is little down time - these two things are a big reason why this is such a great gaateway game. I actually play it with the most basic rules - we don't even use farmers or abbots most of the time - because I like this game as a relaxing break from more intense, strategy games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite gateway game to teach to those that are uninitiated to modern strategy games. Carcassonne is extremely easy to teach, has very intuitive rules, and can accommodate a large number of players.

It does not have the strategic depth of heavier games, and skilled players will acknowledge that there are only ever two or three "obvious" moves to make on any given turn. However, this works in favor of the game in terms of keeping play fast-paced, and prevents new players from getting overwhelmed. Often, the best of these choices is not itself obvious, anyways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good mix of skill and luck. It should be noted that I have the Big Box, which includes many expansions.

I'm sure it would hold up where in other circumstances, but I'm a bit biased against Euro games since I prefer games with a deeper theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Learning Curve: 9/10

Strategic Balance: 5/10

Player Interaction: 6/10

Thematic Direction: 4/10

Replay Addiction: 7/10

Additional Information
[b]Simple and addictive game [/b]which focuses on fort and road stealing. Very irritating if playing with an experienced player. They know how to screw you up so bad and it feels like you can't do anything about it. It's fun if you can teach your new player the strategy because the game mechanics are simple enough to pick up fast. Hardest concept is the farmers, which makes the game very tricky.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Its a light, fun game which is very replayable. And it can be taught very quickly to new players. Players build cities by placing cleverly designed tiles and attempt to score points for them.

For nostalgic purposes, this is one of the first games I got into, and I think most of friends really enjoyed this one.

RATING: 7.5
Carcassone is another in the category of games with simple rules and a great deal of potential for growth in skill. As far as tile-laying games go, it offers a lot to like. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]Update 11.26.07 :[/b] I raised this game from an 8 to a 9. I still haven't played it with any expansions except River 1 and the Mini-Expansion from one of my gaming mags (which introduced the much needed new river start tile). I have now played it quite a few times with 2, 3 and 4 players. For me I prefer it with 2 or 3 players, although with 4 it still ranks around an 8. Normally I'm not a big fan of luck, but this game shares similar traits with [gameid=24508] which I also enjoy quite a bit too. [b]Original:[/b] I found this game to be pretty fun. You randomly draw a tile (luck) and place it to where it helps you the most (luck again). The luck in the game though is balanced by the strategic placement of your meeples which you can only place on the tile you just placed. Do you hold off or do you place a knight, thief, or bishop to help score some points so you can reuse them later, or invest a few farmers that are stuck in the fields the entire game but might bring home the bacon (and the win) at the end of the game? Easy to learn and teach, the few rules offer quite a bit of depth in terms of game play.

RATING: 10
Fantastic game.  The rules seem quite intimidating/complicated to new users, taking a solid 5 minutes of explaining.  Once they begin to play they're happy to find that the game isn't as complicated as they thought.  Fun for light strategy and thinking.  A big hit with my family (all over 25).  Plays well with all recommended players (2-6), with different experiences for different amounts ie. more heavy thinking with 2-3, a bit more chaos with 4-6.  We're hooked.

RATING: 9
I bought this game because it's often recommended around every board game forum, it's a classic and it's easy enough to learn. I've now played 6 games of it with a range of 2-5 players and I find that the more of it I play the more I want to play. I'm having a blast with it. I took the advice in the rules to not play with farmers, abbott, or rivers to start and we've just introduced the farmer and I feel like this is a great way to do it because it's making the game more strategic as we play more.

I'm looking forward to playing this more and I really wish that I had someone in my house who wanted to play with me steadily instead of waiting for friends! I paid $35 at a local board game shop, but I've seen it for $25 at Target (I think it was Target). It's well worth the money though.

Edit: I am changing my score from 8 to a 9. I really really enjoy this game and the more that I play it the more I want to play it.

RATING: N/A
Favorite of one of my partners, but we play without farmers because she thinks they are too complicated (it does simplify scoring at the end, but it removes the battles for control of the big farms). I really prefer the old graphics, the new ones are overflowing with little blue towers that add nothing and make reading the tiles confusing. If you're going to get lots of expansions (I would not play without at least Inns & Cathedrals) then get yourself the Broken Token organizer, it rocks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the grand daddy of tile laying games.
One of my earlier games that i bought to play with my gf at the time - now she is my wife, dont think because of Carcassone though, but you never know).
It filled the role perfectly. We wanted an easy game, that wasnt overly aggressive or long - Carcassone is all of these (can be longer if you play with more sets) and we both enjoyed the building aspect. Our favourite is, when we have the time, is to play with 2-3 base sets and then when all the tiles are gone, to have a look at the map that we have created. Very cool!
As for the tons of expansions, i only have one of them, and i quite enjoyed how it added a little spice to the game. Having said that, i also tried with another expansion and would consider adding maybe one more expansion to our games - however, i would not want to be playing with more than three expansion at once, as it just convolutes the game and reduces the streamlined, "easy" feeling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This one fell flat with most of my friends and myself. While I see that there is a strategy component behind tile placement. I just don't really enjoy the limited decision making process that seems to take place in this game.

Others may disagree with me, but I feel settlers has more interesting decisions in terms of negotiation, trading, decision to purchase or wait, where to move as well as initial set up (dependent on examining where other players are)

Carcassonne just feels too simple to me. Another factor is probably that there wasn't much verbal interaction based on the game.

RATING: 7
Már nagyon régóta vártam, hogy végre játszhassak ezzel a játékkal. Látva, hogy több, mint 10 éve töretlen a sikere, és hogy folyamatosan jelennek meg hozzá a kiegészítők, nagyok voltak az elvárásaim. Valószínűleg kicsit túl nagyok. Az alapjáték valójában nagyon könnyed, gyors játékmenetű. A szabályok pár perc alatt elsajátíthatók. Először szándékosan mindenféle kiegészítő nélkül játszottuk, és bevallom, nekem kicsit kevésnek tűnt. Hiányoltam a bonyolultabb, fejtörőbb szituációkat. Ez persze betudható annak is, hogy csak ketten játszottuk. Hátha több játékos esetén néhány kiegészítőt is használva összetettebbé válik a játék.

Frissítés: igen, fantasztikus lett a különböző kiegészítőkkel, de az alapjátékot továbbra is kevésnek érzem. Mindenesetre most már szívesen játszom vele. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
Original Carcassonne is easy to play, fun, and features gentle competition.  As you add expansions, the game loses this gentle charm, and players are charged with knowing more and more rules.

As you add expansions you also add time to the game.  This removes Carcassonne from the light family game that plays in 45 minutes and transforms it into a more involved game that takes longer.

I once had a bunch of expansions for this game.  I have trimmed down to the first two major expansions, and the Cathars.  I also kept the tile rack from the Tower, but ditched the rest of that expansion and all others.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun strategy game. Light enough to play with non-gamers but in depth enough to make it fun for more hard core gamers.

RATING: 6.5
Well, the other variants (Hunters & Gatherers, Ark of the Covenant, Neues Land et al) are all much, much better from a standalone game point of view than the basic game.

The blue Carcassonne starts to shine a little brighter with the first expansion, though, and with more expansions piled on it becomes even more of a decent game. Unfortunately each expansion also pushes the game length into the borderzone of tedium.

So, I prefer Hunters & Gatherers as my everyday poison, but basic Carc' is alright every once in a while.

/kgm

RATING: 9
Pretty much the perfect game for introducing people to the hobby. It's so simple to play even my Nana can play it. My Mum's favourite game.

The game also continues to be entertaining against board game enthusiasts and gameplay takes on a whole new level. Everyone is so busy fighting over a huge field and the large cities within that the cities never finish and the farmers score very little. Haha!

I've never met anybody who doesn't enjoy Carcassonne. Not a game I want to play every gaming session, but I can't see it being a game I would ever sell.

RATING: 8
This is a lovely game which combines simple rules, fun tile-laying mechanism and surprisingly deep strategy, especially how you can use your placement to help or hinder other players, and take long-term bets on the development of the map.

There is luck in the draw of the tiles, obviously, which can help balance the game between experts and novices. That said, it doesn't take a long time to play and victory is rarely down to a single lucky tile.

RATING: 6
UPDATE: The game is Funnest with the three tiles variant and Builders and Traders expansion!

Three tiles variant: Always have three tiles on hand during and between turns (Gives it a more strategic feel)

Builders and Traders: BEST expansion to the game, gives incentive to finish other peoples castles!!!! 

(Original Edition) Bought the original loved it so much bought "The Big Box". I leave the original at work. Great game and quick enough to play during lunch break. My family and my wife love how simple the game is and yet very unique in its own way. Never played a game like it

(The "Big Box" Edition), Played all editions recently, really made the game very long and extremely complicated. The scoring for the end game was to tedious to even care. The game is still amazing, Just wouldn’t recommend to play Every single rule in Carcassonne. Next time I play I won’t play Barns, Wagons, Inns and Cathedrals, Simply cause of the points can be overlooked and become to tedious. I loved the entire Big Box just would not mix up all of the expansions together.

RATING: 7

From Millennium in Henrietta '06

[b]Rating: 7[/b]
[i]Design rating[/i]: [b]4[/b]
[i]Component rating[/i]: [b]1[/b]
[i]Willingness to play rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b]
[i]Fun rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b] 

[b]Player considerations:[/b]
More the better, more competitive.

[b]My thoughts:[/b]
Needs a little more to not get boring, the fields are not as exciting as scoring in other games, like Hunters and Gatherers and Ark of the Covenant. Needs more or all the roads after roads tiles gets boring. Not enough variation of strategy.

RATING: 8
Was for a while my favorite game (with the expansions). I understand the criticisms, but the randomness is not an issue with me. And I know from beatings I endured on BSW that there is skill to this game, and tile draws will not mitigate against a difference in skill levels. Tis game has been a hit with every family member and friend we have taught it, and it is one my wife and I can play again and again. I prefer it for only 2-3 players. When it is just my wife and I, we play non-aggressively (limited blocking of each other in, etc.), and as a comfort game, it works just as well as when played in a more confrontational style. There are eople whose opinion I value who really, really don't like this game, but the objections they raise don't seem to bother me.

RATING: 8
I've heard it is a good family game and an appealing game even for non-gamers if played nice but I'm not very good at that. For me this game is a tense confrontation that's all about resource management, risk management, optimization, protecting your investments, and stealing from your enemies as much as possible to maximize your score. 

With the Inns & Cathedrals expansion this game ranks among my favorites for 2 & 3 players. With more players it is still a fun game but the influence of luck and chaos upon the outcome increases with each player added.

Carcassonne is very good game for 2-3 people. With 5 or 6 players uptime and randomization are very high and gaming becomes pointless.

RATING: 3
[size=12][b]Top 300 or higher board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Carcassonne:[/b][/size]
- The game lacks meaningful decisions because you are just randomly drawing and placing a tile. There are other filler games that are shorter and more enjoyable to play. 
- I am not a fan of collectible games and Carcassonne qualifies for this status with the number of expansions the game has. I consider this a sign that the game is flawed. 

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Not willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 8
Light game to wrap up an evening after a long day. No brain-busting decisions, just a pleasant time.

UPDATE JULY 2015: The more games I get, the more rulebooks I read, the more I crave the simplicity of Carcassonne. I have dubbed it my "Beer with Buddies" game, meaning you can sit down at a table with your friends, have a beer and chat about things while also laying down a tile here, a meeple there. I'm bumping it up from a 7 to an 8 because of that.

RATING: 8.5
One of my favorite games. It's like a competitive tile matching puzzle game. It has very pleasant to look at art, and the tiles are nice and thick. The building a landscape theme makes this a nice pick for younger crowds since it's nonviolent. There are many expansions of various sizes for Carcassonne, so there's tons of customization. My recommendation is to not use TOO many expansions at once or else you'll get a long and confusing game.

RATING: 8
Well-known tile-laying game which is still good, even I have (finally) growth out of it - just played it too much (~50). However, the basic set of Carcassonne needs the first expansion set, otherwise game is imbalanced: you get too much points of cities compared to roads.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this fairly light tile-laying offering, players pull a tile from the pool and then place it against one of the previously played tiles. If you create a new object (like a city, road or a monastery), then you can place one of your control markers on the tile to denote your control. Alternately, you can place your marker in the pasture on the tile as a farmer. Markers (called Followers by the publisher and called Meeples by us) cannot directly compete when placed, so to achieve some gains you must place your marker, then use later tiles to connect up to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Carcassonne is must have in any gamer's collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Carcassonne is a tile-placement game in which the players draw and place a tile with a piece of southern French landscape on it. The tile might feature a city, a road, a cloister, grassland or some combination thereof, and it must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played, in such a way that cities are connected to cities, roads to roads, etcetera. Having placed a tile, the player can then decide to place one of his meeples on one of the areas on it: on the city as a knight, on the road as a robber, on a cloister as a monk, or on the grass as a farmer. When that area is complete, that meeple scores points for its owner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Love this game! I like that the map changes each game and that you can play with up to 5 people. Each game being different is a lot of fun and the game rarely gets stale.

This is so very simple and the player has very limited actual control over how it's going to end.  This control seem to diminish as the # of player goes up.  Plus, even tho the mechanics are simple, the scoring can be a real hassle.  The best version I've seen of this is on XBox Live Arcade (a video game adaptation) where everything is automated and the only part left is the actual fun to be had (tile placement).  It's not a bad game, I just don't like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Edit:  Picked up the iPhone app, and have finally learned to appreciate this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sweet game. Extremely easy to play, but deep enough for the time it takes. It is very strange to find a game that can be played for both hardcore gamers and no gamers at all, and Carcassonne brilliantly hits this spot. Although I am not keen on games of this kind (I prefer other, more "epic" objectives) I can enjoy this one without effort. Recommendable.

RATING: 7.5
Base (vanilla) rating is probably a 7.  An excellent game to introduce non-gamers, newbies or casual gamers but I prefer Carcassonne Hunters & Gatherers best.  For a Carc-on-training-wheels version, just skip or eliminate the farming rules if you think that the inexperienced players/kids could not handle it yet.  With the plethora of expansions, you should a la carte which ones to add.  Four or less should keep the game from being excessively long.  It's pretty cool-looking to watch the whole landscape of Carcassonne build out.  I always think of this when Le Tour de France stage hits this town in France.  [The extra half-point to 7.5 is b/c I never play just the base game so I added it for when expansions are thrown in.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Egy játék alapján (amiben az alapjátékot és a kereskedő kiegészítőt használtuk (az építész és a disznók nélkül)) alapvetően tetszett. Szerettem azon gondolkozni, hogy hova is lenne a legjobb letenni az adott lapot, ugyanakkor kicsit olyan érzésem támadt, hogy nincs igazi választási lehetőségem: ha odaillik valahova, ahova nekem jó, akkor oda kell letenni, ha meg nem, akkor pedig nagyjából mindegy. Szóval nem éreztem eléggé, hogy a saját döntéseim alakítanák a játékot, túl nagy volt annak az aránya, hogy a játék önmagát játszotta a két játékost bábként felhasználva.
Kevésnek éreztem a játékosok közti interakciót. Nehéz elérni, és nem is igazán törekszik rá az ember, hogy az adott mezőn/várban/úton többségbe kerüljön, ha más is odavetődik; mi inkább csak magunknak játszottunk, szinte passziánszoztunk. Ezen lehet majd javítani a gróf és a sárkány kiegészítőkkel, kíváncsi vagyok mennyit javul velük a véleményem.
Szóval így elsőre nekem túl egyszerű ez a játék, amiben lehetne ugyan sokat gondolkozni minden egyes lépésen, de ez valószínűleg nem sokkal növelné a játékélményt. Nem igazán lehet a másik játékára hatni, csak nagyon közvetett módon, ami vagy összejön, vagy nem. Direkt kölcsönhatás a játékosok között gyakorlatilag nincs, ennek a hiányát erősen éreztem.

A társasjátékokkal többször játszva mindig javulni szokott róluk a véleményem, hisz jobban megismerve őket jobban meglátom az értékeiket, a szépségüket, és valószínűleg ennél is ez fog történni. Első játék után kb. 7 pont, aztán majd meglátjuk!

Update: Játszottam 3 személlyel is, teljesen jól működik így a játék. Játszottam a netes verzióban egy rakás kiegészítővel (sárkányos, építész és kereskedő, kocsmás, király és vándor), azok is teljesen jól működnek, pluszt adnak a játékhoz. 7 -> 7.5 pont.

Update2: Rá kellett jönnöm, hogy ez egy férfiaknak való játék. A barátnőmmel játszottunk, és az volt a gond, hogy míg ő békésen építkezve játszott volna, addig én agresszív voltam: több félkész városát is elfoglaltam, majd végül a nagy mezőjét is. Rosszul esett neki, úgy érezte, én nem építek, hanem csak rombolok. Én viszont nem vagyok képes másképp játszani, mint győzelemre törekedve a játékszabályok maradéktalan betartásával és kihasználásával, ráadásul szerintem épp a városokért/utakért/mezőkért folyó kis csatározások adják meg a játék ízét, nélkülük ez a játék unalmas és interakció nélküli. Számomra csodás érzés küzdeni a többség kialakításáért vagy megtartásáért egy-egy nagyobb városban vagy mezőn. Az egyszerűsége mellett pont ez az, amivel együtt szerintem megérdemli az év játéka díjat, és amitől annyi rajongója van.
Női aggyal játszva (konfrontációt kerülve simán csak építkezve) semmilyen potenciált nem látok a játékban, nem érzem, mi lehet benne úgy a jó. Így aztán vegyes nemű társaságnak vagy nőknek nem javaslom, fiútestvéreknek vagy férfi baráti társaságnak viszont annál inkább, lehetőleg kiegészítőkkel együtt.

Update3: Jó játék ez: 7.5 -> 7.7 pont.

Update4: Újrapontozom a játékokat aszerint, hogy melyikkel mennyire szívesen játszanék mondjuk ma este. Ez alapján: 7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
One of the first wave of great Euro-strategy games, this is a game that has a very simple gameplay and easy setup and execution, but which also has endless replay value.  There's a huge number of expansions and versions available, but the original set alone is enough to keep you occupied forever.  It can be taught in just a few minutes, but with the degree of variation, it never gets stale.  You can play offensively or defensively, the strategy can get quite deep, and it's not too random.

As perhaps the very definition of a tile-laying game, it works great -- the pieces are solid with attractive artwork, and the theme is simple enough to lend itself to a lot of variations.  It takes up a decent amount of space, but there's not too many pieces or too much complexity.  This game is a classic for a reason, combining simplicity and elegance for tons of play value.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I love Carcassonne. I purchased the big box 2010 edition and it was the best $75 I had ever used to purchase a game. Carcassonne is so simple, and yet the strategy is amazingly complex with just the right amount of complexity to make it a hit. The reason it got a 9 was because my very first play I just wanted more out of it, more tiles, different tiles, more ways to score, more ways to screw someone. BAM! expansions. This game is perfect with two players, tried it with three and it went well, but it's hard to explain with more people but it's easy to pick up and play. Grade: A+

RATING: 7.5
BREMEN
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This was our gateway game.  The tile placement mechanism is very conceptual and understandable---you just have to match up the edges.  Using meeples for controlling different areas elevates the strategy above simple tile matching.  

We were also able to still have fun playing with only two players.  For the first couple of months, we would play several times each night.  We would play over and over again.  The best part of the game, and something that I think is underrated, is that the gameplay scales very well with your experience level.  In the beginning, we would play nicely and it became more of a "race" game to finish features.  But as we played it more, we began to get a lot more aggressive and cut-throat as we'd hone in and try to steal each other's cities, roads, and farms.  You can fine tune the amount of interactivity in the game to the comfort of each player.  

Even after several years, we still have [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/39484/item/862918#item862918]tense, nerve-wracking games[/url].  I have to give it a well-deserved  10 rating.

Session Reports:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/297568]A Farewell Carcassonne Match[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Just recently got a copy of this after playing our friend's (who has all the expansions) many times, was surprised at how quick and low-scoring the game is when you don't have all those extra goodies. Regarding gameplay - since you aren't allowed to directly move in on someone's claimed feature it may seem very good-natured and less competitive... but just give it a few games and the cuttthroat maneuvers develop.

RATING: 8
Excellent tile-layer. Quite a few rules, but the basic gist of the game can be explained in a few minutes (leave the scoring in the hands of a pro for the first few plays). A must for any serious eurogamer, and a toehold into the genre for newbies. Not beer-proof. Of the two "entry-level" eurogames, my gaming group generally prefers Catan, but Carcassonne hits the table often enough.

RATING: 6
Yes, I know that there is skill involved in this game (I happen to suck at it enough to see it quite clearly), but it's the randomness combined with the need to know the tile distribution that bugs me.  Just not my kind of game.

UPDATE: Bumped my rating to a 5, simply because it didn't seem right to rate this lower than Settlers and equal to Monopoly.  A casual gamer friend of mine bought a copy recently (without any prompting from me), so I will actually be playing this quite happily for the next while to encourage her gaming tendencies.

UPDATE: playing this face-to-face has increased my appreciation for the game significantly.  For some reason, while I still play to win, Carc dampens my usual competitive drive to the point where i can just sit back, relax, and enjoy being with friends.  That said, I suspect I really do need to play it with friends.  Note, this rating is for the base game with the standard start tile and no expansions.  I rate the River a 7.

RATING: 9
This game is so simple, but can be so tense at the same time. You only ever place one tile at a time, making teaching it a breeze. I pretty much only play this game 2 player, though I'd play 3 if required, 4+ is rubbish (too much downtime, though the fact the board gets more clogged up with other people's stuff is interesting).

RATING: 5
Works well as a gateway game and definitely requires quite a bit of spatial analysis, but it's just so bland, regardless if you're playing draw 1 tile or hand of 3. It's just different ways to score points and is really abstract. Now I like Patchwork which is also a very Euro-ey, spatial aspect required, abstract game, but I like the economic button aspect of Patchwork too, along with the theme, the artwork, and that it doesn't feel as point-salady, whereas Carcassonne's multiple, somewhat arbitrary scoring methods doesn't integrate well thematically to me.

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Took this to the neighbor's house last night.  It was a hit!  It was the first time playing for three of us, and our son had played on Xbox Live so had some experience.  Fast game, lots of fun had by all.  Played three games back to back and would have played another but the boy exceeded his waking hour limit for the day.

Players seemed to enjoy ease of rule explanation and the tactile nature of tile laying.  Some played nice (my wife and son) and some played mean (neighbor and myself).  Truly a game that can support both styles of play - not to say that the nice players appreciate the actions of the cutthroat players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Carcassonne is what personally pulled me into board games as a whole. This game has an excellent random factor of pulling tiles. This makes the game map new every time and makes it exciting every time. The random element is great because, no matter what tile you pull, you can always score some points off of it. 

Repeat plays lead to more experience as you learn the game tiles and tricks and tips of how to play certain tiles but all of this experience can be gained very quickly (1 or 2 games).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
One of my absolute favorite games. More depth than there appears the first ten times you play it, the player interaction is flirtatious and hilariously passive aggressive ("oh don't mind me, if you just happened to complete my road while working on your abbey, that would be fine", or "pay no attention to my dude in your castle!"). It is the perfect game that gives generously of fun for both gamers and non-gamers, that you can play as cooperatively or as aggressively as you want.

I don't know what you call this, but Carcassonne also has the highest "possible outcome" to "ease of decision making" of any game out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

'Inns' & 'Builders' are great additions (esp. for the extra players and tile bag), but I think the 'Count' and 'Dragon' add too much complexity and not enough fun.

RATING: 7
Carcassonne is a great tile laying game where you select a tile and place it on the board and may place one of you meeples in a city, road, field or cloister.  You are trying to complete these and score points.  

It is very family friendly and a very nice game.  The art is not superb but tiles are functional and the game is easy to learn.

RATING: 6

RATING: 4
I don't know what it is exactly, but I just do not enjoy playing this game. It seems that the times I have played have been very tile dependent. I could be completely screwed if I try to build a city and don't get the tiles I need to complete it. Not a fan of this game... but I like other games that are draw a card/tile and make something happen (i.e. Kingdom Builder). So not sure what it is... maybe I just feel helpless when I draw the tile that doesn't help me at all when in Kingdom Builder there are some special action tokens I can get that will help mitigate a bad card draw or if I place my settlements better then I don't have to worry about a bad card draw. Any who... I am not a Carcassonne fan.

RATING: 6.5
Easy enough to learn quickly and play with anyone.  A little more depth than you'd think after playing your first game. Opportunity to play at a higher level of strategy, especially if you play aggressively against your opponent.  

Only downside is the luck of the draw for the tiles, but for this medium-light game I think it works OK.  I think the more skilled player will win most of the time.  

Very easy to transport; if you want the tiles and followers could be in a ziplock bag for a trip.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
I think this game is BEST played at 2 players.  At that number, it is chess-like and challenging.  With more, it becomes more about king-making (your score being dependent on another, often disinterested or only focusing on themselves, player).  

I think the standard expansions that must be used is Traders and Builders and Inns and Cathedrals.  Beyond that I have enjoyed the worker removal factor of the Princess and the Dragon as well as the random element that Wheel of Fortune adds.  

Stay away from the Catapult as well as the Bridges.

It becomes entertaining enough for adults with the addition of a few expansions, namely: Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Mini, and Siege. That's it. Don't waste your money on anything else. Seriously. Just leave them alone. You'll regret it if you don't. We still have a few of the other expansions laying around, but we rarely use them. This game is still an excellent and light gateway game and even though we've had it forever, it's still charming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of my favorite games. Played well by most teens. Expansions are plentiful and inexpensive. Most expansions provide variability in the game, but some are a mere distraction (last five years of expansions) and some simply take the strategy out of the game (river). The original series of expansions are by far the best and allow for meaningful diversity and number of tiles. Too many expansions should be avoided as it takes far too long to explain the game to newcomers and players tire quickly from this game.

RATING: 9.5
I really enjoy this one.  If you're wanting to have a decent collection of gateway games, this should be in there.  The expansions are pretty fun, and I like the fact that you can simply leave the expansion tiles in the mix for a longer game but not necessarily play by the expansion rules. (does not apply to all expansions.)

If it's a bit too light for you, just add an expansion or two.  Also lots of non-official variants can make it interesting as well (like having a hand of tiles to choose from.)

RATING: 8.5
2.0 £7.99 iOS only. I bought this game because the reviews looked good, but it sat in its box for ages as it doesnt look that exciting from the outside. I do have the app on my iphone, but I didn't like the iphone instructions, didnt get how to play, so it got left.

However, when I finally got it out and played it with people, its a really nice little game. After a few games, it started to become clearer the different tactics that emerged, particularly in 2 player games where two people can build themselves into a city and both score points. The more I play, the more vicious it gets!

From a slow start this is probably one of my favourite board games ever.

Area control/Area influence, Tile Placement

Mostly played on iOS now.

Gameslore £12.49, Feb 2011. https://www.boardgamegeek.com/video/3075/carcassonne/how-play-carcassonne-pt-1-2-base-set

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
When I was first introduced to this game a year or two back, I put the following brief review on my website:

"If you%u2019re into tabletop games, you could do far worse than give Carcassonne a look. Having played it (till my head hurt) quite a bit over recent weeks, I%u2019m blown away by how perfect a game it is. The rules are staggeringly simple, the strategy simple enough for a beginner to pick up (yet subtle enough to reward experience), and the games themselves last less than an hour. In my book, that ticks all of the boxes perfectly. Highly recommended."

I still stand by it. Carcassonne is, in my eyes, the perfect board game and ideal for opening your friends' eyes to the joys of gaming. Granted, many of the expansion packs can detract from the game, but the plain vanilla original is bang on the money.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I have just started playing this with my 7-year old daughter this week, and we are now playing 2-3 games a day.  She loves it.  My 5-year old daughter is also playing it, although she does not completely grasp the rules or strategy.  My wife has started playing with us too, so that is a very good sign as she is not much of a game lover.  After 4 days of playing, we just went out to purchase three of the smaller expansions.  I think that this is a great entry level family game that is complex enough to be challenging and to encourage replaying.  I recommend this one highly!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I loved this when I was first introduced to it, but after several plays it got irritating--it's hard to plan ahead, the board changes too radically too often (one tile can suddenly put several other players' meeples in your field). And it's very hard to estimate your score, as fields are only scored at the end, by which point they'll be totally different. Scoring that happens as you play is also difficult, because the board gets so cluttered and confused. The expansions only add more clutter and chaos, nothing of value.  I can play a game of vanilla Carc and still pretty much enjoy it, but I'd rather play something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

Is it best game you will ever play? No.

But for what the game brings to the table, you will be very happy with your play time. Light strategy & planning, some luck with the tile draws, and plenty of fun. The best part is it is the ideal gateway game. You can teach it to non-gamers in about 5 minutes, and there is no set up. Plus there is just something fun about making a puzzle together and the meeples are cute.

A perfect way to spend 30-45 minutes with friends.

Components are of high quality.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
it was good....but i don't play it a lot now....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Garten
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've played this game by far the most, mostly 2 player. It is easy to learn, even for my kids (6 and 5). I like the diffuse nature of play, that a winning strategy is built up gradually from lots of seemingly weak tiles. You don't have to concentrate or remember anything (unless you want to memorise the tile mix!). I like that opening/mid game/end game tactical changes are required too. I use a custom tile set made up of 72 tiles from the base game and I&C plus 15 trade tiles from T&B, to keep it short and snappy. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Uno de los primeros que tuve. Pero en cuanto descubrí más juegos, se quedó en la estantería.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In my opinion, the only drawback of Carcassonne is that the game relentlessly encourages experienced players to be really nasty to each other during the whole course of a game (as stated in my comment of Ticket to Ride). There's no mechanism to counter it.
That said, it's one of the greatest game I know, with a replayability that earns it one of my highest scores. It was the growing hit that converted some of my closest friends to be as open to boardgaming as I am, so I can only praise it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first "serious" game. It´s a very solid design and I really like this game. The fact that my wife never turns down a game of Carcassonne makes me like it even more. 

I like the multiple paths to points, the puzzle aspect, the simple rules, the short-medium time to play, the high replayability and the meaningful decisions. 

One thing that I specially like is the end scoring. Even if you score a lot of points during the game, you have to wait until the end scoring to confirm the victory. This keeps the tension until the very end.

I think it´s an excellent game for 2 players and a very good game for 3 players. With 4, 5 and 6 players, each player looses control and the game is just OK.

Despite being my first modern game, Carcassonne still reaches the table when we are in the right mood.

Unfortunetly, I had no success introducing this game to my non-gamer friends, I don´t know why!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bastante simple...cada jugador pone una plaquita en la mesa para ir formando castillos, caminos, campos y poner una ficha propia sobre alguno de esos lugares, para ganar puntos teniendo castillos más grandes, caminos más largos y campos que abastezcan más castillos.
Tiene algo de rompecabezas o puzzle; algo de planificaciòn anticipada.
Tal vez jugando entre dos personas es cuando más estratégico se vuelve, porque con muchas personas se torna difícil  controlar el desarrollo del mismo y de las construcciones.
Con Inns and Cathedral se puede mejorar la estrategia, ya que hay más elementos que considerar.
En fin: un juego familiar, para empezar a interesarse en los eurogames. Los más fanáticos querrán luego algo más complejo.

RATING: 7
Resources constraints (in the form of limited meeples) and just the right amount of chance can make for some agonizing decisions. That plus accessibility and a variety of ways to win makes for a pretty good game.

The problem is that nearly every game I played back when I bought Carc came down to farmers in a sort of fixed and predictable way. Once I noticed that, I pretty much lost interest in Carc. After six years with no plays or interest in playing, I sold it.

...and then bought the winter edition because I'm a sucker for winter themes and realized what seemed like a fixed path through the game was likely due in large part to my group at the time's metagame. I like it more again now.

RATING: 7
Being a construction worker myself, once upon a time, I love this game. I feel like the alliance/coalition building aspect of this is overlooked in most games. The best players (in my opinion) are those who treat this game NOT as a way to one-up each other and pull in-your-face! type of moves. 

Rather, the top-level performers are those who work TOGETHER to build huge castles, long roads, profitable fields, etc. Share a big couple of projects, one with each different player on the board, and they all now have an incentive to help YOU win BIG. :)

Expansions I own: 
8/10 - The Tower
7/10 - Princess and the Dragon
6/10 - The River (a slightly better way to start the game)

But I continue to own and play it because it's a brilliant utility game: it's easy to learn, quick to play and caters for a wide number of players and tastes. Virtually anyone can spend a fun 45 minutes playing Carcassone. So, in spite of my somewhat "meh" attitude to the game itself, this is a definite keeper.

RATING: 7.5
Another standard gateway game that I play with non-gamers or if people want a shorter game.

What I like:
- Pretty easy to teach.  Probably not as simple as Ticket to Ride, but still pretty simple.
- Game length is fairly short (45-60 minutes), and not much downtime between turns (if people don't try to think too hard)
- Plenty of tension in trying to get in on people's features or preventing their features from completing.
- Also plenty of cooperation (and maybe some backstabbing) when working together to complete features.
- Game complexity can be increased by introducing the expansions

What I don't like:
- Lack of control over what tile you draw (I haven't tried the hand variant).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Carcassonne is a tile laying, and worker placement game.  On your turn you place a tile down into the play area.  The tiles depict various terrain such as cities, roads, fields, and cloisters.  To properly place the tile one of the four edges must touch, and match terrain with a tile already played.  Then you may place a worker on the tile you just placed to claim it.  Once cities, roads, and cloisters are completed, they score.   Farmer's fields score at the end.  The players with the most points at the end wins.

Carcassonne, is light.  It's usually referred to as a gateway game.  Meaning it works well introducing people to the board game hobby.  As such, I really liked it a lot when I began playing designer games.  After awhile though I found it very repetitive.  It's possible that this could be mitigated by the large number of expansions, but I never got into them.

I would recommend Carcassonne to new gamers for sure.  I'd still play it from time to time, but for the most part I've moved on to games with either more interesting mechanics, themes, or both.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Beautiful game, unusual in that it's a lot of fun for anywhere from 2 to 6 players. Great for all ages 4+ (though scoring needs to be done for the littlies). The brilliance is the lovely board, a unique version of which you create in the course of playing... so set-up time is very short. More strategy than you might think; my mother-in-law LOVES this game but has never beaten me, despite many dozens of plays (we play Carcassonne rather than talk!). In fairness, she does suck really badly at it - my (then) 5 year old daughter was a good match for her. Interestingly, the style of game changes dramatically as the skill of the players increases, and also with the number of players.
Has an excellent iOS app with strong AI that play very aggressively - "evil" is quite beatable, but it will require some thought.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
GAMEPLAY: A tile-placement and area-control eurogame. Players take turns drawing and placing a tile. The player who placed a tile decides whether to place one of her limited supply of meeples on one of the features on the tile, hoping to score victory points later on when the feature is completed by the placement of other tile(s) or at the end of the game. The game ends after the last tile is placed. The game is improved by some of the expansions. I recommend Traders & Builders and Inns & Cathedrals in particular. I prefer to play with no more than two expansions at a time.

WEIGHT: Medium-light. The rules are not complex.

PLAYER INTERACTION/CONFLICT: High. If there are not struggles for control of large features in your game, you aren’t playing it right.

PLAYER COUNT: Scales fine from two to five players but luck increases with higher player counts. A good high-conflict two-player game.

LUCK: Moderate. Lucky tile draws can certainly determine the outcome of games. As the player count increases and each individual player necessarily draws fewer tiles throughout the game, the luck factor also increases and more games will be won by whomever happened to draw the right tile at just the right moment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

With so many expansions avaliable, the simplicity of the original gets lost and, even worse, it's hard when playing with people who don't always play together to decide what the rules really are, because people have their favorite expansions.

RATING: 7
This game is great. The components are great, and the play is fun.  Sometimes I remove farmer scoring when teaching new players, which upsets the elegance of the game.  I prefer playing just the base game which allows for a "card counting" style play, increasing the strategic/tactical element.

Expansions add random tiles and, in my opinion, unnecessary complexity to a beautiful design.  However, I do like playing with and without the River Expansion. Helps keep the variety in the game.

RATING: 9
Quick (30-60 min.), fun, and great for 2-5 players. No 2 games are the same and strategy (what little there is) changes constantly. Very random game with heavy emphasis on speculation (i.e. will this move pay off later?) Good light-game for families or casual gamers. Light enough that my wife loves this one, and usually beats me (which enhances its appeal to her). We play with the Traders & Builders and Inns & Cathedrals expansions which enhance player interaction, competitiveness, and strategy... and time (each expansion adds 30 minutes).

RATING: 8.5
A fantastic tile laying game! Carcassonne was one of my "initiation" games and subsequently I've fostered a love of tile laying mechanics ever since. RATING: 7.3
Played it with 4-players, together with 3 expansions. My wife and our mutual friends really like this game. I love playing this game with them, but I find the game itself not really meaningful (for me it's draw a tile, place a tile and a token, yeah, score, etc.). I know that this last comment can be said about any game. But I don't have any control on what tiles I get. The only thing you can decide is where to place a tile and whether or not you place a token on it to score. The mechanic just doesn't do it for me.

I do like the expansions, so this game (with expansions) wins it from Hunters and Gatherers: I adjusted the rating. And I love the art, especially that of a finished game.

RATING: 8
Our gateway game, and one we still still gladly play from time to time. Anna and I play in a very cutthroat manner, usually including the 1st expansion. We like the 2nd expansion a little less, since we rather compete for cities and roads than for resources, although we see the appeal of having the other player compromising and finishing your city. Lately, "Carc: The Castle" has replaced vanilla Carc for us somewhat, but we'll see how that one holds up after repeated plays.

Edit 01-15: After nine months of gaming, this is already a bit on the "too light" side for us. Doesn't see much play anymore, except when we introduce it to newbies.

RATING: 10
Caracassonne and 5 expansions. This is a really cool set. The problem we have with the game is that you are supposed to stack the tiles in x piles, but you can pick from any pile on any turn. Well, the tiles are slippery, it would work better to just have all the tiles in a bag and you draw from the bag. But the game itself is great (I do have a tendency to lose meeples by trying to build cities that get out of control).

RATING: 7
It has been said before but this truly is a great gateway game.  The rules are relatively straight forward, even though some people find the farmers a bit confusing.  Almost anyone can play but there is enough subtletities to keep me interested.  I really prefer base Carcassonne without expansions.  I guess I burned out on expansions back in my Talisman/CE days.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
01/17/02 Bought the 2000 edition. Love it. A great gateway game. You can either "play nice" with newbies, showing them where they can help themselves the most. Or the screwage factor can be very high if you want to try to hinder as many of your experienced opponent's structures as possible, or glom on when the opportunity arises. 
As of 12/20/17 I've played 116 games, the majority with an expansion (or two).

08/15/17 Played using the new edition, and its Abbot expansion. The abbot was a nice edition.  Though I have no idea what fields have to do with being an abbot.  I did find a lot of the incidental artwork on the new edition tiles distracting as it was 2-3 times the size of the old version's minor artwork (pig pens, sheep corrals, and the most annoying, buildings around road intersections). Also, a few of the roads were yellow. Huh?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have yet to play this one with expansions, but people often say that expansions make it way better. It is already a very good game, so that would be amazing!
I like the theme, the artwork (simple as it is), the tile laying gameplay. You can be ambitions and go for massive, risky structures or play it safe and score many small amounts of points. If you're clever with peasant placement you can steal points that other player's would have gotten at the end of the game without them noticing before it is too late! This is quintessential Euro-gaming to me: Elegant, decently strategic, replayable and lightly themed. No bloat in the design. There is exactly the amount of components to it that there needs to be; no more, no less.
I rate it less than perfect because: (1) Maybe it is true that expansion will make it better so I need to try that for myself. (2) I'm still new enough to board games that I prefer to leave some head room for future favourites, score wise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
As cut-throat and tense as the group wants to play it. Sure, you can be screwed by the draw and your opponents can have everything fall in their laps, but that's true for most games I play - and on the whole, you have more influence on the outcome than not.

I'm eager to try the expansions Inns & Cathedrals, and Traders & Builders, as they seem to add some interesting dynamics to the game while not pushing the complexity too far from the original.

Easy game to play with anyone, but it still has enough to consider for people who enjoy more complex games. Works great with the whole range of players as well (though preferably not more than 4 I'd say) - so that's also a plus. 

A great game!

UPDATE: Played with Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders and the River. Unsure about the River but otherwise these two take the game up a couple of notches, absolutely recommended!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Game in a Nutshell: Build cities, roads, and farms by laying one tile at a time. Then place a marker (meeple) to claim it as your own so long as it doesn't belong to someone else. Finish your claims and score points or mess with other people trying to finish theirs. Most points win.

Played as: 2,3,4,5 player (xbox live: 2,4,5)

Played with: Plain; Inns & Cathedrals; Traders & Builders; Inns & Cathedrals + Princess & the Dragon; Inns & Cathedrals + The River II; Inns & Cathedrals + Princess & the Dragon + The River II.

Pros: Big love to a light quicker game that plays well with a smaller group (2-3). My favorite part of the game is how any tile can be used for your gain or an opponents demise. And it's up to you to weigh out so many options in a wide open environment. Few games feel like art in motion, this is one of them as you watch the board grow with every tile. It's like the swiss army knife of games: use it as a fill-in while waiting for a larger crowd to gather for a meatier game; play back-to-back with a friend, you name it and this game will work for the occasion.

Cons: Like most tile-laying games (abstract by nature), it didn't have that instant click that makes a person excited to try it again. This, I think, somewhat diminishes its gateway appeal as compared to SoC or TTR. 

Other: The least luck-based of all the euro gateways. With it's less appealing abstract nature strongly countered by a less luck driven, more intimate (better with less players) feel, this is really a gateway game of a different less social breed. The game's interest will die off if played casually while longer life can be achieved with aggressive play.

Best Use: Works for almost any occasion-- warm-up, filler, 2-3 player gateway, single session time killer, etc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I do enjoy this game time to time though when in the right mood. Need to try it with more expansions because I feel they would make this game more tense and exciting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I used to think this game was too simple and (mostly) luck-based. Then I played a few game on Carcassonne iPad app. Boy, was I wrong... 
This game is a strategic masterpiece hidden behind a cute, relaxing theme. It's also much more evil than most people can imagine, at least when played optimally. There is LOTS of skill in basic (no expansions) 2-player game, obviously with more players the luck factor increases.
Have you ever tried to get into the someone's big city, or even a road? Have you ever placed your tile(s) in such a way so as to minimize opponent's chances of filling in a big city or road? Do you know how and when to place your farmers? (bad farmer placement can easily lose you the game) Do you know the distribution of the tiles and take it into consideration when deciding on your move?
Guess what - strong players CONSISTENTLY do all of the above and are able to post very impressive win rates. Even if you know some (or all) of these concepts you'll still get trashed (in the long run) by someone who employs them better than you. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 4
Well, it's okay for what it is. The rules are pretty easy to get into, although the scoring (especially the end-game scoring) probably requires more than one play to really get a handle on. Like most Euros, it really doesn't make a lot of sense as far as what you're doing--what, are cities and roads falling out of the sky or something? I'd play this occasionally. Better yet, rarely.

It's a more than adequate poster child for the "meh" that is the Eurogame. This is really the game that convinced me that most of the "classic" Euros are essentially children's games with elaborate scoring systems.

RATING: 8
This game is severely underrated. I realize that BGG members are generally hardcore boardgamers, and they tend to look down on "gateway games." This game is fantastic: elegant and easy in style and mechanics, yet the gameplay is different every time thanks to the random tile draw. I love playing it with hardcore and casual gamers alike. I love that my four-year-old was able to pick up the game mechanics and strategy (no reading) and play better every time. Great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wonderful tile laying and worker placement game. Absolutely recommended for family game night although may be beyond the reach of kids under 12. Great for adults, too! The instructions are simple and concise, but the game has many layers of depth to it. 

The random draw for the tiles and then the matching aspect of the tile laying combined with the meeple placement make for a new and different game each time. 

Scoring can be a bit tricky and may require a reference to the instructions during the first few games, but once played through, the mechanics really make for a fun experience.

With dozens of simple, yet deep expansions available for the base game (~$35USD) the themes and variety seem to be endless. 

Well worth the purchase and will stay on my game shelves for years to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.01
A nice game: my wife's favorite and the most-often-played for two years running.  We have several expansions, which we use from time to time.  Plays pretty fast, but the more expansions you add, the more random the final scoring turns out to be.

(Mind you, I can at least be badgered into it.  I do not think that is true about most Eurogames.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[microbadge=1714]  [microbadge=21390]

[u]08-Jan-2013[/u]: This is the game that introduced me to this hobby, and perhaps because of that, it is (and likely will always be) my favorite game.  This hits basically all of my gaming wants: tiles, modular board, good components, puzzle-like, easily played solitaire (either solo multiplayer or with the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/41710/soloplay_carcassonne_wexpansions_v1-pdf]SoloPlay variant[/url], which I love), aesthetically pleasing, variety.  To me, it's all in there.

This is another game Mrs Mo actually enjoys (in it's "vanilla" form) but our girls don't as much.  I really wish my wife would play 2P games with me, because this one would be our go to.  It's fairly simple (the farmer scoring seems to mess a little with the people I play with).  It looks good on the table as you build the landscape with various cities and roads.  It's got meeples!  It has strategy but in that light (vanilla Carc) to light-mid (with I&C added) range.

If you want to go crazy, there are numerous expansions that add all kinds of things.  I am content with Inns & Cathedrals as it adds just that little extra strategy and gameriness (how's that for a made up word) to make it that much more fun and challenging.

Highly recommended all around.

[u]24-Jan-2014[/u]: Still my favorite game despite not really having anyone to play against.  I play a lot using the iOS app vs various AIs so that kind of gives me my fix.  Otherwise, I play mostly with various solo variants.  Just really enjoy this game.

[u]The Solo Variants[/u]:
[listitem=1129534]SoloPlay Variant[/listitem]
This is my favorite way to play solo.  The SoloPlay variants aren't for everyone as some of them have some funky setups and additional rules for gameplay and scoring, but I really enjoy them.  This one can be used with just the base game, or with one or both of the first two expansions (I&C and T&B), or with or without the River.  So lots of options.  It alters all the scoring and adds new ways to score, so it takes a few plays to get it.  But I really like it.

[thread=361708]Carc Island[/thread]
This is a more straightforward variant.  Basically just build within a specified grid and score as usual.  It's much quicker than the SoloPlay variant.  But I found if you add in expansions, it becomes more luck of the draw as there are too many for the grid size.

[listitem=2310292]Byron's Solo Variant[/listitem]
And this is a fun one for something a little different.  It rewards you for building larger cities and roads rather than a bunch of smaller ones.  Pretty neat variant.  I've only played it a few times, but I like that the focus is a different here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
So, I've been thinking - I really ought to play this more. In the time between turns, I could finish my thesis. And with all the expansions, a game could take several weeks.

Most viable for two because of this, and  while I recognize that there is a backgammon-like element of trying to make sure that you have a good move no matter what the next tile is, in general I don't have a lot of patience for the passivity of the draw-one-tile-then-play-it games. Of course, the Carcasonnes are prettier than backgammon, which helps a little.

Vanilla Carc though is just well, vanilla. Almost no tension, and I tire of it. I don't play games just to kill time. Hunters and Gatherers is a significant improvement, but even that I don't want to play with more than two.

RATING: 6
A good game and something I will always go to first when playing with people that don't game often. However, the farming game irritates the hell out of me. New players can never grasp it their first couple games, which ensures they never win, and it just feels like more of a chore every time I play. Having it be so absolutely vital to winning yet the only move that limits your options means the more your group grasps the importance, the more time they'll spend focused on it, and the less fun the game will be overall.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is very simple, both to teach and to play. Players take turns and draw a tile and connect it to the existing map then may place a “meeple” to try and determine control of certain key positions for points. The player with the most points after the last tile is played is the winner! Slight complications arise with scoring rules but it’s nothing terribly complex. That said there could be very deep strategies involved playing this game and choices where to place tiles and Meeples become crucial. There’s not a lot of player interaction and it’s usually light in confrontation but can be played more aggressively as players vie for control over certain types of structures and areas on the map. A great, flexible game that can be taken as seriously as you wish. 

Some of the expansions add some interesting wrenches into the mix and spice things up! Always a good “go to” game and I have had very successful sessions of using Carcassonne as a “gate way” game to other, more complex offerings. Very highly recommended! Truly, a must have!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Awesome game I still enjoy playing. Always play with the following extensions to have enough options available to us: Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Place map tiles and meeples to complete map features for most points.

Plays: More than a dozen?
Type: VP race = a game where you race to collect victory points (fastest/most).
Complexity: Family game = A game that is easy to teach and play.
# of players: 2-5.
Playing time: 30 mins.
Player interaction: Can be played without interaction. Competitive play will involve competition for scarce resources and opportunity prevention. These become more pronounced with 2 players, making the game less family and more strategy.
Randomness: Medium - tile draw.

Replayability: Not so high, usually this serves as a starter or a filler.
Fun: A bit of fun to complete your map features.
Memorability: Not really.

Thematic integration: Workable, with broad appeal.
Components: Iconic. The original Meeple.

Who will like this: Everyone. A must have in every game collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Very nice tile placement game that is great for non-to-serious gamers.  My parents love playing it while still being entertaining for me.

EDIT: After many, many more plays I've come to appreciate this game more and more. The game's dynamic can be friendly and light all the way to darn cut-throat depending on the group of people playing.  A go-to for me with new gamers.  A game that can really stand the test of time and repeated plays.  Still not something I would want to play if I was looking for a "serious" game night, but rather something I will gladly play if I want to sit down and relax with friends or family. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Gets newcomers amused by the pretty little bits. Decent filler.  Fun to talk about the map you're building.  Less strategic with a larger group, but if you're playing with fewer, there are just so many games with a comparable playtime that outshine this.

3/3/2014: I've recently played with some righteous Carcassonne-defenders, who insist it's a much more nuanced beast once you've memorized the frequencies of different tile elements, and know the odds of your plays/blocks working out.  Fine.  True of many games.  I still don't see reason enough to spend the time it takes to reach that point on this one.

RATING: 7
Egyszerű lapkalehelyezős családi játék.

Házi szabállyal sokkal élvezetesebb (pl. 3 lapkát húzol, egyet raksz le), jobban taktikázható.

Nincs ugyan két egyforma játék a rengeteg lapka és variáció miatt, de kiegészítők nélkül elég gyorsan unalmassá válhat.

UPDATE (2017.08.28.): eladva
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Light game.  Works well as a gateway game.  Many expansions, although they seem to make a simple system somewhat touchy.  The question remains...which farmer scoring to use?

>>Update<<

Had to drop the rating of Carcassonne as it now bores the shit out of me.  Also, I could probably suggest a handfull of BETTER gateway games which do not involve tedious tile wrangling.

RATING: 5
I understand but don't quite buy into this game's wide appeal; playing with more than three is deadly dull. Nevertheless, I've played my share of games, mostly two player, and have no intention of ever trading it away. The Inns and Cathedrals expansion is a must add-on, and Knizia's [i]Carcassonne: the Castle[/i] (7) is a very good variation on the Carc theme.  Nice the way the expansions and Castle can all fit in the original Carcassonne box. Oh, and one more thing: I think that green color burned my retinae. [27  plays]

Update: Recently bought the River II expansion, which simply but effectively improves the beginning of the game.
