RATING: 8
classic
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The more I've played this the more I like it... so subtle and beautiful and really unlike anything else I own. Those that complain it is too simple, too abstract, or too uninteresting are themselves too simple and too uninteresting. With the right ruthless opponent (like my wife) this game becomes an excruciating competition of area control, and essentially gambling as you weigh the benefits of placing a meeple for scoring much later against the possibility you will not draw the tile you need, or have your opponent place a tile in a position to prevent you from completing your plans. Best with 2 only, since it becomes pure competition. Also, it doesn't really become a pure game until both players are familiar enough with all the pieces (the way one becomes familiar with the 52 cards in a standard playing card deck) that each decision of placement (tile and meeple) becomes educated based on knowledge of future potential. Not worth playing without the Inns & Cathedrals expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

People complain about how the farmers determine the game, which is probably true. I'd like to try the newer versions of this game which likely help balance it some more.  A good "advanced" game still accessible to novice players, I think.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of the best game designs of the last twenty years. It takes a basic tile placing mechanism, adds color and personality, and links it to a fine scoring system. Indeed, the scoring system is so good that it has spawned several dozen interesting variants. I'm not sure this is the "best" of the Caracassonnes and I play other versions much more frequently, but it is the first one, the groundbreaker, and it deserves a 10 for blazing the path!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
nice non-gamer game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'd bought this game about 3-4 years ago, and we'd played it once in that intervening time (I got stomped, and I wasn't so thrilled about bringing it back out to play).

In 10/2006, I dragged the game out and we (a friend, my wife and I) decided to give it a try again.  I learned two things:  this game is really rather good, and don't annoy my wife.

The game is the classic tile laying game, so it really needs no introduction.  If everyone knows how to play it (and can get past the rules, which constantly change the name of the figures you have and so make it hard at first to understand), the game is rather fun.  Unfortunately, we were a little hazy on the farm part, and so when my friend put down a farmer, my wife got really annoyed that she'd now pretty much lost the game before it started.  In spite of me trying to point out that there were plenty of opportunities to get back in the game, my wife remained annoyed at me until we played a game of Settlers (in which she stomped all over us).

What I've been tempted to do with the rules is to cross out the terms "thief", "farmer", "knight", and "abbot/monk" and replace them with "meeple" to make for easier reading.

Since that day in October 2006, my wife and I have played many times, and now that we have some strategy down, the game is really rather fun.

(EDIT: Aug 22, 2007): We don't get this game out to play that much these days, and when we do, it's usually a fallback filler type of game.  I'm bumping the number down to 6 accordingly.

RATING: 9
Over time I had accidentally allowed the glut of expansions and their subsequent substantial increase in game length to cause me to forget what a great game Carcassonne is.

If you've forgotten, too, use one of the online tile references to strip your collection of all the add-on extra tiles, and enjoy a heated 30 minute 2-player game with the opponent of your choice.

It was like hearing back from an old friend.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
+1 light. easy setup, short teaching time. 
+1 Initially strategy seems extremely shallow, but a little more meta strategy reveals itself with a few of plays. 

-1 Huge amount of random chance. 
-1 lots of my turns involve no meaningful choices or actions ('oh boy, another straight road piece...spare merson? yup... goes here then...')
-.5 what deeper strategy there is only comes with meta knowledge (how many of this tile is there, etc) or random chance
-1 Scoreboard is often meaningless, as final tally can feel almost random ('oh, I  won?') or meaningless if folks are paying attention. 

Takes too long to be a filler-game, but fills time with atable of very new/attention-scarce players. Bores me to tears if played more than once in a blue moon. 

I suspect a few expansions, or min-maxing with some very competitive players might make this a little more enjoyable. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I bought this game since it was recommended as a simple gateway game. I figured it would be east to introduce, especially to people who are new to board games. I didn't expect to like this game as much as I did.

There is a lot of tactical and strategic depth to this game. Thinking about the best place to put a tile, evaluating the chances of being able to finish the mega-city for lots of points, rationing your meeples, cutting off your opponent, maneuvering your position in order to contest features. It's a very fun game - I enjoy it most with 2-3 players but it plays very nicely with more. 

The game is satisfying to play, and offers a lot more fun and depth than I gave it credit for. Now if only Inns and Cathedrals would be restocked... 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Carcassonne was one of those games that sparked my enthusiasm for board gaming. Tile laying, placing meeples and collecting points from finished constructions is easy and rewarding. If you concentrate only in finishing your own castles, roads and monasteries, it can be very kind and non confrontational game. It is possible to play this game also more aggressively so that you try actively outplay your opponent, sabotgae their constructions or steal their victory points with meeple offensive. 
I think it never gets so old that I don`t want to play it at all.

RATING: 8
Carcasonne ist ein zeitloser Klassiker, mit einem Spielprinzip, dass sehr oft versucht wurde zu adaptieren oder zumindest in einem größeren Gesamtkonstrukt zu verwenden. Die Rede ist natürlich davon, Geländeplättchen passend aneinander zu legen, damit so eine stimmige und hübscheLandschaft entsteht, denn das macht man in Carcassonne. Man zieht ein Geländeplättchen, legt es passend an und stellt ggf noch einen seiner Meeple auf das eben gelegte Plättchen - das war´s! siegpunkte gibt esdann für fertig gestellte Städte, Straßen, Klöster und Wiesen. Ein eifnaches, aber tollen Spiel, was bis heute nichts von seinem Charme verloren hat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Along with TTR, Carcassonne introduced me to the world of modern board games.  It's a simple, tile-laying game.  I enjoy playing it from time to time but it can often leave players a little frustrated as you are at the complete mercy of the tile draw.  This leaves next to no room for long term planning.  I would still recommend it, providing you take it for what it is, a high luck, family game.  Good but not great.

Played 5/28/2006 (with "The Princess & The Dragon" and "River 2" expansions, 3 players, 1 hr 42 min);  6/2/2006 (original with initial "River" tiles, 5 players, 48 minutes);  7/3/2006 (with "the Tower" and "The Princess & The Dragon" expansions, 4 players, 1 hr. 30 min.);  11/30/2007 (with "Inns & Cathedrals" expansion, 6 players, 1 hr. 16 min.);  12/21/2007 (3 players, 37 minutes).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
主題:1
我第二款購入的桌遊，套用中古世紀的城堡--卡卡頌，藉由卡卡頌伯爵建設家園的主題來包裝的拼圖遊戲，拼圖遊戲我們都有玩過，但能在拼圖中加入計分規則與遊戲主題帶入感，卡卡頌真的做到了。此外，除了在拼圖外，還融入工人放置的機制，讓整個主題更加完美!(伯爵的手下)，不管是當農夫、當路霸收錢、當傳教士、還是城堡內的騎士，配合地圖的開展，還真有開疆拓土的味道!

美術:0.9
這款美術與農家樂一樣!簡單的線條外加淺色調的彩繪，美術看起來十分有童趣，說真的這一類有強烈主題的歐式遊戲，若改搭美式漫畫風格或寫實風格就真的就格格不入了，我喜歡這一款的美術!至於米寶工人，我不知道起源在那一款遊戲!但我接觸到的桌遊!好像卡卡頌的米寶最具知名度，令人印象深刻!

規則:0.9
抽圖板、擺放圖板(拼圖)、放置工人、換對手，就是這麼簡單的流程，除了要將最後的農夫計分講解清楚外!其他工人的計分方式都十分直覺，教學上也十分容易，除了擴充有一大堆不同規則要消化外，基本上款這遊戲的規則讓遊戲流程十分順暢!

設置:1
這是一款設置容易的遊戲!我喜歡攻城塔的擴充配件，把圖板全部放置攻城塔上，圖板抽完遊戲結束，十分實用的小配件!(尤其是一大堆擴充圖板不知要如何取捨時)

路線:0.4
基本上就是看你抽到板塊的運氣，來選擇要用那種工人取分，得分路線不多(擴充增加部分得分路線，但相對的也給遊戲增加複雜度，造成遊戲規則太多特例影響遊戲流暢度)，有時抽牌運氣不是很好的時候，你會發現你會被卡很久!

互動:0.8
基本上我覺得卡卡頌是兩人遊戲，雖然遊戲可以2-6人(加擴充)但人越多玩家閒置發呆的情形就更明顯，尤其要在一大片拼圖中，找出可以放置手上這片板塊的位置，有時真的要找好久!加上多人遊戲中，大家互相卡來卡去，越多人就越卡，真的變成卡卡不爽的遊戲了!所以我推薦本款兩人玩最佳人數!不過三人局也可以試試，玩起來會更有合眾連橫的政治角力感覺!

個人:0.8
我是很推薦這款遊戲，想等小朋友長大點就教他玩這款遊戲，可以訓練觀察力、也好過單人玩需要大量時間又無代入感的拼圖遊戲!(這句話得罪很多拼圖愛好者)

朋友:0.8
我跟我老婆玩兩人場，老婆說十分有趣，跟同事玩五人場，大家只想草草結束，我想這款還是兩人專用就好!雖然同事並無惡評，但我想大家會更想玩別的。(挑人數開很重要)最近跟5歲的女兒玩兩人局，小朋友愛的反應出乎我意料之外，女兒常說要開卡卡頌，而且要玩不同的擴充。學校桌遊社教學，大部分的小朋友也很喜歡。

想玩:0.8
玩了很多重度策略類型的遊戲，偶爾會想試試這款輕度桌遊，享受你卡我我卡你的樂趣!

收藏:1
擴充很多，每款都替這遊戲帶來不同的變化，說實在的這款遊戲不容易玩膩，我會想好好收藏!

總分:8.4
講評:兩人互卡、三人眾橫、四人等等、五人等等等、六人等等等等等!好遊戲?我會說是經典遊戲!

RATING: 8

For me this is the gateway par excellence.  Pared down to two in its basic version it is quick and confrontational.  Throw in a couple of expansions and it becomes epic.  It can be whatever you want it to be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a really nice tile-laying game. It can be played from 2 to 5 players and is very simple to teach. It also provides a satisfying visual element because you are building the game board together with the opponents.

It can get very chaotic with a higher number of players. I think 3 players is the ideal number for this game, just like in Samurai. Then it's not too chaotic, and not too calculated.

Also, it's worth mentioning there is much luck involved in the tile draws. If you don't get the tile you need it can cost you the game. But since it's a casual fun game I can forgive this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game, great family fun. The innumerable extensions add more and more mechanics, be careful not to play with too many of them, making the game unreadable and unplayable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Another modern classic found in most decent board game collections. Simple tile laying game with minimum set-up. It seems a bit simple at first, but there's actually a good bit of strategy to be had in Carcasonne once it 'clicks'. It's all about the Where and When of where you place your Meeple (Farmers... or something). You're working collaboratively with the other players to build roads, cities, abbeys and farms. But you need to be the one to claim them at the right time. Too early and you might not finish them alone. Too late and another player could shut you out by claiming it first. I think the main negative for Klaus Wrede's Carcassone is the artwork. I read it once described as 'Dusty', and for some reason that word sticks. It's quite uninspiring. Where are the rolling plains? The sprawling metropolises? The awe-inspiring cathedrals? Nope. None of that. It's a long brown line leading up to a town that looks like the digestive that dropped in the bottom of your mug of tea. Sort it out, Klaus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very strategic and easy to teach. Lowered my rating a point for the need to memorize the tiles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is one of the absolute must-get classics. Anyone can learn this one almost instantly and yet it's still quite interesting. I recommend getting the big box version because once you get the base set you'll probably end up buying most of the expansions anyway.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Note de 7.5 (2013) revue à la baisse.

[size=7][i]Farm rules clarified: Work out the majority owner/s of the farm. Only the owner/s of the farm get points for each completed city the farm touches. Do this for every farm.[/i][/size]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Probably the game that really got me into the board gaming hobby. Carcassonne's turn structure is refreshingly simple - pick up a tile, place it, put a follower on it (if you want to), score any completed elements. I love the way that the landscape grows as the game progresses, and in a way this is what brings the game down for me. If I am to play the game to win, and strategize against my opponents, then the beautiful landscape will be tarnished by the unfillable holes that I create to hinder my opponents scoring. The expansions add a lot, and it’s great that you can pick and choose your rules, but unfortunately the game can run a bit long as you add more and more tiles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game, especially for 2 players!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
15+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Carcassonne is an excellent game to introduce to new players becuase it is primarily a visual game and has only a few rules.  It also has some interesting tactical decisions, and it looks great when spread out on the table.  It can handle a large number of people, and plays fairly quickly, which are also good.

Ultimately, though, I find the game uninspiring.  The strategy is offset in many cases by the other players affecting your plays.  Now I realize that this is an important part of the game, but at some point you have so little control that you cannot do any sort of planning.  Carcassonne is a good gateway game, but I wouldn't want to play it with any serious gamers.  There are many better games to play.

RATING: 7.5
Overall comment: simple tile placing game with subtle strategic tactics, domino players may like this game, older players relate well to the play mechanic

Ratings:
Initial: 8 (nice thick pieces with simple but effective graphics)
Family: 7 (wife doesn't mind it, rest have little interest in it)
Game group: 6 (too simple with not enough tough decisions - not requested)
AP: 9 (little down time helps the pace of this game)
Solo play: 8 (#4 SoloPlay currently - plays quick and offers a different kind of challenge than the regular play)

When purchased: 2006
Expansions recommended: yes (need to cautiously review those available - traders/builders adds a different element which varies the game a bit)
Age range: 8+

Reason purchased: Geek analysis (wanted a gateway game for my wife)

Pros: plays quick and interesting to look act.  More fun if played light-heartedly
Cons: not much going on here and newer players have trouble understanding the farmers

Recommendations: Older players grasp the concept of this game quickly and enjoy the low strategy factors.  As far as a bridge game for my wife, it did not happen.  Others also struggled with the fun factor.
Replay rating: Below average
Game value (plays/cost): Marginal (solo play has helped a bit but it is rarely requested.

RATING: 7
The basic activity of constructing the worlds easiest and least interesting freeform jigsaw puzzle is fundamentally fun. The game itself, winning points by plonking meeple, is disconnected and unengaging unless played with the kind of focussed competitivity that would discourage most members of the family groups you can imagine gathering around to play. There's a pleasure deficiency involved in this game that no amount of reskinning or expansion can cure.

RATING: 10
Carcassonne could be called a modern classic.  It's relatively simple, quick to set up, very fun, easy to teach, and easy to play.  It's a game you might come back to over and over for years.  I don't think I'll ever really get sick of it.  It lacks some of the complexity and flair of something like Agricola or Castles of Burgundy, but this is a special game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I don't like giving Carcassonne just a Five. Building the board as you play, and placing your peeps on it feels cool. It is simple, easy to play, and really fun to watch the board expand into a beautifully confusing medieval landscape as you progress. I really do appreciate this game. BUT for me, its just not that exciting to play. I'm a competitive person and when I play, I find myself just placing tiles in a spot where they look the prettiest, not really focusing on winning. It's just not invigorating enough. Once you've placed one of your people on the board, you're kind of just waiting till you get the right pieces so that you can take them off and score points. The only part that can get exciting is the end of game farm warfare. Trying to steal your opponents farms can get pretty intense. It also feels good to magically find the perfect piece you've been waiting for all game. I wonder if the expansions add much spice to this game? Oh and I HATE the river tiles, they always ends up messing with the aesthetics of the board because it will leave holes where you couldn't find a piece with a river, road, and city in it. But the river tiles are a great tool for screwing over your opponent(s). I would be interested to see what rating this game would get if it were released today. All in all, I get a little bored playing this game, but it's still solid and I love that it exists.

RATING: 7
Fairly innovative tile laying game where one reveals a tile, plays it on the table to connect to other tiles, then place a token on a road, farm, castle, or cloister to score points. It's fun, everyone can play from family to Eurogamers. Going the farmer route has not completely won all games. Some decision making involved.

RATING: 6.1
[b]Carcassonne[/b] - base game

A bit light for my taste, more of a family game, but haven't tried any of its numerous expansions and perhaps haven't played with the bloodthirsty crowd that I prefer. Basic version is a good introductory to board games for kids.

I've forgotten - I've actually played this one online at Brettspielwelt.de  WITH  some of the expansions (Traders&Builders, Cathedrals, Princess&Dragon) and it was much much better than the basic game. Quite good for 2, 3, even 4 players. Keep in mind that with each additional player the game will slow down a bit.

Earns a higher rating provided you play with one of the above expansions.

Updated Sep 20, 2014:
Has been fantastically successful with kids age 4&up, despite their love for video games. They love Carcassonne's tile building aspect, and the dragon from the Princess&Dragon expansion is a very exciting addition. You can water down the rules for them and introduce the more difficult nuances later on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The famous game that I really never cared for. I played only 2-3 times with some expansions (river expansions and something else that I don't remember). I thought I would play if I buy the game. So I bought it. I never opened it. I found Die Burg and I liked Die Burg. I only played Die burg. I sold the game unopened. Now I love Die Burg and think about this original Carcassonne. Do I want to play? Not really. 

It is so interesting to find out that these two games (Carcassone and Carcassone - Die Burg) are a lot more different than I thought.

Carcassonne - flip a tile. Find where it is playable. Later flip a tile and hope it is the one that matches the other tile that benefit you.

Die Burg - flip a tile. Now it can be played almost anywhere. Wow. So many decisions. Decisions Decisions....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Like Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne is a good "gateway" game that has very broad appeal, and unlike Settlers, the price is right ;-)  It's good to have a copy of this in your collection to play with non-gamers, but it's no longer one that I pull off the shelf for my own enjoyment (and I feel the same way about SoC).  For absolute beginners, "Metro" is a better tile-laying game than Carcassonne due to its simple and elegant ruleset.

RATING: 10
This is easily my most played and favourite game.

Perhaps the most accessible game I own; people can usually comprehend the rules part way through their first play through.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Note: I play with 3rd ed/HiG rules, not the 1st ed/RGG rules that came with the Big Box. 

Carsossonne is a tile-laying game, allowing you to build roads, cities, or fields, all interconnected. You only scores points by claiming a tile when you play it, using a limited supply of "meeples."

In my experience, Carcassonne is very dependent on who you are playing with. Playing a tile that makes a city or road difficult for your opponents to complete is one thing but this game can turn aggressive with some players. There is aggressive yet still fun, and then aggressive and ugly. 

However, it is by nature a variable game, different each time. And with the right crowd, is lots of fun. 

This game also travels well. Throw the tiles and figures in a couple Zip-lock bags and (with paper/pen to keep score) you are good to go. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Uno de los euro-juegos más clásicos y el primero que tuve en mi colección.
Su simplicidad es francamente genial, se trata de una especie de una especie de híbrido entre un rompecabezas y un dominó moderno: se amontonan al principio del juego, y al azar, todas las piezas con las que se juega, cuadrados de cartón que contienen dibujos de pequeños trozos de un paisaje compuesto de dos o más de los cuatro elementos que conforman el juego (segmentos de ciudades, segmentos de caminos, segmentos de campos o conventos). 
Se coloca una pieza inicial en la mesa y luego, turno tras turno, cada jugador roba una pieza adicional, al azar, del montón y la coloca en la mesa de tal manera que empalme perfectamente con todas las piezas con las que colinde (segmentos de ciudad deben empalmar con segmentos de ciudad, segmentos de camino con segmentos de camino y segmentos de campo con segmento de campo) hasta que las piezas del montón se terminen.
Cuando un jugador coloca una pieza, tiene la posibilidad de colocar a uno de sus seguidores (fichas de madera, cada jugador empieza con 7) sobre alguno de los elementos presentes en ella (camino, ciudad, campo o convento), bajo ciertas reglas, y así reclamar el elemento como propio.
Las reglas definen los mecanismos para definir como se finaliza la construcción de cada elemento y como se obtienen puntos cuando eso suceda y lo más interesante, como lograr que los jugadores invadan territorios de sus oponentes y tomen posesión de ellos.
Es un juego muy divertido, dinámico y fácil de aprender, ideal para jugar con personas no habituadas a euro-juegos o para personas que quieran empezar en este mundo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
When I first saw this game, I instantly knew I was going to like it. Haven't met anyone that doesnt like it yet. Sceptics, yes. But they where quickly turned over.
Very simple game, draw a tile and add it to the ever growing "puzzle" of cities, roads, cloisters, and farms. When one of above mentioned features that is controlled by your followers are completed, you score points.

House rule: Each player starts with two tiles and draws a new one each turn, adding some tactic to the game.

I have a huge set containing 2 Carcassones, Inns & Cathedrals, 2 Traders & Builders, King & Scout, River I & II and the Mini Expansion. Can't actually fit it on a table any more :)
I still feel sad when I realize that a game is about to run out of tiles... :(
Commonly claimed to be a good two player game. I disagree.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Player interaction is so limited that Carcassonne feels almost like a solitaire game. The interaction that does exist is almost entirely with the intention of screwing your opponents over and yet the game remains very relaxing: Draw a tile, play that tile, and maybe put a meeple on it somewhere. A deep, off-topic conversation would disrupt the flow of most other games, Carcassonne is the exact opposite: You can have a deep conversation, forgetting you are playing the game, and when your turn arrives it won't even interrupt your train of thought.

The appeal of the game is actually in watching the layout of the Carcassonne countryside gradually unfold. 

In both gameplay and atmosphere, Carcassonne is this generation's Dominoes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Reference tile laying game every other similar game will compare to.

One of the gateway games of choice, thanks to its simplicity and elegance.

I don't rate it higher because of its lack of depth. You draw one piece and you have to place it, and whether you'll accompany it with a meeple or not. That's the only decisions you'll take (the first one usually is quite evident, the second one not so much).

I increase my 2012-09 7.0 rating to 7.5 -> Not a lot of games are still that compelling after that long.

RATING: 5
Relatively lightweight but still midly satisfying game. It's got much of what it takes for its popularity - very easy to learn, smooth, appealing to the eye, rather short and thus good for several plays in a row -, but the style of play is pretty obvious since the first couple of turns, and with every move affected by the luck of the draw there's not much room for long-term strategy. As a result the game is fun but it leaves only a faint aftertaste.

RATING: 6

RATING: 7

It's enjoyable and satisfying, but I feel lacking in long-term strategical depth. In terms of excitement it doesn't get you really engaged and 'battling' your opponents, or on the edge of your seat to see what card you are dealt next like some games do.

Having said all of that, it's a really good game and concept. I haven't played the expansions but I imagine they add to it.

[i]Great game I originally bought to play with my wife.
She loved it but what surprised me was how much my kids enjoy it as well. This is a great family game, and what is most surprising is that my wife is probably the most cutthroat player closely followed by my son. This game has a very easy to learn rule set but there is a surprising amount of depth for a tile laying game. This really is the game that every family should have.

This is a game we have played with a lot of people who don't typically play or enjoy games. My in-laws played it one night at our house and they bought it the next day![/i]

RATING: 7
This was my gateway game into Euro-style board-gaming. I have always been a gamer, and I had played RoboRally many times, but this is game that started me down the road towards searching for more and varied board game experiences. Something this game has taught me is to be frugal with adding to many expansions to a game (Race for the Galaxy excepted I guess). I have have found that while expansions can spice things up a bit, adding too many additional rules can sometime obscure the core game experience. This is especially true when one of the key appeals of the games is the accessibility.

RATING: 8
A year ago I gave Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers, a mediocre rating, and was not particularly eager to play again.  This, the original game, made a much better first impression on me.  Although I am not very good at games involving acquiring territory in general, this one made more sense to me than the Hunters and Gatherers expansion.  It's not a cooperative game, but it does have some cooperative aspects to it, which I like.  The object of the game is to win, but the competition is more benign, which for me translates to a less stressful, more fun gaming experience.  The components are of very good quality and the artwork is really attractive. (4+4)

RATING: 7
Like "Ticket to Ride," another gateway game, I found "Carcassonne" to be only mildly interesting, and too dry on the whole to continue playing. I also found the 'farmer' rule to be too fiddly and therefore detracted from my enjoyment. 

At the time I had it, my 13-year-old stepson took some interest in playing it, but not overwhelmingly so. On the whole it's okay to play and the board looks beautiful when a game's done. 

I'll also say that when I'm traveling and see people playing this, I feel happy that games like this are becoming better known and enjoyed. 

Like many others, I agree that the farmer rules are very fiddly and easy to simply ignore.

RATING: 9
2009/08/30
I've just over thrown my initial comment about this game. The more I play, the more it grows on me. I always have fun playing this.

Verdict:
Both strategic and tactic. Very good for 2~3 players. I can just have fun and relaxed playing peacefully or go cut-throat and nasty playing competitively; depending on the mood. 
4~5er game can only be seen as a fun & relaxed filler since luck of draw kicks in too heavily.

A good exercise to improve one's observation skill.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
50+ plays. Very elegant in its simplicity. Pick up a tile, play a tile, score if you've completed an element you started earlier, place a meeple on one of the elements you've just placed to potentially score later. The key to its success is the claim now, score later feature - in most tile-laying games you score with the playing of the tile itself. Combine that with offering people different elements to claim on each tile to offer choice, and fast turns to boot, and the game has broad appeal. While it doesn't come out as often as it used to, it's still a quality game I enjoy. This base game is moving closer to filler territory now that everyone can play fast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Some of the variants get a bit carried away, but this game is VERY good.  A must have and a good game to intro people into German style games!

It is a light, easy-going, and enjoyable game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
What I like:
- Portable
- Plays reasonably quickly (4p 60 minutes)

What I don't like:
- I'm not a fan of tile-laying in general
- Can be quite cutthroat
- Requires a form of planning ahead that I'm not good at
- Tile draws are frustratingly random

This is a classic game, and it's a reasonable gateway game with good replayability...if you enjoy it to begin with. My wife found it quite dull, but also hated "stealing" farms. I find it either dull (if you play casually), or brain-burny and cutthroat (if you play seriously).

Rating lowered from 5 to 4 after my 3rd play.

Traders and builders is the best expansion in my opinion and stays as well, the only problem is if you play with both the tower and the princess & dragon expansions... WHAT A MESS!! We keep all the pieces though we just ignore the special tiles from the expansion we don't wanna play with, I just can't help myself, it looks great when all the tiles are on the table...

RATING: 7
Players: 2-5 (Best with 2 or 3) I think Carcassonne is better without expansions. Normal Carcassonne is a good light and short game. Expansions increases the luck factor, game difficulty for newbies, the game is longer and there is not a huge increase on strategy. The only expansion i think is useful is "The count" went you play with a lot of people in the same game. I have played all the expansions i own more than one time but i only note the first one on every expansions (if every time i play Carcassonne i have to note all expansions...)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
As Peter O’Toole said for cricket in “What’s new Pussycat”:
 "It doesn't involve anxieties or pressures. It's leisurely and lyrical. It's the song of willow on leather."

I bought it in order to play with my family and my wife as a couple.

My mother (can't manage complicated games) loved it. (actually the farm rule really messed with her mind, I am thinking of not using farmers when playing with her)
My brother (more of a gamer, but get's easily bored) doesn't care for it but will play it if I ask him. I personally love it, but it doesn't seem to go very well with everyone else. I guess it feels a bit dated to them.

I think playing with three players makes the game a lot more interesting.

I can explain the rules to anyone within five minutes.

Love to see the town forming from zero. 
Love the wooden followers. 
Eager to use all the expansions but i don't want to spoil the exhitment too early!

Conserning the gameplay maybe the farms are a bit more powerful than they should have.

I keep tidy in the main box in very classy homemade tuck boxes the following expansions:
Inns & Cathedrals
Traders & Builders
The Princess & the Dragon 
The Tower
Abbey & Mayor 
Count, King & Robber 
The Phantom 
Hills & Sheep 

(Wife's Point of View: Me and my wife spend a lot of our time indoors and I bought it mainly for playing with her. To my surprise she doesnt' like it at all. Major disappontment. I thought that Carcassonne will be a hit because it's the opposite of frustrating. I think she finds it really boring.

...I still remember the cashier when I bought the game. He asked me why I was buying it and when I told him that I want it as a 2-player for me and my wife he went. "Oh it's perfect for that". Who could have guessed)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although I haven’t logged many games of this on BGG I think it is actually my most played game, probably close to 100 plays. Most of these plays were with the Inns and Cathedrals expansion, which I think is essential and should have come in the base game. My sheer number of plays reflects the greatness of this game (and the short play time), and it was really interesting to see the change in play style as we it more and more. It went from the two of us almost ignoring each other and trying to score as efficiently as possible with the tiles we drew to screwing each other over at every opportunity! To the point where drawing a cathedral tile would be more useful as way to scupper your opponents plans than it would be to score extra points on your own cities. The farms also become super competitive so finding creative ways to engineer a way to sneak just one more meeple into a big juicy farm became a staple part of the game.

My overall rating of this has only dropped due to the sheer amount of plays I’ve had and that I am gravitating towards more complex games these days. I would still play this two player, if ever given the chance.

RATING: 7.5
One of my favorite filler and gateway games.  Easy to teach and there are easy objectives for new players.  With experienced players the field points can get nasty, but that's not a bad thing.  I have only played this one once without the river expansion.  I would suggest always playing with it.  This game is great when you have three players.  Four works as well and since the game is limited by the number of tiles, it doesn't really increase the game length.  Five is okay, but I would suggest getting additional expansion tiles to give everyone more plays if you're going to do five.

RATING: 6
Not really sure why this game has become iconic of eurogames, as the luck factor really dominates the game.  The tile laying is fun, but often frustrating because you can't get the tile you need.  It's impossible to plan in this game, and the farmer scoring is too unintuitive.

(5+ plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is the classic medium weighter, with a good playing time (less than 1 hour) and enjoyable by a range of types. Probably my most played game, as it is very easy for new people to pick up and tactically interesting enough for most experienced gamers to enjoy as well. The gameplay mechanic is clever and simple, with players facing a wide range of choices but requiring little forward planning. While some people may see the simplicity as a drawback, I find it makes Carcassonne the perfect game for anything from a relaxed afternoon with non-gamers to an intense evening of geeky games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

OK gateway game; not my favorite;  I think it has to do with the large amounts of luck;

Bring it out when I have small groups, or non-gamer friends mostly. Have played it solitare and tried to beat my previous score (written on back of box).

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
One of the best gateway games out there. The base game is pretty simple, easy to learn rules and excellent to introduce to non-gamers, as well. However, it's not simplistic, as it offers a great depth; Carcassonne is pretty much a concealed wargame, wrapped around a eurogame box with high-quality wooden components. The numerous expansions add various flavors and let you customize your game: do you want a peaceful game, a random fun game with the catapult, or a wargame with dragon? I definitely recommend it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
My appreciation for this game has gone up and down, very first times to try this game did not spark the interest too much (and it was well before playing Settlers of Catan - the game that really got me hooked). After getting more into board gaming I started to play Carcassonne again and few first times were good. Then again it felt boring after 10 or so plays, especially as some of the games were with 5 players (not recommended at all). Then I discovered how competitevly this can be played and especially with 2 players. And now I think it is a very good game for 2-3 players with really great replay value - every game evolves differently. Traders & Builders Expansion also sparked new life into this game and is now the preferred way to play the game for me (base Carcassonne + T&B)

RATING: 8.132
I owned Carcassonne several years ago. It was played a bit, but I never got into it. I lost the game while I was in the Army and I really did not have the desire to replace it. 

Recently I have been gaming quite a bit more though and one of the things that we have been looking for are good language independent games. We picked up the Carcassonne Big box because it just seemed like a good fit.

I have not been dissapointed. The game fits the bill for what we need. It has been enjoyable and I am looking forward to trying out some of the expansions.

Update: Added a few of the expansions in last night and suprisingly enjoyed the result. This game is getting played a lot due to the language independence and the ease of setup. I am glad I am trying this again.

RATING: 8
Update:  This will always be a good game to introduce to new gamers, but I don't seem to reach for it too often otherwise.

Update:  We did finally play the uber-game with all the expansions at once, it was huge and took over 2 hours!

This was our first real 'Geek Game' that I found via BGG.  There's a very good reason that it's so highly considered.  This is just a terrific classic that is accessible yet always challenging.  There are too many permutations to get jaded with it.  We liked the base game so much, that after one week with it, we ordered the "Big Box II" so that we could have all the best expansions and we passed the base game along to my in-laws.  We've never played all the expansions at once, and yet, it's fun to try to pick ones that will work well together.  This is one we will keep coming back to time and time again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
(01/08) It is a classic for a reason. It continues to engage with people I play it with. It usually gets to be played more than once in one sitting, even without any expansions games tend to vary a lot from game to game. It can accomodate experienced players and new players.

It is as simple as pick a tile, place a tile and decide if you want to put a meeple on it to try and get points according to the tile you placed it into, yet it can generate really interesting interactions and risky moves that can almost become a meta-narrative on the game. (A player built a castle that just keep on growing, will he be able to close it before the game ends?)

Quick, fun, simple. It has influenced other games to use this mecanism as part of a bigger machine (Isle of Skye, for example)

RATING: 10
(25+ plays)
This is a great family game.  Place tiles to match other tiles like building a big puzzle and put meeples (little wooden people) on them to score points.  Always a winner if you don't spring too many expansions on new players.

As a family game, I can recommend the Inns & Cathedrals Expansion, and the Traders & Builders Expansion.  They are totally worth it.  I wouldn't bother with any of the other 10 expansions unless you're a game geek playing with game geeks - or your family really plays this game A LOT.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

Great game. Not too complicated, easy to understand and the rules are very easy to explain to other players, even to those who are new to board games. All this makes the game perfect family game, allowing people to play it and chat the same time. 

Ideal for those who does not appreciate brain consuming games played in total or almost total silence. Wide (not to say enormous) amount of extensions gives variety of play where you can control the impact of the randomness of the game (from medium to large).
The amount of extensions and randomness makes it very re-playable for such a easy game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We play this a LOT. It's a near perfect level of strategy for winding down after work. We play it with the river expansion which greatly accelerates the initial part of the game which can be slow when you start from a single tile as in the base-set. The river expansion should just be considered an essential part of the base game as it perfectly solves the one downfall of the base set which is the slow start.

But the river is the only expansion we use. I've found some of them fun - but some, like the Tower, radically alter the nature of the game (turns it into a mean-spirited "gotcha" game) Trying to stuff too much into a beautifully crafted smooth-as-silk-playing light strategy game sort of defeats the point. Carcassone, Patchwork, Morels, Tramhahn, Splendor, these are so perfect in balance and weight and fun. I can't see trying to bulk-up Carcassone into a midweight game. It isn't - and that's part of its charm. It's a near perfect lightweight strategy 2p game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Carcassonne is an okay game. In my mind, it works best as a gateway game, but it seems a little lacking for seasoned gamers. However, I have never played with any of then expansions. 
I enjoy how the map comes together, and like how you can interfere with your opponents' plans.

RATING: 6
I'm a bit shocked this is rated so highly, and how in love with it some of my friends are.  Still...I find it a pretty enjoyable game, though I'm a bit worn on it now.  It's difficult to overcome an early, powerful farmer.  What troubles me about this one is that I know HOW to overcome such a farmer, but the difficulty is immense, and I always lose out to someone who's been lucky.  But when you CAN overcome it, victory is satisfying. I won't play this with more than 3 and I don't like the river any more.  Players can also take a little too long to place a piece.  For me, the game is too light for it to be enjoyable with more than 10 seconds of AP.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What else can you say about Carcassonne? One of the most simple boardgames out there. It's like a collective jigsaw puzzle activity but with the crucial addition that each player claims parts of the puzzle being constructed. 

So you get both the sense that your are building this great map with everyone else at the table while also strategically placing the tiles and meeples to get the maximum benefit for yourself and, if possible, mess with other players too.

Quick, addictive - and great!

RATING: 9.8

RATING: 6
Countless words have been said on this game, but I'll add some of my own.  First, my rating represents my desire to play, but this game is a must-play-once kind of game. I bought it, played it with my girlfriend's sister, whose husband then bought a copy, who now plays with another group guys, etc.  The reason?  Its a great game.  My only hangup revolves around the 'farmers' - too many people get confused on how they score up.


When do I play this?:
This one is for the noobs.  For fun, see how they pronounce the game. Hah!

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
Finally got around to getting/playing this game and I can only say that it is absolutely wonderful. Watching the countryside take shape and adjusting strategy and approach as it does is mesmerizing for me, like a fluid jigsaw puzzle where the outcome is created as you go. Only have the base game as of yet, but I can see where I'll want to add expansions quite soon. Easy to learn, but with many different approaches available for strategy, and the right sprinkling of luck of the draw, this is a keeper for me and my family. Truly deserves to be called a classic.

Update: after over 40 plays and the addition of Inns and Cathedrals, this has become one a favorite. We always play with the expansion now and it managed to make a great game better. My daughter and I play this whenever we get the opportunity now and I simply can't get enough. Great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Personally, I find this game shares the same syndrome as Lost Cities in that the game play is enjoyable, but determining player status requires maths gymnastics and the climax of scoring is an overlong, dull chore.  My other experience niggles are that: A) the pace of the game tends to become inverse (from quick to slow) as the options to place a tile increases (a limiting border as in TaYu/Entdecker would help), neither does playing with more than two players or the original rule of picking a tile at the start of your turn speed up pace. B) to help in making an informed decision you have to speculate on the remaining distribution of tile types and configurations which isn't uniform and so difficult to commit to memory.But these objections contradict the popular experience of the game. What's the universal appeal? I guess it is the several mini scoring advancements and the satisfaction of completing a desired castle, road etc to get a scoring opportunity back. The other elements could be the creative expression and continually different designs the plays make. Could the greeness of the board be pleasantly calming?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have been playing the basic set with no expansions for 
well over a year now and I'm still enjoying Carcassonne. 
There is a lot of strategy involved which operates
on a very simple level, satisfyingly nuanced without
need for a complicated rules system. 

The game is watertight, I would not make any changes to the 
core rules at all. It's a great pick up and play game that
has really nice wooden pieces that don't intimidate my non gamer friends and you can finish a game in 20 minutes, perfect.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Comment:[/b] This is the classic game of tile laying where you create an entire landscape. This game more than any other taught me more expansions does not a better game make. In fact, this is easily expanded beyond playability. If you are an expansion-aholic like me, keep track of how many tiles the base game has, and incorporate no more expansions at one time than would double the basic game length. This game also has lots of downtime between turns. I love it as a classic, but with Carcassonne South Seas and Carcassonne The City, I wouldn't recommend this game at this point.

If you are interested in it, keep the expansions to the following and you'll do fine:

[thing=2993][/thing]
[thing=5405][/thing]
[thing=2591][/thing]
[thing=26615][/thing]
[thing=66646][/thing] (bridges only)
[thing=31784][/thing] (abbeys only)

:star: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:star: Good with min or max players
:nostar: Low time between turns
:star: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::star::nostar: Enjoyment

Highly recommended and always up for a game.

RATING: 7
While the tile draw is totally random, there are lots of decisions on what you can do with that tile. Go for points with a city, road, or farmer? Try to block or limit points on one of your opponents? Negotiate some kind of deal to help you in the future? 

While there are better games of this type, the simplicity of the play and visual appeal make the game more accessible to more people so I get to have fun with people that won't play some of my

RATING: 5.5
A tile laying game combining plenty of 'luck of the draw' with strategic token (meeple) placement. The scoring mechanism isn't intuitive (especially the farmers feeding the castles). If you don't know how the points are scored, you will always walk away from the game somewhat disappointed and feeling a bit cheated. Too light to warrant careful recollection of the fiddly scoring rules.

RATING: 6.5
6.5 - I generally did not enjoy playing this game but it haunted my memories years and years later with questions about would I still hate it?  I decided to give it a second chance and so went out and purchased a new copy thinking that my tastes may have mellowed a bit.  When I first played this game I was barely into the board gaming hobby and I didn't like all the points and didn't like that it was just flipping tiles over.  Now that I have a better understanding of the mechanics I see a deeper strategy, blocking some areas while being a total sneak and jumping into someone else's town through clever placements.  Learning the tile pools helps a great deal as well so you aren't blindly hoping that a tile that doesn't exist comes up.  The game is definitely more fun and I occasionally feel an itch to play so I think it will be sticking around this time.

1 start tile

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My gateway game. A timeless classic. It will always hold a special place in my heart as the game that got me into board games. It's relatively simple and easy to play. The farm scoring and the "stealing in" mechanic takes a while to explain. After the game is over, there is an overwhelming sense of accomplishment after creating such a picturesque landscape. However, this game can be a bit too cutthroat. You can definitely hate-draft and make an opponent's structure almost impossible to complete, which is annoying and frustrating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne is a classic Euro game of tile laying, meeple placing (and is in fact the original source of the word, which of course is a portmanteau of "my people"). You place tiles, claim regions (in the most basic game, roads, cities, and monasteries). Closing off regions score them, roads can be shared in ties, cities are not, and cloisters score for being surrounded, and it's all very straightforward. 

I'd only played this game once before, with a copy I'd bought when I was in Germany, and that was before I really delved into Hobby gaming. I can understand why this game has a dozens of variants, expansions, mods, and other ephemera, and at the same time I can grasp why this game has a sorta odd place in the hobby games canon. It's fairly light, fairly strategic, super low conflict, and just right to bring people into the fold.

RATING: N/A
This is a good game, but NOT a good introductory game. It's a bit abstract, you have to think several turns ahead to be successful, and making early mistakes can ruin your chances. This one's better to play with players who have some higher-level board game skills. For beginners, Ticket to Ride is better in every way.

Tentative rating: 6/10 more plays needed.

RATING: 8
A classic.  Who does not like Carcassonne.  It is fun building the country and trying to horn in on someones city or farm.  My one complaint is that each player should get an equal number of turns.  We have this as a house rule and any additional tiles are removed.  If one player gets an extra turn that can be just enough to win over a player with one less turn.

RATING: 7.5
Everybody loves it. Fun, light-herted, easy to learn and play. It's not as luck dependant as most people tend to depict it, and good tactical playing (aggresive playing, counting tiles, blocking others) will go a long way towards winning the game. Great game for 2 players. My wife loves it. My family loves it. Come to think of it, I love it too!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A lot of people started with Settlers of Catan, but I started with Carcassonne after reading about it on a friend's blog. After reading him gush about this game that had no board that he and his wife were playing together, I was intrigued. That was October of 2009, which was my entry to this whole world of modern games. 

As for the actual gameplay: I think this game scales well in a number of ways. It plays well 2p all the way to 4p, and it also plays well whether you want to play cutthroat or casually. You can modify it by having a hand of tiles, if you want, but we've played it where you draw a tile at the end of your turn so you can think about your move. 

Regardless, it's satisfying to grow a countryside, and the use of meeples is a great (and light) way to balance Now against Later. It's a very clever game, even this far after its release date. There really is something special about Carcassonne. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Sólo puedo decir que es un juego muy bonito y que es muy fácil que salga a mesa tanto como filler para jugones como juego de iniciación a no jugones.

Fácil de aprender, barato... Su único defecto es que acabas por aprenderte las fichas y puedes acabar jugando "de memoria". Para evitar esto en las partidas, recomiendo quitar al principio de la partida 2 fichas por jugador boca-abajo para reducir el "factor me sé las fichas que faltan."

Mejor si se acompaña con alguna expansión.

RATING: 9
Two points:
1) This is a fantastic game
2) Its not very deep
This is the kind of game that you can break out for a evening with non-gamers and expect that everyone will have fun. The rules are very simple to learn, and it plays very quickly (45 minutes for a 4 player game). Be warned that there is a lot of luck involved in this game because the main play mechanic is to randomly draw tiles from a pile. However, there is also a lot of strategy involved in how to place them.

RATING: 9

When I was packing for the Peace Corps this was the only game I brought with me, and thank god I did - the children at my center learned it easily (despite the language disparity) and they just loved it. I'm fairly confident that Carcassonne has strong potential for both educational and therapeutic application, as well as being an excellent way to pass the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Is Carcassonne a bland co-op or cut throat jigsaw puzzle?  That, my friends, is up to you.

Carcassonne is simple.  A bunch of tiles show parts of cities and roads surrounded by green fields and containing the occasional abbey.  The components are quite lovely.

On their turn a player draws a tile and places it, puzzle like, next to a previously played tile.  Roads and Cities spill over onto multiple tiles and as the game progresses.  After placing a tile a player can place a meeple (the rules call them "followers") on any structure in that tile.  If that tile, however, expands a pre-existing structure, a road for example, that already has a meeple on it, then no new meeple can be played on that structure.

When a tile completes a structure, ending a road for example, any meeples on it are removed from the board and the owning players score points based on the size of the structure.  The game ends when all the tiles are drawn at which time end game points are awarded and the person with the most points wins.

Now the rules state that on a turn a player is supposed to draw a tile and discuss with the other players how best to play it.  Two words: BO RING.

Here's how you should play Carcassone: 

First draw your tile at the end of your turn so you can think about where to play when your next turn begins.  

Second, it's possible for cities, roads and fields with meeples already on them to grow together.  If they do, the player or players with the most meeples on the structure get the points.  Yes, you can steal points from other players this way!

Third, unless a structure gets completed a player can't get their meeples back.  They are stuck on the board.  Clever tile play can lock up other players meeples and reduce their scoring opportunities.

On one hand Carcassonne provides many of the fun puzzle solving elements that one can find in jigsaw puzzles.  But it can also be played in a competitive fashion.  These two elements combined make it one of the best family games out there.  It's simple to play, fast and full of interaction.

I've heard complaints on BGG about down time issues in multiplayer games.  I've never experienced such a problem, presumably because we always play such that a player draws a new tile at the end of their turn rather than at the beginning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This was one of my first "modern" games, back when I played it in the early two thousands. A great tile laying game, with a luck factor yet plenty of strategic options and possibilities for dirtbaggery. 
I love it when a plan comes together in this game. Especially if it happens in the final turns. Still it can be rewarding to see an opponent make a great move and rake up the points.
The building your board concept also factors into the equasion for me. 

Played this mostly with two and I would like to see how it scales.

RATING: 4
Note that I don’t particularly care for tile-laying games that involve edge matching. I really thought Dad would like this game; he doesn't care for it at all. Is it because of the farmers? Or is it because my dad doesn't have the patience to look all over the playing area to find an appropriate place to play his tile? This game is mostly all about short-term strategies; you’re building little things, accumulating points here and there. I’d rather build something larger – the farmers’ rule is close to what I mean, but the difficulty to attack those farmers that your opponents control doesn’t make this part of the game dynamic enough.

RATING: 8
O primeiro jogo moderno que joguei, lá por 2003. Era um viciado em War, e foi bacana conhecer algo "diferente".

Por causa dessa memória afetiva, sempre será um jogo bacana para mim. Gosto de leva-lo a mesa sempre que posso e principalmente para iniciantes no hobby, e família.

Gosto da imprevisibilidade do jogo, e das disputas pelas grandes cidades, pela melhor aposta nas fazendas, etc. Certamente há muita coisa melhor para se jogar, mas esse pra mim é um dos pilares dos boards, e que estará por aí durante muitos e muitos anos.

RATING: 6
This game isn't nearly as good as I expected from the hype.  If you or your opponent/s don't understand how to steal points away or to prevent point scoring, the game becomes just a very simple game of placing your drawn tile where it fits.  I've yet to lose a game of carcassonne simple because no one I've played has caught on to the deeper strategies involved in scoring.  Kids love it though.  The expansion does help to make it more interesting and balanced. Update:  After a year of playing other great games, this just doesn't seem to compare.  There is so much luck involved that it isn't fun.  I bought the Traders and Builders expansion to hopefully make the game less luck dependent but it makes the game much more difficult to teach.  I'll pass and play something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a quick, simple, and yet challenging game.  I found newcomers were able to pick it up quickly and it's fast enough that you can play a few times in a row to get the hang of it.  I bought it for a friend who occasionally plays board games with us and her and her boyfriend absolutely love playing it.

There are always pivotal decisions to be made over where and when to place workers and turns generally move quickly.  You always feel like you are in control of you play and you won't find yourself waiting long  for your next turn.

The random tile draw can make developing a strategy difficult, but by counting tiles, you can usually make some informed bets on whether or not a strategy will work. It can be frustrating when it doesn't work out, but the tension of finding out is half the fun of the game.

Despite this, it's a lot of fun to build up the map and there are enough big payoffs throughout to make you feel that you've played successfully.  It's a good, quick game that newbies will take to with ease.  It's great to play as a time-filler when waiting for somebody to show up or when you don't have a lot of time for a longer game.

However, there are a couple places where the game can really slow down.  Figuring out what fields are attached and who owns them can interfere with placing workers.  Also, the points often aren't clear until the end of the game, at which point it can take several minutes to add up the score while everybody else waits.  It does make for a suddenly slow ending to an otherwise fast-paced game.

I recommend this as a game for younger kids, for playing with new gamers, and for a quick game when deeper games just aren't appropriate.  If you prefer more strategy, you may find this game gets old after a while, but it's simple enough to explain and get the hang of for new comers to quickly take to it and the game offers plenty of depth to keep strategists entertained.

Over a year since getting this, several of my friends now have their own copies. I've also introduced many non-gamers to it and they absolutely loved it. This is a great gateway game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My favorite thing about Carcassonne is that you can step back after you are done and marvel at your beautiful map with the feel that you've built something.  I hate it though, when you've got something you've been working towards for a large part of the game that gets thwarted because you didn't draw the right tile.  I know there are many people who would say that seasoned Carcassonne players never get themselves into that situation, but I am not that good and will probably never be that good.  I don't enjoy Carcassonne enough to get that good.

RATING: 7
I read a lot of comments from people talking about how great this is 2 player, but I think it really shines 3 player.  I like the dynamic and interplay that is there with three, choosing who to screw over, banding a big castle together only benefiting two of the players, etc.  I think in the two player game it's too easy to do what you want and to cancel moves out.  The third player not only adds another force to be reckoned with, but adds another person drawing tiles into the mix, therefor diluting the number that you will draw.  It does this while not diluting it so much that the game feels out of your control, which I htink starts to happen with 4 players.

RATING: 7.5
I know of no other game that is as open to both casual and serious gamers as Carcassonne. It is deceptively simple. The game is amazingly open to expansion and only after about a half dozen expansions does the game start to feel too busy. Basically, you can customize Carcassonne to fit your groups play style. Turns flow smoothly. Scoring is easy. Did I mention it's fun?

Update:
After many years of Carcassonne, I still think it a great gateway game, but I have almost entirely moved on. A few of the MANY expansions were a big pass for me.

RATING: 10
My favorite game when played with Inns and Cathedrals, Traders and Builders and a house rule with the Robber only: the Robber is awarded to the person who OWNS (NOT COMPLETES) the longest road, which entitles him/'her to one point for every completed road, usually 15-20.  This increases the value of the road pieces you pull, and provides perfect balance to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Description: Tile laying, city building, territory building, area control, light family game with meeples and medieval French castles theme.
Weight: Light.
Number of players: 2 to 6. Best with 4.
Designer: Rudolf Ross, Klaus-Jürgen Wrede.
Publisher: Z-Man Games.

Impression: Classic tile placement family game that I am very fond of. It also popularized the meeples, which is now official Oxford dictionary word. So far I only played basic game, and few expansions not included in this Big Box, like the Tower, and I can't wait to try it out with the rest of it.

Likes: Tile placement mechanic. Easy to learn and play. Various viable strategies. Scoring tiles which gives you back your meeples. Admiring the kingdom you built together in the end.

Dislikes: Bookkeeping and exhausting scoring in the end. Unfair randomness of tile distribution (easily overcome with the house rule). Some expansions bloating the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Have only played this with 2 players, and it works surprising well! Plenty of strategy, tactics and decisions, compressed into a short and simple game. Plus, the visual effect is very stunning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
There are dozens of tile laying games I'd rather play.  I don't like games where people interfere with what I'm trying to accomplish.  Or sweep in at the last moment and steal the route, etc.  Pass.

RATING: 8
Like most people, just love it.  Here's our House Rule that I recommend:  HOLD one tile in hand, so that at beginning of turn you are drawing a 2nd into your hand.   This helps diminish the Luck by just a little, and it gives you something to do during other people's turns (looking at the board to figure where your in-hand tile could be placed).  Always fun and challenging.

RATING: 8
Carcassonne was one of the first games I ever bought. The game is easy to learn but is complex enough that you won't get tired of it. It is one of those games where you can become a real a$$ by trying to steal other's cities and all. I recommand that game for someone who is new to board gaming but also, to experienced players who wants to have a nice time with a game that isn't too long nor too complex but is still very enjoyable. When you get used to it, go and buy some extensions, they will expand the gameplay experience even more.

RATING: 7
I used to play a lot of Yugioh at my local games store (Mind Games Albury) every Friday night. Sometimes we'd get bored of Yugioh though and so we'd play a store copy of a board game. That's how I came across Carcassonne.

I don't play the game much byitself anymore (I almost always play it with the Princess and Dragon expansion which I LOVE!), but I have fond memories of flipping over cloister after cloister, much to the annoyance of my opponents :D I also love getting the 4 sided city piece, placing it in an opponents city to make it virtually impossible to finish!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Players: 2-5
Time: 60-75 min.

Tile placement game. Players randomly draw tiles and must match them to the currently played tiles to recreate the region of Carcassonne. In doing so, players build roads, cities, farms and cloisters. Players can claim such constructions as theirs and score points when the road, city, or cloister is completed. Farmers score at the end of the game for each city to which they supply food. Always an enjoyable game.

RATING: 9.2
It has been a terrific game for my wife and me to start getting into "real" games.  We realize it's not a particular "heavyweight" game compared to a lot of others, but coming on the heels of Ticket to Ride it's been keep the gaming momentum going.  Defintely my wife's favorite game to play (along with the Inns and Cathedrals expansion).

Update (Feb. '09): It was the second "real" game we bought.  But now (with 75 or so games) we really don't play it but once every few months.  Still fun.  Haven't been able to get many kids in my h.s. boardgaming club into it.  Thought I might.

Update (May '09): down from 9 to 8.

Update (July 2013): Over the winter, Carcassonne was a complete shocker in my first ever Top 200 Games List. It grabbed the #12 spot even though I hadn't played it in many, many months and pretty much only play it with my wife. So I moved the rating up to a 9.5. And now my wife and I are playing it a good bit over the summer.

RATING: N/A
An excellent tile-laying game and, with its affordable price point, it's an easy one to recommend to friends who are just being introduced to Designer Games. I have a number of the expansions and my only frustration is that each one adds to the length of the game, making it drag on a little too long. Scoring can also be a lengthy process, with farmers often being difficult to explain to newcomers.

RATING: 8
A simple and subtle game with enough luck in to ensure that the most experienced player does not always win but enough scope to have a really good tactical game. Plays really well on www.brettspielwelt.de. I recommend anyone who likes this game and needs partners to go play on there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was one of the first Euro games I ever bought. I had a hard time getting my wife interested, but my buddies and I enjoyed it quite a bit. I like the "screw your neighbor" aspect of edging in on other peoples' cities or cutting off their farmers. I haven't purchased any expansions, but I might in the future. There's a bit of luck in the tile draw, but it doesn't usually outweigh strategy. Scoring is kind of a pain and definitely contributed to some people I played with not becoming interested.

UPDATE: My 7 year old daughter loves this game! We play without farmers, but it's still fun. I'm bumping up to an 8 due to her liking it so much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was our gateway game and it still remains high on our playlist. We prefer the basic game plus the River expansion (helps make farm scoring more strategic). Other "bigger" expansions can change the game too much by adding luck/random/aggressive components. Inns & Cathedrals does the best job of maintaining the basic game while adding more strategy. Traders and builders is another that enhances the basic mechanics. Carcassonne scales pretty well 2-4 with 2 being a bit more cut-throat and 3 being the "sweet spot". 5-6 becomes slower and more random. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 6
I like Carcassonne. It can be a little frustrating at times, with tiles not going your way, but it's a relatively simple idea for a game with a bit of strategy going along with it. 

The major issue I might have is that there's not much to do between turns. As your entire turn involved drawing the top tile from the pile, figuring out where to place it and then putting it down, then placing a meeple somewhere on that square - there's really not much to do outside of your turn. You can't really plan ahead in this one.

So while it can be fun, it's just a once in a while type game for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

CONS: some moves can severely handicap other players

RATING: 7
Nice game with simple rules where you have that Euro thing that you compete by trying to be more efficient than everyone else but with a bit of "in your face" component since you can steal or join other players features (cities, farms, etc). These "steals" are not necessarily zero sum if you are playing multiplayer which adds a very interesting layer to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For such a simple game, carcassonne has a nice balance of cooperation/competition, 
conservative/aggressive use of resources (meeples), attack and defense, utilizing different functions of each tile's features.  As a result, even though the game is about taking and putting down a single tile and a single wooden piece each turn, it's got a lot to think about.  All this would probably induce analysis paralysis if it weren't for the fact that you get to show your situation to your opponents, who then can offer 'helpful' suggestions (sometimes really helpful if they're nice, sometimes some sort of 'let's help each-other' kind of move).  This makes the game a bit social.  Not as social as a trading game like Settlers of Catan, but nice, tea-time manners, social.  I personally like rowdier games or more thought-provoking games, but still i enjoy it when i'm in the right mood--a bit sedate and polite, like with a church group or something.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
NL

OMSCHRIJVING: Licht tactisch area-control tegel-aanleg-spel met een behoorlijke gelukscomponent. De spelers trekken om beurt blindelings een landschapstegel en passen deze aan aan het landschap dat zich op tafel vormt tijdens het spel. Met hun onderdanen trachten ze steden, wegen, kloosters en weiden onder hun controle te houden.

--> 2 tot 5 spelers

RATING: 10
~~lot of 3&4pl games with base set~

i was less than enamoured with carc h&g when i tried it but something just clicked for the good when i tried this one - we always play with 2 tiles in hand - which is a MUST imho ). Yeah sure the farmer's are intuitive but there's just a very nice feel to the game. plays well with NGs and gamers alike.

 have tried some of the expansions -jury's still out on these but i dont think ANY are in fact necessary inc inns and cathedrals. i do plan to get two base sets and combine them just to have more tiles tho

i never thought i'd say it but this a MUST-HAVE for any collection and a great gift idea for anyone at all really

edit - recently played with 6 players (3 game noobies) using 2 full base sets and had a blast :)

edit - played over new years with 8 ppl and 3 base sets and STILL grt fun! everyone i showed this too loved it and everyone watching wanted to play or buy it. 

this game should be THE game EVERYONE plays

NOTE - it prob is more luck than skill but is so much fun i forgive it this and besides it mean noobies have a chance of winning so it keeps them coming back for more :)

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne remains one of my favorite games. Yes, it is a fairly light game with a fair amount of luck in it, but the fun really comes from the group you play with. The players make this game SOOO much fun! Also, I have not yet run into a person who doesn't like Carcassonne, which also just adds to how great a game this is.

The expasions really add to this game. They give it more variability and replay value. Also, if you want a more strategic game for instance you can use specific expansions to do that. Or if you want a game of Carc with lots of confrontation, or maybe one without much of any confrontation. Due to all the expasions for it, Carcassonne easily beats any of the other Carc games in my opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My rating is based on the following conditions:

1. Play with a hand of 3 tiles.
2. Includes several expansions, especially Inns and Cathedrals.
3. Has 2 or 3 players (no more).

We are pretty evenly matched so the game play is tense right up to the finish, and that is what we all want in a game.

It really is the best game for introducing new people to our hobby (sorry TTR and Settles) based on the 100+ people I have taught this to.

If you are thinking of buying this I would buy one of the "Big Box" versions, it saves you some money and you will want the expansions anyway.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Kathy

Humans are not so good at that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My relations with Carcassonne are of love-hate type that averages on mediocre. First it was Ok, but got boring very quickly. Then after a long break I tried it again with my wife and surprisingly liked it. We played it more and it quickly flipped to other extreme.
Now I don't mind playing it and appreciate simplicity and (even today!) freshnest of game mechanics, it's cute look and zen-ness, but eventually it's too random and lacks enough interesting decisions for my taste.
Carcassonne highly customizable with expansions (and this box has ones of the best), you can always find something more to your liking, but they detract from purity of base game and don't change it's feel that much anyway.
I'm still keeping it though. If anything it still is a classic.
* * * UPDATE 30/01/17 * * *
My feelings had another turn. Throwing in all expansions I own, though totally crazy, brought game to another level. If you have a few expansions mixed in, the game is dominated by that expansion-specific mechanics. But you have a lot in the mix, their impact spreads thinner and often competes with another expansion, creating tension and harmony. You want to build bigger cities and roads to get King/Robber, but now there is threat of towers and dragon, so what do you do? The towers are diluted by other expansions and are not ever-present threat, and if you do get knocked out, you still have an option to take it back with Count's help. And so on. The game becomes epic. So does play time, setup and takedown, but so far it's my favourite way to play and elevates game to 7/10.
* * * UPDATE 2/04/17 * * *
Vanilla Carcassonne grew on me a little. It's not a good game, but it's an enjoyable experience. And at least it plays fast, Carcassonne with all expansions is way too time consuming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I prefer the Hunters and Gatherers version as it fixes a few minor issues with the base game. However, this is still a great game to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.55
A clever tile laying game where you take turns building the ancient town of Carcassonne in France. Different tile alignments allow you to score a little or a lot of points. How you place the tiles can really help you or really stifle your opponent. The rules are simple but they supply a surprising amount of strategy and depth to the gameplay. Very enjoyable and engaging. One of the automatics for any game collection.

RATING: 5
fast tile laying  game where you lay tile to extend roads, farms, cities or churches. The key to the game is to use your workers and tile placement to get the most points.

Pros: Short game length, appeals to wide variety of people, still  fairly strategic given the game length

Cons: can include luck aspect, can introduce alpha gamer mentality in certain groups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game to play with anyone who is new to gaming, including the significant other. Simple rules but I think pretty deep gameplay. You can play it lightly and have fun, or you can play it much more competitively and plan long term and have a satisfying game. Plays almost too fast with more than two players. We always play with some expansions, which are almost a necessity with more than two players. I can play this game a lot and not get tired of it as long as I play some other games to add some variety to the evening. Familiarity with the tile deck, I believe, can minimize the results of "bad" tile draws.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
