=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like many others here, Carcassonne, along with Settlers of Catan, is primarily responsible for my headlong plunge into a full-blown gaming addiction. Unfortunately, I know far to many people with Carcassonne and Settlers "burn out." Therefore, I don't get to play this game nearly as much as I'd like. Not sure how I escaped unscathed, but the fact remains: I still love this game!

Much like vanilla Settlers, it's difficult to rate the base game by itself with knowledge of all the expansions and spin-offs, and that's without taking into account the newest edition of the rules. The revised rules were certainly for the best, especially considering the simplified farm scoring.

For such a simple set of rules, this game seems to contain a satisfying amount of depth. The experience is even better when players play aggressively. Inns and Cathedrals manages to successfully iron out a few of the wrinkles when it comes to balance, particularly the road scoring, but even without the expansion, the game is still playable and contains a lot of charm. There's nothing like glomming onto a huge city your opponent was about to finish, or connecting your wimpy farm with your opponent's massive one. I think the game plays best with 3, it's okay with 4, and I avoid it with 5. Downtime gets annoying with 4 to 5 players. It's also a perfectly adequate 2 player game.

If you've ever played Entdecker, you'll realize how much Carcassonne owes to its tile laying predecessor. Claus Jurgen-Wrede managed to pull the most enjoyable mechanic from this early Teuber effort, and turn it into a brilliant, addicting gateway experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A perfect entry-level game. I've played this with a huge variety of people, and all have enjoyed it. Simple mechanics, clear rules (the farms usually get people the first game, but that makes them more eager for the second). Hard to master, and newcomers have a shot at winning their first game (if you don't go too cut-throat on them).

RATING: 8
SDJ

I own this on iOS as well.  Great version.


Two Player Value = Good.  A little more competitive with more players though.

Three Player Value = Excellent.  A little more competitive with more players though.


I am not going to go into a lot of detail explaining Carcassonne.  By now everyone knows what the game is and how to play.

I believe it is enough to say that Carcassonne is one of the grandfathers of the gaming hobby and is clearly the frontrunner of tile-laying games.

This game is easy to teach and the learn.  Even learning by reading directly from the rules is simply.  That makes it a great game for beginners.  Yet even well seasoned gamers find the game enjoyable.

That is because everything just sort of fits with Carcassonne.  

The components are very nice.  Thick cardboard was used.  The artwork is likewise.  Not flashy, but it fits well.

The theme is interesting and fits the game wonderfully.

The mechanics are completely solid and fit the theme well.

This an all-around excellent game.


Pros - 
- Fun
- Great mechanic
- Simply to learn and play
- Innovative for its time


Cons - 
- Many of the expansions are out of print and hard to get



Overall Playability = 8.0

Design = 9
Strategy = 8
Luck = 8
Artwork & Components= 7
Use of Mechanics = 9
Time of Play = 8
Fun = 9
Innovation = 7
Analysis Paralysis = 8
Theme = 7


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=2993][/thing] expansion as played during the Carcassonne Project.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 6th player pieces.
- Big meeple worth two normal meeples.
- 18 Tiles.  Most are either new city tiles or Inns on road tiles.  One Cloister. 


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- The Bigger Meeple offers new strategy for control of structures.
- Inns on roads and the Cathedrals in cities offer more points for finished structures respectively.  But offer zero points for unfinished structures at end of game.


[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- This is a great expansion.  Easy to learn and play.  No complicated rules.  And it blends into the base game easily.
- The Big Meeple is great for take-overs and you can really start playing the game on the attack.
- The bonus points on finished structures is really nice, but it makes you plan ahead a lot more.  Unfinished structures will not score at End Game any more and many times the points for unfinished structures makes the difference.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=5405][/thing] expansion as played during the Carcassonne Project.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 24 tiles with all but two containing city parts.  
- 20 Goods Tokens
- Pig Meeples for each color
- Builder Meeples for each color


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- The new city tiles have Goods on them.  The player that finishes a city collects those Goods present in that city.  End game offers a new scoring mechanic for majority control for each of the three Goods at 10 points each.
- Pig Meeple can be added to a Farmer to increase the value of Farms at End Game.
- Builder Meeple is added to a structure a player already has a Meeple in/on.  In later turns if that player adds to that structure the Builder allows the player to take a single extra turn.


[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- Fantastic expansion.  
- Maximizing the Builder get nasty quick.  It is wonderful and adds a layer to the game where other players want to finish your structures to limit your extra turns.  Turns the game so players often play tiles defensively.
- The Goods add a cool new scoring feature that can alter the End Game just enough to tip the scales.  Also adds to the defensive play of the Builder as players will want the Goods.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=2591][/thing] expansion as played during the Carcassonne Project.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 12 tiles with sections of River on them, include a Spring to start the River and a Lake to end it.  Some tiles also have structures on them.


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- This is a new way to begin the game.  Players first build the River and can place Meeples on the River tile structures.  This sort of seeds the game.  Then the game is played as normal.

[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- This is a great new way to begin the game.  Much better than the single start tile.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=7707][/thing] expansion as played during the Carcassonne Project.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 7 new tiles.  5 Structure tiles with one King tile and one Scout tile.


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- This expansion offers a new scoring mechanic.  The King and the Scout each score bonus end game points.  The King is awarded to the player that built the largest city and grants 1 point per completed city at game end.  The Scout is the same but with Roads.


[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- A simple expansion that offers a fun new scoring mechanic.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]



Here I will discuss the [thing=12903][/thing] expansion as played during the Carcassonne Project.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 12 new tiles that make up the City of Carcassonne and a new Count of Carcassonne meeple.


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- The City of Carcassonne is a new way to begin the game.  The game starts with the City of Carcassonne already in play.  The city is comprised of four sections; Cathedral for Cloisters, Blacksmith for roads, Castle for Cities, and Market for farms.
- Each time a player finishes a structure for another player and scores no points for themselves, that player can add one of their meeples to the City of Carcassonne into one of the sections of the city.  That player may also move the Count of Carcassonne to another city section.
- On later turns when a structure is scored a player may remove his meeple from the corresponding part of the city to score that same amount of points or add to his majority/minority control of that structure.
- The section of city the Count of Carcassonne occupies is closed and may not be used.


[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- This can be a rather nasty addition to the game and can make for brutal games as everyone fights for control and points of structures.  But it is fun addition to the game as well.
- This expansion takes more long term strategic planning.  Players need to account for meeples leaving the city and stealing points and plan to do so themselves.  Furthermore you must be more careful with your meeples.  You will find yourself very short on available meeples if they are all in the city.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=15158][/thing] expansion.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 30 tiles all containing either a Volcano, a Dragon, a Magic Portal or Princess symbol
- Dragon meeple
- Fairy meeple


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- The Volcano brings the Dragon into play and the Dragon flies to each Volcano as it enters play.
- The Dragon moves whenever a tile with the Dragon symbol enters play.  Each player moves the Dragon one tile orthogonally until it moves 6 total spaces.  The Dragon eats any player meeples on a tiles it is on.  The Dragon will not enter a tile with the Fairy meeple.
- The Magic Portal allows the player to place a meeple on any previously played tile obeying all normal tile laying rules.
- The Princess when played to a city containing any player meeple must remove a meeple from the city.
- The Fairy scores the controlling player 1 point at the beginning of his turn.  If a structure is scored and it contains the Fairy that structure scores an additional 3 points.  The Fairy protects against the Dragon.  When a player lays a tile, but does not play one of his own meeples, he may instead take control of the Fairy placing it on any tiles containing one of his meeples.


[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- This expansion offers many new changes to the rules including new scoring mechanics and new attack mechanics.  Keeping all the new rules straight is difficult the first few plays.
- The Dragon can get really nasty and clear the board if the Volcano tiles are place well.
- The Magic Portal is meant to allow players to claim structures the Dragon or Princess has cleared of meeples.  But many times it is useless as there are no valid, nor any good, previously played but yet unscored and unclaimed tiles remaining.
- The Fairy often gets forgotten to score each turn given its nature of constantly moving around.
- The Princess can get nasty.  Don't accidentally place her in a city with only one of your meeples present because the Princess must remove a meeple.
- Overall I am not impressed with this expansion.  It is primarily about attacking the other players.  The attacks will either be vicious or completely useless.  The additional scoring mechanics are not really powerful enough to make a difference.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=18836][/thing] expansion.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 12 tiles with sections of River on them, include a Spring to start the River, a River fork and two Lakes to end it.  Some tiles also have structures on them.
- Some tiles contain additional components from prior expansions like an Inn or a Pig Farmer.


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- This is a new way to begin the game.  Players first build the River and can place Meeples on the River tile structures.  This sort of seeds the game.  Then the game is played as normal.

[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- This is a great new way to begin the game.  Much better than the single start tile.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=21385][/thing] expansion.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 18 Tiles each holding a Tower building place
- 30 Tower pieces
- 1 Tower that holds the tiles


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- A large Tower now holds all the tiles.
- After a player lays a tile he may place a Tower piece instead of a follower.  It must go on an open Tower building place or on top of an existing Tower to further heighten that Tower.
- A meeples may be placed on top of a Tower to cap the Tower so it may not be further built and extended.
- Each Tower has an orthogonal area of influence equal to its height in Tower pieces.  Any opposing meeple within that area of influence may be taken Prisoner after adding a Tower piece.  The player takes that Prisoner meeple off the board and puts it with his meeple supply.  It is no longer in play and no longer adds its influence toward control.
- Prisoner meeples are given back to their controlling player once two players have taken each others meeples as Prisoners.  Or a player can pay 3 points to have a Prisoner meeple returned.


[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- The Tower is silly.  I did fine without it holding the tiles.
- The Tower rule for taking Prisoners is extremely powerful.  Over powered in my opinion.  With 18 Tower tiles finding them is not difficult.  And with smart placing, you can easily put a Tower in a place to remove many meeples.  The overall effect is that is makes the game center around attacking your opponents.  
- Overall, I do not like this expansion much so it won't get played much.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the [thing=26615][/thing] expansion.


[b]New Components[/b] - 
- 12 Tiles.  Two of the new tiles are used with the two River expansions and are a new Spring and new Lake.  The remaining 10 tiles are new structure tiles.  1 tile has a pig farmer to boost Farmer scoring.


[b]New Mechanics[/b] - 
- No new mechanics.  This expansion uses the rules from the base game and a few other expansions.


[b]Thoughts[/b] - 
- This is a fun little expansion.  A few of the new structure tiles are interesting and not previously seen. 
- Always a good addition to any game.


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Aw man, this game is just good times. Good for at least one "Yes!" moment per game when you get just the right tile.

One time we were strapped for table space where we were playing, so we decided to play Carcassonne on an extremely long, narrow table (about fifteen inches wide and six feet long) and a variant was accidentally born: Carcassonne Valley.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Getting Carcassonne marked the beginnings of the boardgame hobby for me. This was before I was even aware of the plethora of categories of games and before I knew of Euro or AT mast to pin my colors on. I can't remember what attracted me in Carc, or whether it came recommended by someone, but I can remember that initially I really enjoyed the game. I introduced it to just about anyone we had over, and it seemed to fit any group, any time and every mood. We played this with all counts, but most games, around half I'd wager, have been just the wife and I, and we played really cuththroat. No matter how I've changed and how what I value in games has shifted, one thing has clearly remained: I play for fun. In our 2P Carc, winning mattered, but having fun mattered more. And what was fun was contesting castles, nevermind how effective it was pointswise, and imagining what was happening, teasing each other and, sometimes, outsmarting the other and being outsmarted. Sadly, we've come to a point where I can't approach Carc with that same, open let's-have-fun-with-this -attitude I used to.  For better and for worse, I acquired a taste, and am unable to enjoy anything and everything. It's not with a heavy heart that I gave up Carc, or with teary nostalgia or anything soft like that, but it does remind me of a simpler time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Bought this as a New Year's present for my family (and myself). They love it! 
    The tiles are beautifully illustrated and games often create a nice looking landscape on the table while playing. The rules are truly "easy to learn, hard to master", it's one of those games where you don't have to beg non-gamers to play it. Once everyone's familiar with the rules, this can be played in a fairly short amount of time, including setup and break-down.
    With more players, this game becomes more dependent on good 'luck' in drawing the right tiles, as you'll be drawing less tiles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Compared to the other big lightning-bolt games that broke into the mainstream, Carcassonne has always struck me as second-tier. It lacks the immediacy of both Catan and Ticket To Ride, and has probably been expanded and revamped a big too much for its own good.

That said, it's still a very good game. Its intuitive domino-like gameplay has the potential to be either cutthroat or gentle, sometimes in the same session. If you play with the Rio Grande version, be sure you use the Hans im Gluck scoring rules for farmers. It's also better with the first couple of expansions thrown in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
See the box box comments.  Family favorite.

RATING: 6.5

That's not a big deal, however, as the blind tile draw keeps the game moving and forces you to hedge your bets and take care when pressing your luck, because you may never close off that city, or you opponent may manage to take it over...

RATING: 6
Valentine's Day 2012 gift from my wife :)

It's a great game for us, at this time in our lives. It was easy to learn, plays very quickly, and has a balanced, well implemented two player version. We can set our toddler down to play and finish a game within 10-15 minutes before he starts to fuss, or needs our attention.

Update: after having played this for several weeks, I wouldn't call it my favorite game. But it's still a good choice of game if you have 15-20 minutes on hand, and a fussy toddler that needs 30% of your attention.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Everyone loves this game for some reason, but the lustre has dimmed for me lately. Now when I play, I almost always use some variant to bring down the time of the expanded game (leaving one third of the tiles in the box seems to work well, or you can use Richard Garfield's variant of adding the 50/100 tiles to the tile bag and stopping when three have been drawn).

Carc is the most successful gateway game in my collection, but it has a big problem in that it scales poorly. It's best with 2 players, good with 3 and okay with 4, but with 5 or 6 (as you often see in a gateway gaming situation), it's too random and too long. I've been playing a lot of 4, 5 and 6 player games lately, so I'm a bit burned out on it. Definitely best with 2P, but still too lucky to have staying power as anything other than a gateway / family game.

I would recommend keeping the expansions to a minimum: Inns & Cathedrals plus the tiles (but not the rules) from King & Scout. If you add too many expansions the game becomes fiddly and way too long, and you have to shorten it using one of the above variants. We usually play that after a tile has been placed, the player can draw a fresh tile to study during downtime. This is helpful also.

If you're uncertain whether to get a copy, I say go for it. It's relatively cheap and as a gateway game it's amazing. And meeples come in handy for other games: as player markers in Traders of Genoa, role selection markers in San Juan, etc.

Update: Hating this more. It has well and truly outstayed its welcome.

Update: The iPhone version is much better -- not so much downtime.

RATING: 7
Very enjoyable and fairly fast - which is important when the kids are lurking around waiting for their chance to grab a meeple and run...

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a tile laying game where players have a common pool of tiles to draw from, at random, and then play the drawn tile to add to the existing map.  Players score by assigning one of a limited set of wooden token to the tile they just played.  They get the token back once the road, building, cloister is complete, which is not always obvious when.  Players must decide where to place their tiles, and if they should commit a token to scoring off that tile.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Family (1.9/5.0)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is how I got into german games in the first place! We play with the expansions, of course. Now that we have other games, this one isn't played nightly (as it was when it was our only game) but we still love it every time we bring it out.

One of the most beautiful aspects of this game is that the luck of tile drawing is ofset by the fact that you can always do something with the drawn tile in order to win points. Maybe not enough points, but at least the luck factor doesn't steam roll anyone.

RATING: 9
ONGOING opinion:  This has evolved into my favorite (I have updated it's rating several times).  To me it has a very high replayability since each game is so different.  I just love to play.

EARLY Opinion: Among my favorites when we have 30 minutes and want to play a quick game.  Much better game when playing with the river expansion (came included) and while I originally thought it was much more luck than strategy I am starting to see how strategy can impact the game.  Luck is still a big component and you can't overcome bad tiles.  But you can finesse mediocre tiles into a pretty good score if you work it.

RATING: 6
I've come to appreciate this game over time, but it's been a long road. These days I prefer it with four players and I think the odd lucky tile is outweighed by clever play and the fun of taking the odd risk. The basic game is fine.

I bought the very first German edition - where the rules for farmers were rather obtuse. Since then various rules about points scoring have been modified, so now I don't know what I'm playing until we run through the rules before a game and agree on them - usually depending upon what edition game we're playing. I'd suggest to the publishers that they start printing rules titles like "Big Box Carcassonne using fifth edition rules" on the cover, so we gamers could just start referring to the ruleset by edition numbers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my most-played games. With 2 players, I would rate this higher than 8. With more, I don't think it's as good. The monasteries make it a bit random, but that's also part of why it's fun - it's always possible for weaker players to win,

One of my favourite gaming moments happened in Carcassonne when my father laid an early farmer and was surrounded by four of those L-shaped road tiles in the smallest field possible!

RATING: 9
A unique mechanic of players draw random tiles to build a countryside with scattered cities for points.  A good games to introduce players to as it is more about building well that "crushing the other guy" in order to win.  A near perfect design: some randomness in drawing tiles to keep a high replay value, but enough "here or there?" decision making to give it plenty of strategic value.

RATING: 8
Emlekszem, 2006 nyarelejen egy unalmas pentek keso delutani hangulatomban keresgeltem a neten Catan kiegeszitok utan, ekkor akadtam ra a compaya.hu weboldalra. Ekkor meg alapbol elvetettem a nem Magyarorszagon kiadott jatekokat es ezert akadt meg a szemem egy Carcassonne nevu jatekon. Irtam egy E-mail-t az oldal uzemeltetojenek, hogy marpedig nekem most es azonnal kellene a jatek (olyan este 8 korul lehetett mar), teljes megrokonyodesemre 5 percen belul jott a valasz (ezen akkor csodalkoztam, ma mar tudom, hogy Payanal ez a tipikus support, most mar azon sertodok meg ha nem valaszol 5 perc alatt) es mondta, hogy akar mehetek most is, neki nem problema. A tobbi mar tortenelem, nem csak Carcassonne-val jottem el tole a honom alatt, hanem egy TTR is ott logott. Hogy irjak magarol a jatekrol is, felesegem kedvenc jateka csak O nem szeret ugy jatszani, hogy egymastol veszunk el dolgokat, szep lassan egymas mellett fejlodni, ennek a hive. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great 2-3 player game. Simple and fun, and playable in about 30 minutes if everyone knows that they're doing.  I'm a big fan, and I doubt this game will ever leave my collection.

Note: Always play that as soon as you lay down a tile, you pick the next one up. That way you can think of your move as the other people are placing theirs. Speeds up the game. Two knowledgeable players can knock out a game in 20 minutes.

Oh, another great thing about this game: amazing quick set-up and cleanup time.  You normally only get this kind of speed with a card game. (Although, drawing tiles from a stack and cards from a deck are kinda similar...)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
To me, Carcassonne is the definition of a 7: a good, solid game, thank you very much.  Little to criticize, little to brag about.  The game plays well with any number, and isn't even bad as solitaire.  Still, there can be a somewhat mechanical feel to it, as there's usually an optimal place for each drawn tile.

RATING: 10
Carcassonne is *THE GAME* that did it for me -- the one that got me permanently hooked on the world of European board games that I had never known existed before. The game that opened my eyes to the whole world of fun out there that I was missing out on. I think anyone who has played this game would immediately place it at the very top of their all-time favorite list, but it's relatively low ranking on BoardGameGeek (it's currently #46) has probably more to due with its age than anything else, since it's a 7-year old game as of this writing. In any case, this game is an all-out classic, and is considered a "gateway game" for anyone looking to dip their toes into the "alternative" world of gaming. EXCELLENT & OUTSTANDING.

RATING: 7
Solid game, and I can see why it's one of the bigger hits. The tile laying aspect means that you'll end up with a different board every time, and the rules allow you to play pretty much separately with newbies, but to get more cutthroat with more experienced players. There is an element of luck with what tiles you'll get, and I've seen people draw 4 roads in a row with a lot of frustration. Still, the game is quite fun, especially with some expansions.

RATING: 8
Really love this game with 2 players. I don't think I've played with 3, and with 4-5 it seems a bit too random to me, at least without expansions (since there are only ~80 tiles, you get to place 40 in a 2 player game and only 15-20 in a 4-5 player game, which definitely detracts from the strategy a bit). Very tactical two player game though.

Update: now we have the Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders expansions, and it does add a lot to the game. With 2 players I'm fine playing without those two expansions, but I think with more players they add a lot more depth to the game (and mitigate the randomness)

RATING: 7.5
FUN ★★★✰✰
I play it with my family and girlfriend. Easy to setup, nice to play.

RULES ★★★★★
Clear and easy. Can be taught to casual players in 10 minutes (without the expansions).

IMMERSION ★★✰✰✰
For peoople who like to repeat history or at least to have a flavour of challenges of the past, there is no so much interest. But that's not the purpose here.

DEPTH ★✰✰✰✰
It's a game where strategies are quite easy to understand. I would play it to spend some good time with people, not to try to elaborate complex new ways of winning. But this is ok.

RATING: 5
This game is not terrible, but it doesn't live up to the hype. Mostly my complaint is with the Farmer scoring. A secondary problem I have with it is the down time, and the 'everyone telling you where to put your piece', which some people seem to actually like. As a variant I'd probably try a 'draw as soon as you've played' rule so you can look at most of your options before it gets to your turn. It might be nice to have more than 1 tile to play as well, maybe a hand of 3 or something for more strategy (though that's not really what the game is lacking).

RATING: 6
First time I played Carcassonne, I really didn't like it. Then I started playing some of the variants of it and warmed up to it. The base game, however, is still just too plain, though. The only way to even the playing field is through subterfuge. And then when everyone's using subterfuge, it all boils down to luck.

I'm much happier with The Castle or The City, because of all the distractions. They give the game some much-needed flexibility.

RATING: 3
2-5 player tile-laying family game, but any game above 3 players isn't much fun. The game is cute and probably innovative for its time, but doesn't seem very fun to me. The epitome of "manufacturing victory points", this game just feels like work and no fun.  

Annoying thing about the game is people can "game" you by memorizing the tiles, and I'm never sure how well I'm doing in the game - the scores fluctuate a lot from game to game.

2+1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This was a staple for a long time.
With all the tiles in the mix, the game gets very long, especially with more than 2 players.  
We have played 'timed' games and tile limited games to shorten the time it takes to play.  
It is often a misunderstood game.  There is never a 'perfect' or 'optimal' place to put a tile.  Usually you can play the tile defensively or offensively.  Too much offense and your opponent becomes offensive forcing you to become more defensive.  Politics and attitude go a long way in this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
2012 early Christmas for Zack from Julia

This along with Stone Age is my wife's favorite multiplayer family strategy game to play together that takes 45-60 minutes to play.  She eagerly awaits to play future expansions after she was impressed with the challenge brought about by Inns and Cathedrals added with Traders and Builders (which are must-buy expansions in our opinion if one wants an optimal Carcassonne experience).  The components are classic in their wooden colorful "meeple" aesthetic that has defined what Euro games look and feel like compared to mass-market American games.  I think we actually enjoy this game more than we had enjoyed Settlers of Catan (the game that brought us into the tabletop gaming hobby).

RATING: 7

Engenhoso e bem feito. Facil de aprender e ensinar. Envolve estratégias e táticas variadas. A contagem é fácil. O jogo é bastante equilibrado. Todas as partidas acabaram com uma mínima diferença de pontos entre os jogadores. Bom tanto em dois quanto em três jogadores. Tambem funcionou em cinco, mas fica dificil sustentar as estratégias. -1 por conta da sorte que ainda acaba determinando a vitória.

This game fits as a metaphor for life. You get the pieces chance offers you and try to fit them in the right way. You have the workers representing your attention and investment labor, decisions based on prudence, prevision and consideration capacity.
Would like to see a metaphor for life not so based on Ego though...
Maybe a co-op spin-off objecting the building of a better or more beautiful common board.

RATING: 8

2-games-in-1. When played with 2 becomes a ferocious, brain burning cutthroat action. When played with more, becomes a hilarious party/family game.

I'm lucky enough to procure one with The River expansion these days!

RATING: 4
Potentially nasty family friendly euro that can easily be taught to players of tradition card games. No real theme, but looks cute enough, has a charm of seeing the board getting built. Easily taught, just use the farmer rules from latest edition - I had no problems with them (complicated? jeeze...).
Scales interestingly = more players make more chaos, less players make the game more thinky. Use the house rule to draw tiles at the end of your turn, not beginning - makes game flow smoother. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a go to game in our family. My almost 8 yr old wants to play it all the time. I also play on my phone as I unwind at the end of the evening.  Most other people seems to enjoy the game as well, except for my wife.  She prefers games with one or more endgame goals that she can set a strategy to work towards the goals on each turn.  This game has no such endgame goal; it is light on strategy and heavy on tactics which is why I think she does not enjoy it as much. My son has more difficulty executing long term strategy so this game lets him rack up points from a series of good short term decisions. I enjoy both types of games so I enjoy Carcassonne for what it is, a great tactical game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A real classic, and it's portable too! I must've played hundreds of games against the AI using the Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders expansions.

What I find interesting about Carcassonne is how the nature of the game changes depending on the player count. With 2P it is more calculative, especially when playing with those who have memorised the tile compositions (not something I'd plan to do again any time soon, but it is an enlightening experience). With more players added, it becomes more like a party game, since players are prone to negotiate the sharing of certain features.

I've had a lot of success using Carcassonne as non-gamer's game because it's simple and the gameplay is as gentle as the players want it to be.

People consider it a light tile laying game and play it once and move along to other games without enjoying the simplicity of the Classic that is Carcassonne.

If you are buying your first game of this type, then I'd recommend Carc: Hunters and Gatherers over this original version as a better version with more intuitive rules and scoring.

It's pretty much the only "cutthroat" game that we own and there is a perfect amount of indignation and anger when someone swoops in to steal a city or road you have been working on for the last half of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
I've played Carcassonne close to 20 times.  It plays very quickly, and I don't think there is quite as much luck as some think there is.  It's more about managing your farmers than hoping to draw that perfect piece which will complete an over-sized city.  There are many shrewd tactical choices to be made.  When you draw a tile which doesn't directly benefit you, think about using that piece to hinder your nearest competitor to the greatest effect.  Doing so will make the game seem far less luck-driven.  

I've never lost at Carcassonne.  I've tied for first twice.  Generally my play group with it has been the same two people.  They beat me their fair share in other games.  So, either I'm extremely lucky, or this game is indeed deep in its strategy and tactics, and the luck is minimal.  I believe the latter is true.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
переворачивает взгляды - так просто, но интересно же !!

RATING: 7
The expansions seem to over-complicate what is a nice, simple and fun tile placing game, accessible to a lot of people.  Still a favorite and some of those expansions add some nice touches.  Playing with 2 or 3, it is fast and tactical.  With a larger group there is the fun of negociating the placement of the tile.  With the right crowd in a noisy mood, this is very fun, even when you lose! It can be frustrating at times though - the luck of the draw factor.  As long as you enjoy the ride, that is OK.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassone is a light, relaxing game. In Carc, players take turns placing a single tile which might depict a farm and a road, a city, or a cloister - or a combination of these. Then you have the option of placing a meeple on your tile (as a knight, bandit, monk, or farmer - depending upon whether you put him on a city, road, cloister, or farm); and then there's some scoring business. There is something very pleasurable about slowly building the French countryside with others, and the scoring mechanism is ingenious. Learning when to deploy farmers takes a bit of strategizing. Now don't get me wrong, there is real strategy at work here - Carc just "feels" kind of light to me. This makes it an ideal game for social play. Skill matters (some anyway), but you don't feel that you have to watch the play like a hawk to perform well. My rating for this game includes a slight variant we use: we add the river tiles in with the rest (as opposed to playing them all at the beginning or leaving them out) and then use them to "screw your neighbor." Try it! It adds a little bit of ruthlessness to the bucolic setting.

There was a time when I rated Carc higher, and I do think it is a great game. But I've now played it sooooo many times, it's become a little stale. For a strategic game, I find myself desiring something a lot meatier, with greater control.

CHILDREN'S RATING: 8

This is fun to play with even very small kids too - just remove/simplify the scoring and play it primarily as an edge-matching game.

RATING: 3

Other expansions add more options and also "fun", but really makes counting points and checking who controls what very complex. BSW could do that for you, but of course player interaction is equal to 0 there. (As if Carcassonne had any to begin with...)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really like this game.

CONS: not very confrontational with 2 players. The scoring track sucks - it only goes up to 50 by which time you flip your meeple on its back to signify 50+ and keep going around. Probably not a big deal with more than 2 players- thus less scoring but we find ourselves loosing track if we score big as then you gotta flip your meeple a different way...sigh.

PROS: well the pros far out weigh the cons.  EASY! game play, fun tile laying, opportunity to steal points (I like this :) Fast for those need to fill between games moments.  Good all rounder! Great for first timers!

UPDATE: if you find Carcassonne a bit unchallenging or a tad bit boring you HAVE TO get Traders and Builders extension- best buy ever. It turned my Carcassonne game hating partner into a believer (or is it follower?) :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The first few games of Carcassonne that I played were with more than 2 players, and left me underwhelmed. I thought it's nowhere near as good as the remaining two of the popular trio: [thing=13]Settlers of Catan[/thing] and [thing=9209]Ticket to Ride[/thing].

It's when I started playing 2-player Carcassonne that I saw the real beauty of this game. Fast, engaging and potentially cutthroat - this is another excellent gateway to the hobby.

(The variant with 3 tiles in hand seems to be popular, but I've never felt the need for it. The game is strategic enough as it is for a 2-player game - keep it simple.)

RATING: 7.5
Quick and easy, but very fun!  Tile-drawing mechanic works nicely to limit too many options and AP, while still rewarding skilled and clever players with the worker-placement mechanic.  Creating unique "boards" throughout the games is always enjoyable.  Expansions: too many, too unevenly distributed, and often too irrelevant.  Only Inns & Cathedrals seems necessary, a couple of the others (notably Traders & Builders) are good additions.  Classic game; still holds up and is perfect for its weight.

3/20/16 - lowered rating to 6.  i enjoy the cutthroat aspect of the game and trying to do farmer wars.  but overall find it a little less exciting and not something i would ever ask to play.  i do like it as a gateway game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne is a classic at this point and deservedly so. For me, it's a very relaxing experience. It's one of those games that you can talk about your day while playing. We play it almost cooperatively, with everyone helping to find the best spot for a tile. It's like doing a puzzle, but with points. If I had a negative about the game, it's the farmer scoring. Points are usually pretty close, but it always seems that whoever lucks out with the better farmer placements wins. It's a small issue and doesn't deter me from bringing this game out when we just want to sit back and relax.

RATING: 7
My brother bought this game in late 2003, and I can credit this for my renewed interest in all boardgames.  Prior to Carcassonne, I was occasionally playing Risk 2210 with friends, and some Magic: the Gathering online.  After Carcassonne, I came to BGG looking for strategy and I was hooked.

---

I'm now not as big of a fan of Carcassonne as I was when I first played it, and I prefer Hunters and Gatherers over the original, but it is still a remarkably good game, and a worthwhile addition to most players' game closets.

RATING: 8.5
Certainly a great game. There's some variety of strategies to use -- our 7-year old plays without peasants, while my wife and me always end up in the peasant war, and sometimes we almost tie up, the three of us. I also found out though that the peasant wars are only important on big games -- we have some three or four extensions, and it only makes sense to fight for land and towns on a field with 200  tiles. We never could figure out the princess, but the dragon brings a lot of tension to the game that otherwise might have just ended up in the first third of the bag of tiles.

RATING: 7
The standard edition of Carcassone with the expansions is falling out of favor with my gaming group. The City is more advanced and contained, making for a neater game. I think that the manufacturers over-extended themselves on the brand and tried for the easy $ while the market was hot. Still a fun game and definitely worth the price. But would recommend H&G over this at the $20 price point. If you want to spend a little bit more, for $50 you can get the City which is superbly constructed and more strategic IMO.

RATING: 7
Fun little tile laying game that is more like meditation to me than an engrossing game. If one could produce the perfect word about the experience of playing Carcassonne, I would say "pleasant." Thats not bad, mind you, and I do love to spring this one on non-gamers, who seem to enjoy it much. Fact is, I believe there is a little known chemical in the brain called Carcassonnine that gets released only when one begins to place these cute little tiles one after the other down on the table. The Carcasonnine induces a state of hypnotic euphoria, feelings of fuzy warmness, and above all, pleasantness.

RATING: 7
The game that got me back into boardgaming! I played this so many times and I enjoyed every single one of them. I no longer play it as often as I used to, as my gaming tastes moved on to heavier games, but this is still a lot of fun when I do. I love seeing the board grow differently every time. I love how you can play this more or less agressive.
Nowadays I'd rather play with just the base game and the Inns & Cathedrals expansion. Over time I collected quite a number of expansions, but it quickly gets bloated to a point where t's no longer a quick, lighter type game.

Owned expansions: Inns & Cathedrals / Traders & Builders / King & Scout / The River 1 & II / The Cult / The Tower

RATING: 7.8
Really great gateway game and a nice way to draw in all sorts of new gamers, whether they be kids or adults. In my opinion, playing with the King, Inns and Cathedrals, and Traders and Builders expansions together makes for a killer, deep game, and one that with some investment, even novice gamers can become familiar with the additional pieces. My rating, therefore, is based on having some expansions, and the Big Box is highly recommended as a purchase.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fun tile-laying game -- the one that made the genre popular! But it's been around a while, and rating has fallen slightly - prefer the variants to the original, now. 

Tiles show some combination of land/city/road +/- cloister. Place starting tile in center. In turn order, draw then play a tile adjacent to one already on the board, until last tile placed. When placing, features on edges must match adjacent tile. MAY place a meeple on a feature of the tile you placed, but only if no other meeple is already present on that type of feature on another tile, where the features are contiguous. If your tile placement completes the feature, score it immediately (city: 2 per tile; shields count as extra tile; road: 1 per tile; cloister: 9 when completely surrounded). At end of game, each farm (contiguous cluster of land) scores 3VP/city to the player with meeple majority in the farm. Most VP wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Like it, don't love it -- when I play it, it's more to pass the time and have something to chat over than to actually play a game.  Having said that, as light games go Carcassonne is one of the best.  I'd rather go with something slightly weightier, like Alhambra, but if Carcassonne gets suggested I'm typically happy to play.  Still, Carcassonne is my game of choice for getting reluctant non-gamers into gaming.  Works every time!

RATING: 3
I keep wanting to like this one, but I seem to enjoy it less every time I play.  It is a well-designed game that can be enjoyed by children and adults, but I don&#039;t usually like these type of free-form tile-laying games, especially where you&#039;re drawing one random card that you have to play.  I can see why most people like it.  Just my own personal quirks coming into play here for the most part.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I just don't get it.  I've only played the base game without any expansions but it's just boring to me.  The drawing of tiles is completely random and I get that there is strategy involved in shaping your roads and cities and meeple placement against this but that's not enough to keep me interested.

After playing this game several more times in an attempt to give it a fair shake I think I like it even less.  I really don't get the love for this game!

2 players is the maximum you can play this with any semblance of strategy and still sometimes you will never see the tiles you need while your opponent gets the perfect one every turn.  With more than 2 it is just nonsense.  The chances of you getting usable tiles that fit your strategy is diluted even further with every additional player and the number of tiles placed that screw with your whole plan is increased.  Every tile you place you have no idea if it is going to help you or just end up being a waste of a turn.  I'm ultimately convinced this is not a very good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm giving this game a second chance.  Never did much for me but now that my girls are older this suddenly became more interesting.  I think the base game is a solid game but not great.  I'd like to try the traders and builders expansion to get more out of this.

RATING: 9
Just great. Carcassonne is one of these games that I just can't say no to play. Sometimes you don't feel in the mood of thinking too much, to play Puerto Rico, Euphrat, or one of these a bit more complicated games... but Carcassonne is so easy that I'm always willing to play. As well, so far I've all the expansions for it and it gains a lot of gameplay and variations. I'll say that the basic game itself is maybe too simple, so if you can, play it at least with the river expansion.
Completely recommended to everyone, no matter the age.

RATING: 10
Probably my favorite game, it still doesn't feel old to me. The mix of puzzle playing, planing, luck, messing with the opponent and strategy is just extremely appealing to me.
The thing is, no other game has held its attraction with me like Carcassonne, with others my liking usually goes up and down a bit but this one I can always play.
It holds up very well with any number of players, it plays different with 2 than with 5 but is good fun in any variant.

RATING: 8
Game that got me into all this (thanks methsdrinker!) - great stuff - easy to learn, and easy to get others involved, inc. non-gamers. 

With slightly modded rules, have even played with my 3-year old, and not a single meeple casualty (so far).

Often use "The River II" (for an uber-river - by the way, Meeples can't swim...though they do float) & 12 central tiles from "The Count of Carc" (but not the count himself) to add starting set-up variety - Inns & Cathedrals are pretty much always in there too, except when playing with the wee one - too long otherwise!

Interesting solo variant described on the geek too.

EDIT: Comments from Jan 2010 above; now 3 years later I'm still enjoying this, particularly on the ipod and with Emma, including Inns and Cathedrals, but not counting fields, and she's good!

RATING: 8
Carcassonne fills a niche perfectly: It's simple enough to play with non-strategic players, but deep enough to satisfy the more hardcore players. You can play it as a beer and pretzels game, but you don't have to.

RATING: 8
Easy to teach and popular with non-gamers and gamers alike. I enjoy puzzling out the best place for a tile. With gamers, you can play dirty, blocking each other's castles off, or sneaking in to share or steal the points. I prefer with 2-3 players only, but will occasionally play up to 6 with non-gamers.

When teaching new players, I'll add to the basic rules the big guy, inn on the lake, & cathedrals only. I leave the traders and builder to another day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

We played it a lot as it was one of our first games, but now we have much better games and it only gets played when we have people visiting that want to play a light, easy to explain game. My father-in-law doesn't really like games, but likes Carcassone.
EDIT May 2015: We played it for the first time with our daughter without the farmer rule.
EDIT April 2016: First game with full rules with our daughter with the 2 expansions.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
Classic, simple, fun.  I only have the base game + the river and bishops, but it's just such a pleasure to get this game to the table.  Whether I'm in the mood for a tight 2-player game or a 5-player free-for-all, this game is never too long and never too dull.  I never want it more than twice an evening, though, so it's good for a quick appetizer but not a main course.

RATING: 7
The first time I played this, I didn't get it. Maybe because I didn't understand the rules. Maybe because I was expecting more from it, after having played Settlers of Catan non-stop for a while. I gave it another go and lo and behold, we've got ourselves a pretty nifty game. I really like this game but it simply doesn't see the table as often as many others, maybe because I've outgrown it... Still, it's historically relevant in boardgaming history and a classic. After Catan it's considered a sales reference and an unequivocal gateway game. So I can see myself playing this to introduce people to board gaming, or occasionally, simply to remind myself that it's a fun game to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Meh.  I play mostly 2 player games with my boyfriend, and we played this when we were relatively new to gaming.  This game shows up on all of the lists recommending games for newbie players/couples to start out with, but I'm really glad this wasn't the first game we got because I don't know if we would have continued.  It was "fine" but decidedly underwhelming.  We got the Inns & Cathedrals expansion and also tried some house rules (drawing more tiles for example) -- that helped, but the game just had no tension.  Maybe if we knew the tiles better and could predict which tiles would come up and then try to plan out our moves... but if we were going to do that, I'd rather play a heavier game with more to it.  I can say that I enjoy the iPad version much more -- moves way quicker and it's helpful to see where you can/can't move.  Also, we didn't find the scoring that complicated as some people did, so that didn't scare us off.  I get that the board is nice looking, but there's no sense of having accomplished anything at the end -- you have no idea looking at the board at the end which of the cities/roads are yours, and which are your opponents.  Really just quite boring.  We traded it away.

RATING: 7
Tile laying, area control game that is low to medium strategy, but experienced players have a significant advantage in knowing where to score the most points.  Part of the challenge is that the drawing of tiles is random, so it is difficult to plan ahead for optimal advantage.  I have yet to try the game with a tile auction (like Tikal) but would be interested to see if this changes things.

RATING: 9
Carcassonne is the first of the collection and it brings the whole new experience of modern board games to me. I like that the situation of the game can be changed all the time while playing. It keeps me thinking the best way to manage tiles and turns and teaches me to plan ahead before everything forms into shape. The game also slightly reveals true personality of each player which is the true fun of the game and is the reason why I got hooked to it. Highly recommended to both beginners and regulars.

RATING: 8
:thumbsup: LIKE
+ easy to learn and to teach 
+ great tile laying gameplay that never plays the same twice
+ accessible to new players, but still engaging to more advanced players
+ cutthroat 2 player game

:thumbsdown: DISLIKE
- some luck tied to the tile drawing but you can play with the 3 tiles in hand variant to alleviate that
- farmer scoring is a bit opaque to new gamer

:star: VERDICT
Fast, fun and simple.  It's a classic.  My rating is for the cutthroat 2 player game (3+ being a little too chaotic).  
If you get bored with it, there is tons of expansions (most of them not too good though) to renew the game.

RATING: 5
Ah, Carc!  You were one of The Originals that started my wife and I gaming together.  It's hard to remember any more what the original game without the expansions was like, although it was certainly a fine little game in its own right.  I have carefully chosen which expansions I have purchased [edit: I have thrown caution to the wind and now own most of the expansions, which has pretty much destroyed the game by drastically increasing the amount of time required to play] and every one of those expansions has added an interesting element to the game.  When playing with all the expansions I own (The River, The River II, Inns and Cathedrals, Traders and Builders, King and Scout, The Princess and The Dragon), and with about half the tiles in the bag to decrease the play time, I would rank this game 7.5/10.  With my wife as my most frequent gaming partner, this has been one of the most played games we own (although it was one of the first games we owned!).  [Edit: Well, we finally killed poor Carc - http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/27391 - so we traded it away and purchased "Carcassonne: The City".  Game design: 3/5  Personal enjoyment: 2/5  Total: 5/10

RATING: 7.25

But I'm adjusting rating for basic game and raising it, because core set is excellent. I think I'd like to see only some rules from expansion sets, pawns and tiles in a single Designer’s Cut Set… ;)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[RGG Carcassonne Big box 2006 edition] {City building, gateway; tile-laying; optimal 3-4p} Carcassonne is a very good family game. It's easy to learn and interactive. Scoring happens all the time, which allows player to visual scores more easily, although it slightly disrupts the game flow. In addition, it's fun to play Carcassonne. Highly recommended as a gateway game in any collection.

It's more forgiving than Hunters & Gatherers, where incomplete roads and cities can still score.  It has good player interaction with mild confrontation. In addition, it is dynamic because tiles can be merged together and there are bonus tiles so that the situation may change abruptly.  

The Big Box edition is real good. It saves space and has a good insert for all tiles. In addition, it has a reference sheet for the distribution of tiles in the basic game and all expansions.

[Rulebook] The annotated rulebook in BGG shall be used with RGG Big Box edition. This rulebook provides the latest rules and FAQs, which makes the rules it much clearer.  I prefer the scoring rule of 3rd edition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My expansion checklist:

✅ Carcassonne (2000) (72 tiles)

Big Expansions:
✅Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals (18 tiles)
✅Carcassonne: Expansion 2 – Traders & Builders (24 tiles)

✅Carcassonne: Expansion 4 – The Tower (18 tiles)
✅Carcassonne: Expansion 5 – Abbey & Mayor (12 tiles)
❎Carcassonne: Expansion 6 – Count, King & Robber
✅Carcassonne: Expansion 7 – Catapult (12 tiles)
✅Carcassonne: Expansion 8 – Bridges, Castles & Bazaars (12 tiles)
✅Carcassonne: Expansion 9 – Hills & Sheep (18 tiles)
❎Carcassonne: Expansion 10 – Under the Big Top

RATING: 7
I will probably rank it higher, when I find the right combination of expansions.

My main gripe with this game is that it can be very mean for a family game. When I introduce it to new (usually boardgame novices) I have to hold my punches and refrain from taking over their roads and castles. And I don't like holding punches.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Carcassonne recently shot up to become one of my favorite games after a bunch of one-on-one plays with my partner.  This is a simply fantastic game; simple and fairly easy to teach, friendly-looking and colorful, but rewarding of a lot of thought and downright cut-throat when it comes down to it.  My partner even introduced it to my parents-in-law, and now they have their own copy that they play regularly, too!  A beautiful and elegant game.  I enjoy it most two-player, since it tends to take a bit longer with more players (only because people think harder about their turns and aren't able to plan ahead as much), but fun no matter what.  I honestly don't see getting too many expansions, I think they'd ruin the nice simple-but-difficult feel the game currently has.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Non è solo il nome di una città della Francia meridionale. È diventato il simbolo della lotta all'eresia condotta dalla chiesa medievale. La cittadella fortificata, unica nel suo genere, è circondata da un paesaggio molto bello e intricato. I giocatori piazzano le tessere che contengono gli elementi del paesaggio (città, monasteri, strade e campi) ampliandolo ad ogni turno. Con i propri seguaci (cavalieri, monaci, ladri e contadini) i giocatori cercano di estendere definitivamente la propria influenza sulle singole aree e in questo modo ottengono punti vittoria. Bravo il giocatore che riesce a conservare i propri seguaci per le fasi più calde della partita... 
CARCASSONNE - Un gioco di strategia semplice e duraturo, assicura sfide nuove ad ogni partita.

Contenuti:
72 Tessere Paesaggio
40 Seguaci in legno
1 Segnapunti
1 Libretto delle regole

RATING: 9
I like this game for all the reasons everyone else seems to. Its quick to learn and teach and there is no set up time. I have taken this to the school I teach in and it is great for a lunch time - you can start them off and within 5 minutes they are underway with only a few pointers or reminders. My own kids who are 7 and 10 like the fun of building the landscape itself, irespective of how it helps them win the game. I like the depth to the various strategies, the way people try to convince each other of where they should lay their tiles; mini alliences often break out between players and the fact that the winner can often be a suprise.

RATING: 4
A tile laying game. Very fun, light, and easy. A mix of worker placement and area control. However, it's too light to hold serious gamers' attention, and downtime and chaos are bad with more than 3 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[u]Key Words:[/u] Tile Placement - Area Control - Gateway - 2-5 Players - 45mins

[u]Summarized Opinion:[/u] Good, simple game. The lukewarm rating is primarily because it's lost its interest for me and nowadays I only play if I'm not up to something heavier (which happens only rarely). As a gateway, this game is easily a 9.

[u]My Rating Explained:[/u] Ok game, will play sporadically if in the right mood.

[u]Verbose Assessment:[/u]

This light tile placement game is great for beginning or casual gamers. It offers manageable options each turn and is easy to explain, while still interesting enough even for more experienced gamers. The game takes under an hour to play and down-time is minimal.

Expansions can be added to add a little more options to the game if so desired. Just be careful which you choose, they're not all good.

Fantastic as a gateway. Only ok if you're into heavier fare.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As of 10/06/07, this is still my favorite game and the only one I rate a 10.  Its just perfect, IMHO.

EDIT - As of February 13, 2008, I have another 10.  But this is still my all-time favorite.

EDIT - As of March 8, 2008, Carc has been replaced as my favorite game by Scripts and Scribes.  Its been a great run, but S&S just offers deeper gameplay with less luck.

EDIT - On July 14, 2010, the unthinkable happened.  I dropped Carc down to a 9.  I still thinks it's brilliant, but I really have no desire to play it anymore.

RATING: 8
yet another game from the "you must own this game" series. i'm so impressionable. i'll rate it after i play it a few times.
Played it several times now. I really like this game, not because it has great mechanics and causes me to agonize over decisions, although I like that in a game. The reason I like this game is because it's fun and easy. I can play it with anyone I know and everyone enjoys it. It scales excellent from two players up, though a two player game is a little different than three or more it's just as fun and challenging. IF we have trouble deciding which game we should play out of the few I own, Carcassonne will usually be played first. See the PC version at www.carcassonne-online.com

[b]The Goldmines[/b] :
[b]The Ferries[/b] :
[b]Hills & Sheep[/b] : 7 sheep are fun, vineyards nice and easy, hills no

[b]Update 9/14 : Our preferred big Carc game style

Meeples:7 base, Big guy, Mayor, pig, Phantom, Builder, Shepard, 

Add ins : Abbey, Castles, Bridges, Inns, Cathedrals, Vineyards, Sheep, Goods, River 1 & 2[/b]

Update 2012: has not held up for me. Okay to play if in the right mood with non-gamers, but otherwise has become a dull experience with too few interesting decisions that is also too long for what it is.

RATING: 8.36

I also enjoy the variant where each player has a hand of 5 tiles to choose from - in my view this speeds up the game and allows for some longer term strategy, lowering the luck factor slightly.

EDIT Sep-2011:  Nowadays I have the I&C, T&B and BC&C expansions.  Keen to get the other two main ones as well, P&D and A&M.

*Three years down the road and after playing many more games, this game is hardly put on the table anymore. The thought of laying tiles seem tedious now as the novelty wears off...Nonetheless, it is a fascinating game for anyone new to boardgaming.*

RATING: 7.5
A nice family game somewher between puzzle, ressource management (your meeples), chance calculation, luck-pushing, and "take that!" moments.
After having played with most of the expansions for ages, going back to just the base game was quite an experience. The base game on its own is much more cut-throat, as there are less tiles to fill "this certain gap" in your city... and as some combinations are not available at all, it's easier to block other players (and be blocked).

RATING: 7
A classic, of course, and the ideal game to pull out of the cupboard when you tell someone you play board games and they say "What, like Monopoly?" Colourful, simple, with nice solid meeple bits. Gameplay is light, but nonetheless engaging enough. A game of long-term efficency, wherin the small decisions add up to a long-term victory or loss. Expansions add greater depth and gameplay considerations.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I have this rated at a 5 because while I don't mind playing it, it's just not for me.  The game is highly praised, very accessible to new players, and contains enough strategic depth to interest veteran gamers for at least a few play throughs.  In short, you and other players score points for creating a landscape of cities, roads, monasteries, and farmland by placing tiles side by side like dominoes.  This game is fairly light and easy to play while chatting and talking.

However, I find the farm rule is very confusing for non-gamer since it's hard to define the border with some tiles (I.E: river), I did struggled with it when I first played the game before I was a serious gamer.

RATING: 6.1
Carcassonne is one of those intro games that keeps surfacing. I'll admit I didn't really appreciate on the first playthrough. The second time around I had a slightly better idea of what to expect, so it wasn't so bad. Still, a player's performance does seem unusally impacted by tile draw. That's probably because I don't quite understand what patterns I should be constructing to best leverage the probability space.

It's simple and fast, and I feel like I could learn more about it, but it does get edged out by more intricate games that I'm more familiar with.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Generally the people I have introduced to Carcassonne have enjoyed it, but after I introduce them to other games, it tends to fall by the wayside.  One problem I have is that I can never remember what the 'right way' to score cities is, there's so many various 'official' ways of doing so that I get them all jumbled.  I highly recommend playing where each player draws their next tile immediately upon placing their current one - this tends to cut down on analysis paralysis as people can decide where to place it while everyone else is playing their turns, and get stuck only if another player's placement changes the strategy on the board.

Revised January 2010 from 6.5 to 5.5 - I haven't played this in almost two years, and even the people I've introduced it to that liked it never even think of it.  It's like one of those games from days gone by that was once a shining star and is now pedestrian.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

"Carcassonne." And of course, I proceed to consider my life choices that have kept me from playing this cute strategic game. Played two rounds, lost both, but still had a marvelous time. Would wholeheartedly recommend.

RATING: 7
As the main game studier, buyer, player, etc. in my group of family and friends, I like games that other people like.  They just make it so much easier for me to get to play games.  I have found that most of my non-gamer friends and family take to Carcassonne easily, so I like Carcassonne.  There's more to it than that, however.  Even though it is a fairly light game, there is enough depth to keep me interested and having fun as well.  There are a lot of defensive moves that are not obvious at first glance, ever-shifting alliences are key, and blending a farmer into an important field always gets a bit of adrenaline flowing.  After having said all that crap about being the main game studier, let it be known that my wife almost always wins at Carcassonne.

New

Very fun game to play with any age group. Very Replayable.

Expansions add to the combination. The only expansion that I have added that I did not like was The Tower. Make the game too...Weaselly!

Carcassonne is the granddaddy of all tile placement games. It may not have been the first, but it is the Icon.

RATING: 7
The river expansion is rather lame.  Scoring the farms at the end of the game is sometimes tedious.  

We play using the rule where everyone starts with 3 tiles, then change the play order to "play a tile, draw a tile".  It works out pretty well and speeds up the game for 5/6 players since people can plan their moves out while waiting for others to play their tiles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Hm, this is a tough game to judge. While I think it's inherently likeable--there's nothing offensive here, and the tile-laying mechanic is soothing and fun--it simply doesn't capture my interest very well. It seems overly simplistic at times and there just doesn't seem to be much strategy in it--or rather, the strategy seems obvious. Still, it's very well made and pretty; a lot of people enjoy it for its simple and elegant rules. At the time I bought it, I was just venturing out into the hobby so it was the right level of complexity and depth for me. At this point, I like it mainly for new gamers and nostalgia's sake.

A classic I respect more than love.  I see the quality of design, but don't seem to enjoy it as much as others.  I don't think you should play with too many expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Quite a simple tile laying game but can be very strategic for the more experienced players. The idea is to lay tiles to form the board. Each time you lay a tile you have the option to put one of your pieces (Meeples) on that tile to try and get points later in the game. They can be on roads, cities, cloisters or farms. Even though you may have more points early in the game the main part of the scoring happens right at the end when some big scores can start happening.

I would recommend this for kids with autism as I see it a structured game. I would 1st teach it using only the tiles without the meeples to just get the idea of correct tile placement. I would then add just one type of meeple at a time in subsequent games (no farmers) until this concept was understood.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great game to pull out for the non-gamers. Even if they don't care about scoring points, building cities and roads with the pretty pretty tiles will keep them happy. Just expect some confused looks when you try to explain the farmer scoring. The play adjusts well from two players to more, so it is a great game to pull out for any number of players. My neighbor just brought it home from Germany. Since my wife loves it, I expect I will be playing it a lot! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I haven't played this game in years, but now I had a chance to do so again. Back then I thought this was a so/so game which I'd rate 5.0. Take it or leave it, there's better stuff out there. But now I really like the simplistisc yet very strategical choices of Carcassonne. The game works just great. As you can play this in a very short time, I would never turn down a game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
On the first few plays my wife and I loved this game, but as we racked up more and more games we became increasingly frustrated by the high luck factor involved.

Getting the right tile at the right time is crucial and you can easily get bogged down in waiting for that one piece to complete your personal jigsaw - and sometimes it never comes.

I still rate it highly, but we tend to play other games over this one at the moment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good gateway game, usually a success with non-gamers. With 4+ players is just a friendly filler without player elimination and quite relaxing. People tend to like the puzzle nature of the map.

Gets a lot more cutthroat if played 1 versus 1. The luck factor is reduced drastically, as you get to draw 50% of the tiles. Big cities lead to interesting fights to get control of them and the farms are key at the end of the game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Addictive.  I am always up for a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have found that games with up to 4P are quite enjoyable, while 5P games tend to be a bit crowded and hectic, which can be mildly frustrating. I've found that 2P games are a blast and enable you to carry out much more of a cohesive overall strategy than is possible in games with higher player counts. Because it scales so well for two AND offers a 30-45 minute play time, I find that it makes a perfect game for after dinner with the wife. 

Carc is an excellent gateway game, yet still manages to offer plenty of strategic depth. The concept of farmer scoring can be a bit difficult for those new to the game to understand, but it is usually quickly absorbed after the first game or two. Replayability is of course quite high due to the ever-changing nature of the "board", much less the myriad expansions available. This is a well-rounded game which possesses very high appeal, and it is one of my favorites, all things considered.

60 plays: I hadn't played this for many months, but playing again has made me realise what a good game this is. Rating increased to 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This rating is with the Inns & Cathedrals expansion.  Without the expansion I give the game a 9.

Very nice game.  I find it relaxing and fun, but still interesting and it really is fun building the cities and countryside.

My rating has gone up after about 20 plays.  

Everybody likes this game.  It is fun, pretty and there is actually a good medium-weight game there.

It is definitely best with 2, but it plays well with three and can handle up to 6 (w/I & C).  The more people you add the less  you can actually plan ahead, so the game because more about tactics and luck.

If I could have only 1 boardgame in my collection it would be this, even without I&C.  Mostly because it has been so universally popular with the people I've introduced it to.

Update:  My rating stays the same. This is the most played game in my collection because my wife loves it. I still think it is a great game, but Daytona 500 takes over as the game I would keep if I could only have one game. The rating will not likely go up, but could edge down as I approach 100 plays. 

Update: Carcassonne is now the one I'd keep. 




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 3
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 3
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 1
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3


Overall - 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Perhaps my least favorite board game ever, or perhaps my least favorite extremely popular board game.

Boring. That's as eloquent as I can put it. Large gaps between frontrunners and the rest result in de facto player elimination, making it not only boring for those poor saps, but an exercise in futility. This type of game should be no longer than an hour, but it's never taken less than THREE.

Poorly defined scoring. Uneventful turn-by-turn playing (i.e. nothing ever happens).

And for a game that relies so much on artwork...it's hideous. Like, really. An eyesore, to put it mildly.

Look, I admit I don't get the popularity. Guess I'm the wrong one. But really...I hate it.

RATING: 7
Wife and I play this quite a bit and enjoy it everytime. Simple, straight forward, tile laying game. Lay tiles, place meeples and collect points. Personally, I feel this game is best the more players that are in it. With 2 players, it gets stale quickly. Again, it's an enjoyable game, but the strategy aspect doesn't really shine for me. Imagine Kingdomino with meeples....so if you really enjoy tile laying games or love a no stress, layed back, low strategy game, it'll be a great game to add to your collection. In all fairness, it IS a classic game for a reason!

RATING: 8.5
:star: simple, straightforward rules make it very approachable for new players
:star: plays quickly, especially with 2
:star: offers plenty of decisions and player interaction
:star: it's fun trying to steal someone else's hard work
:star: plays five
:star: the abbot and gardens are a nice addition

:nostar: gets a bit too random with five
:nostar: this new edition doesn't come with a reference sheet listing all the tiles
:nostar: the abbot's ability to be removed at will is a bit of a rules wrinkle (it'd seem completely normal in a different game, but stands out in a streamlined ruleset like this)

RATING: 7.5
I grew tired of this game after it became a mainstay for "gateway" game groups. When my daughter turned 5 we introduced her to Carcassonne and this renewed our interest in the game. Buying the Big Box helped add some options. Setup and tear down do take a little time, and the game takes up a huge amount of play area, but overall this game has some serious replayability and is extremely versatile. It's well balanced and accessible to most who are willing to play a board game of any type. Few games get anywhere near the gameplay by my family as Carcassonne.

RATING: 10
This is my favorite game, and I play a ton of games. Setup takes literally 10 seconds if you know what is going on. Rules are relatively easy to learn and the strategy is easy to grasp but difficult to master. There is no game board, only a bunch of thick tiles with wonderful art and wooden meeple game pieces. Truly a great game to play with anyone! 

PS - if you have older family members who cannot read small print or symbols, this is the perfect game as there is no text involved. Just tiles whose art is matched with adjacent tiles.

RATING: 7
Its good.  It is not fantastic though.  I don't really care for the two player game as much as multiplayer.  That pretty much holds true for every game for me though.  Quick time play, and interesting decisions makes this a quick fun play for 3.  The map looking different and cool to look at is a plus.

This is a nasty 2-player game.  Vicious and cut throat.  Hosage rules high, unless of course both sides play nice, then its a nice light romp.

With 2 players I'll take the base vanilla carcassonne and get 2 rematches in for the light game fix.  I like busting out the City for games with more players.   Staying away from the expansions, because increasing the playing time does not strike me as a bonus.  I'd rather set up the rematch.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games of all times.  Scales WONDERFULLY from 2 to 6 players it's the same fun.  People who say they don't like this game make me wonder if they are playing passively becuase the game is not a passive game.  Even without expansions like Princess & Dragon and Tower it's a very aggressive game if played correctly.  Don't believe me, give it a go on BSW.

After a lot of agonizing over this I am going to move Carc. up to the coveted 10 rating.  After all this time of playing this simple little tile laying game I still get juiced up playing it. Any game that can do that deserves a 10.

UPDATE: Yes definitely made the right choice moving this to a 10. Fits all the criteria and after literal years of playing I'm still loving Carcassonne.
