RATING: 8.5
I just love this game and I bought every single expansion for it. It looks amazing, it plays fast and all players have about the same chance of winning no matter how experienced. Best with 4 or 5 players but also nice for 2 players. I always use the first expansion and one of the others when I play this with a group of 4 or more players. Using 3 or more expansions makes the game less enjoyable. For a gamer that likes to play complex games, its kind of strange that this game is in my top 10. Maybe its because this game got me into boardgames that I have a soft spot for it. But after 50+ games, I still enjoy it every time.

RATING: 10
After enjoying Settlers of Catan for many years, this was the second modern board game I bought, and I was surprised to find there was a game that I liked even better than Settlers.  I no longer enjoy the base game of Carcassonne on its own very much because I've become so used to playing with the Inns & Cathedrals and Traders & Builders expansions, which I consider essential at this point.  I have tried a few of the other standalone versions (e.g., Hunters & Gatherers, Castle, City), but have not been very impressed by any of them, and don't feel the need to own any of them, I even traded away the Castle despite high expectations with Knizia at the helm.  Finally, I think the naysayers of this game fail to play it as aggresively as it should be played, trying to steal opponent's cities/roads, and trap opponent's large meeple/builder.

See my review to read more at:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/133252

RATING: 6
Contrary to what some say, the field scoring in Carcassonne is superior to simple point counting spinoffs as it gives a nice tension to completing cities in fields you own.  However, there are too many dead end roads here that makes the end game usually devolve into who gets the resulting super-field.  Still good tile laying fun even if the hand size of one makes it feel like a game of Magic in top-deck mode.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Simple to teach, which makes it great for newbies, but it has enough strategy to keep it interesting for experienced board gamers.  The games aren't overly long, and there's plenty of opportunities to screw over your opponents.  Works very well as a two-player game, but scales really well too.  It's also a small box, which makes it a great option as a portable game to bring along on trips.  

Good quality durable components, and neat to look at as you gradually build the towns and roads.

It's somewhat luck based and not overly strategic, but there's enough features to keep it interesting, competing for farming space means you can get back into the game even if you fell behind, and the short game time keeps it light and non-frustrating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't think I've ever won, which isn't the game's fault, but it sure doesn't make me interested in playing.

RATING: 7
Well, it's true; the simplest games are often some of the best.  Carc is very easy to learn, but as with most great games you always seem to be learning new ways to win.  Was very impressed with the quality of the components, heavy cardstock with solid pieces.

I've coooled off on Carc a bit, not gravitating towards it as much as I did previously.  I think an expansion would probably rekindle some interest, but the base game & the river are wearing a little thin.  Still, a fun game that I'm always willing to sit in on.

RATING: 7
This game is very easy to teach. Which is great for 1st time players. A few addon's is necessary to add a great level of game play to the game. The farmers portion of the scoring is best if a house rule is used to make it simpler. If you aren't careful and add too many addons you will spend quite amount of time scoring the game in the end. It can be hard to know who is leading going up into the last few turns of the game. Solid tile laying game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a fun strategy game - the rules are straightforward and easy to understand, so you can get going with your first game quickly. Scoring is interesting - sometimes you end up with double the points you expect, and sometimes you feel you are doing well only to end up dead last. You can't rest on your laurels here, you have to keep looking for opportunities at every play. The artwork on the board is really pretty, and the game board and pieces are of good quality. The expansions included (river and abbot) introduce nice variety to the gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Carcassonne is wonderfully simple to understand (with a minor exception for the scoring of fields), yet is beautifully open-ended. The playing time is the same no matter how many people are playing, but as more players are added, the luck factor increases due to the randomness in drawing tiles.

Play count for this game includes plays of Carcassonne with or without the River 1 and no other expansions.

RATING: 8
Excellent tile paying game perfect for entry level. Never the same game twice, players take it in turns to lay tiles and put pieces on a board to build and complete structures. The rules are well-written and explained; it's only the farm concept that might take some time to sink in. Interaction os limited but you can try to muscle in on other people's structures and farms, although it can can require some careful and devious planning! The wealth of expansions available build on the principles and increase the length of the game. Why on earth we had to wait until the Traders and Builders expansion for a bag to draw tiles out of is beyond me though. I disagree with the price of the expansions - also, why so much packaging?!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My all time, go to game for 'modern' games.  It was one of my first modern games, and i STILL play this game a lot.  My copy is so well loved, the box is falling to pieces.

I have accumulated many xpacs along the way, but to be honest in recent years me and my group always play vanilla.

Vanilla Carc is one of the best games out there.  Love the tile laying aspect, love the simple premise of 'help yourself or screw an opponent - ideally both'  per turn.

An excellent game for noobs in 'modern' games.  The tile laying and worker placement is often so different to what they have played, that they find it really intriguing.

the ONLY (tiny tiny ) thing i dont super love is that Carc is a game where it is hard to keep pace with the scores...  in some games so much of the final result is counted up post game, that you lose that 'race/keep up/overtake' excitement.

RATING: 7
Extremely good gateway-game which uses clever tile-laying mechanism. It also has so many expansions that if like it you can literally play it with 100 different expansion mixes. I recommend that while playing players should always take a new tile automatically when they have placed the previous to the board, this makes the game a lot faster and reduces downtime enormously. The reason why I give it only 7 is because it is quite light on strategy when you have played it a lot and my group has definitely "exhausted" it with probably 50+ games (same with Dominion).

RATING: 5
This was our gateway game. Played 30+ times before we discovered other Euro's. Guy brought it to work and lunches were never the same again. We loved it but started to want to try variants and also bought all the expansions. Now really only play with my son. Adult games are all about placing tiles to hurt the other players. When I play with my son, I play being totally cooperative. Really is interesting on the strategies. My wife rarely wants to cooperate and loses by a wide margin everytime. Still interested in playing, but pretty much only when children are playing. At first it was hard to rate this game this low since we did play it 30+ times, but we didn't know better. It was hard to move to another game (didn't know better) but once we did, we never came back to it. Update: still play this... got my grandmother to play... go intro game (without the farmer rule), beats Uno.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Carcassonne is a tile-placement game in which the players draw and place a tile with a piece of southern French landscape on it. The tile might feature a city, a road, a cloister, grassland or some combination thereof, and it must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played, in such a way that cities are connected to cities, roads to roads, etcetera. Having placed a tile, the player can then decide to place one of his meeples on one of the areas on it: on the city as a knight, on the road as a robber, on a cloister as a monk, or on the grass as a farmer. When that area is complete, that meeple scores points for its owner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There is something relaxing and very satisfying about laying the tiles down and building a town together. A laid back gaming experience, not super competitive. I can see how it is considered a classic Eurogame.

RATING: 7
Rating and comments based on 2 player play.

Pros: 
+Easy to learn and teach; good gateway game
+Easy setup
+Deeper than it seems at first glance
+Despite becoming repetitive fairly quickly, "fun" factor seems to remain due to casual nature of game

Cons:
-Once strategy understood by both players, more of a luck-based game
-Limited depth relative to other tile-laying games

Other things to consider:
:Fairly high luck component based on tiles drawn.  But on average, it works out.  :Games are short and relatively casual so increased luck may not be an issue for those avoiding a high luck factor.

RATING: 9

2005
Ok, I am a carc junkie!  The more you play it, the more evident the potential for strategic play becomes - there is a learning curve in this regard.  Yes, there is a luck factor, but it all tends to average out over the course of a game, especially once you have enough experience to avoid the things that cost you a game, such as putting down too many farmers, having 4 meeples in a single town, etc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Attractive looking family game with quite a bit of randomness, but still some nice tactical decisions. Not sure if its appeal will last up to the point where some players are able to count the number of different shapes on the table and estimate which tiles are still to come. In my opinion, it is best played as a light game in which the randomness of the tile drawing is accepted and players need to make the most of what they get. Most of its expansions make the game longer and unnecesarily complex. Just add the first expansion (Inns & Cathedrals) and you have all the variation you will need without moving too far away from the original concept.

RATING: 6
05/2009:6
The game is fun but with the "wrong" type of players, this game can quickly degenerate into something really brutal. Pieces of cities can be added randomly on your opponent's cities to prevent completion of cities. This has turned off many players who abhor conflict. Still, this is a classic game and I won't turn down a quick game.

RATING: 10
Carcassonne is a "10" as long as the Inns & Cathedrals is included.  This plays best as a 2 player game- more than 2 and it becomes a simple tile laying game.  This can be played friendly or cut-throat.  How much larger should I make my city?  Can I steal this road?  When do I lay down a farmer? A bunch of great decisions.  Plus you have a beautiful map when you are finished.

RATING: 5
I will always look back fondly on my time with Carcassonne. It was my first purchase and foray into modern board games. With time though, I've proceeded into heavier territory and this stopped getting any plays. 

Great gateway game with a bit more tactical bite once you have a feel for the tile distribution. Really enjoyable with 2 and works as a light gateway game for larger groups.

Farmer scoring is mildly tricky but they iron out after the first game.

RATING: 7
Carcassone is really simple but that is also its strength.  My 6 year old nephew can play with us treating it like a puzzle while everyone else can focus on scoring opportunities.  My main concern with the game is that the farm mechanic seems like it impacts the final score too highly (which almost feels out of place given the low complexity of everything else in the game).  A well-placed farmer early in the game (even just being on the initial tile) has greater scoring potential than any meeple placed afterward.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I realize Carcassonne is popular.  I try to grade games on what they bring to the table, not what they aren't.  No doubt Carcassonne has brought a lot of people into the hobby.  

That said, I just think there are far too many tile games that are more interesting.  I would recommend Alhambra over this game times ten.  I'm certain that the Alhambra Big Box would be more played and more enjoyed by most average people than Carcassone and its best expansions.  

Carcassonne almost drove me away from all tile laying games.  I tried several times to like it, but it just never felt that interesting.  I only reluctantly tried games like Alhambra and Fjords . . . and realized I didn't have a problem with tile games, I had a problem with just Carcassonne!

Carcassonne, like Catan, deserves its place in history. But just like Settlers, better games have come along.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 7.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Carcassonne accomplishes exactly what it sets out to accomplish - it is, like it says on the back of the box, a "simple tactical game". I think this is what people who complain about the randomness of the draw involved miss entirely - it's not intended to be Ora et Labora. I rate it so highly because it accomplishes this very, very well. 

The beauty of it is how the level of competitiveness scales to your playgroup. It can be played in a laid-back way with casual gamers and relatives, a sort of semi-collaborative puzzle where much of the enjoyment is derived from observing the gradual growth of your bucolic French countryside. It can also be a cutthroat battle to the death for 30 point cities and farms. It doesn't force either of these split-personalities on you - it is what you make of it. 

It is simple, elegant, and can be played with practically anyone.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic for good reason. Simple, elegant gameplay that provides a nice sense of accomplishment throughout the game for all players with a dash of 'gotcha' for players that want to play aggressively. Something for every gamer. It will be interesting to see whether others in my family start to get more aggressive, get better defensively, or lose interest...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Great tile-laying gateway game-- I prefer TtR just slightly over it, but I find this game easier to explain and less stressful for others to play.

Trying to predict farmer scores is a pain in the butt, though-- a lot easier when they're animals instead (Hunters and Gatherers is easily my favorite Carc)

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Can be played cut throat or friendly.  There is some deeper strategy to access in this otherwise simple looking game.  You can use "dud" draws to block off other people's features making them hard to complete.  You can score huge swaths of points by cooperating with other players.  You can backstab people by stealing their giant castles.  You can craftily connect fields to scoop up all of the farmer points.

It would be higher if there was a little less luck of the draw.  1 or 2 bad draws in a row are OK because you can use them to sabotage other players.  But drawing a road for the 5th time in a row is rather annoying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Build the Carcassonne country side by laying tiles and place "Meeples" to score the highest total. One of the quintessential "Gateway Trilogy" (along with TtR and original Settlers). Quick to set-up, good quality components (sturdy tiles with functional graphics, cute meeples), and well designed. With all the expansions out there, I still like the original best and don't mind adding those that don't change the flavor of the original too much: the river I & II and Inns & Cathedrals. I play with 3rd edition rules but score "football" cities as 2pts.

RATING: 8
Turns out we've been doing the final scoring wrong all these years.  We weren't scoring incomplete roads and cities.  Wasn't that much of a big deal and we even miss being able to keep making an enemy city larger and larger just so it won't complete.

The games are turning vicious and foul words are starting to appear....

Now that we've had a chance to play with 3, 4, 5, and 6, we're pleased that the game handles all the player counts well.  It plays differently, but is still good.

We're also impressed that some non-gamers have taken a liking to it.  I've considered giving it a 9 but going by the text it's not quite an "always want to play."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pretty dull with just the base set, but all the expansions really transform this game into a rich and multi-faceted experience.  I love the fact that the base rules are so simple you can play it with anyone (I've taught 7 year olds the game who have loved it).  By adding on expansions, you can then increase the complexity and help young or new euro-gamers ease into higher complexity playing.  

Also, the game can be incredibly interactive with the expansions in a screw-your-neighbor kind of way, but its such a pleasant, fast-moving game it never gets personal (in my experience, anyway).  Just a blast to play and worthy of it's popularity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Maybe I'm still stuck in my board-gaming infancy, but I love this game.  It's probably the most enjoyable game my fiance and I play together, I love it for 2 people as it's much easier to set up your strategies and block the other player.  With the addition of the big meeple from an expansion, you really have some strategic choices to strong-arm the other player and try to steal their buildings.

I really enjoy the fast-pace, quick-turns, and satisfaction of looking at the unique board you created each game.

The reason it stays highly rated with me is that it's just so easy to jump into and play.  Want to play? Okay, grab the bag and pull out a tile.

Have to admit, it's starting to slowly drift down in rating though, as I get more games that I'm more anxious to play.

RATING: 4
I picked this up after I read so many good things about it.  I was very disappointed.  This isn't a gateway game, it's just a children's tile-laying game.  The strategy is overly simple, and eventually comes down to memorizing the tile distribution -- Blech!  I've tried using it as a light gateway, but have had very limited success.  Most people I know just kinda look at me funny at the end and say "That's it?"  And god help you if you decide to play with more than three players, as the game drags on with no end in sight.  The rules are minimal and pretty easy to grasp, and the feel is familiar, which is the only explanation I can find for its popularity.  As someone who is entrenched pretty firmly in the hobby, though, it doesn't get me.  Pass.

RATING: 7
Rated after 19 confirmed games. The game is not at all bad, but it is getting a little bit boring and it seems that there is always something nicer to play. But if this would be the only game around, I would have no problems playing this. There is something in that simplicity, it might be called genius or something... But in the end, may be a little bit too simple.

Updated almost four year and couple of games later: Not a bad game, once I have survived the small "cult of the new" phase, I have realized that there is place and time for good old games. There will be good games made in the future, but also lots of bad games. The mechanics are same, no new ones are coming every year and so on. Game is a classic, easy to teach and play, enjoyable also with non-gamers and a two player game can be finished in half an hour. I need to play this more in the future.

5 duels during Christmas, a simple and quick game which offers tactic choices. When played in about 30 minutes it is quite a nice filler.

22 duels recently, some with expansion, some with just the base game. Good game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Summary:[/b]
Fantastic tile-placement game for families and couples. If I only had one family board game to play, I'd choose Carcassonne, Agricola, or Bohnanza. If I only had one tile-laying game for two players, I'd choose Akrotiri instead. Carcassonne is fun and can be long or short. It's easy to learn and works with different kinds of players.

+ Straightforward. Good for families. Good for couples. High quality. Good longevity.
- Can be too long and AP-prone with larger adult groups. (Use a timer if needed.) No one is forced to use spite/aggression, so one player might be frustrated when another player chooses to.


[b]Rules:[/b]
The rules are very simple and easy to learn. The rulebook is clear.

[b]Components:[/b]
Components are straightforward but of good quality with clear, slightly interesting art. Ours have lasted without any damage whatsoever through MANY plays.

[b]Theme:[/b]
Generally works. It's about laying out a countryside with little villages, cities, roads, etc. (and more depending on expansion use.)

[b]Luck:[/b]
There is a constant luck of the draw, since this is a tile-laying game in which tiles are drawn from a stack rather than purchased from an auction. You may place them nearly anywhere, however, which greatly mitigates this luck. Decisions are more important than the draw.

[b]Interaction:[/b]
There can be a fair amount of interaction if players decide to focus on laying tiles in such a way that other players cannot complete their plans. For friendlier players, the game feels like solitaire building or even coop building. There will usually be ONE player in a group of 4 or more who thinks more interactively than the others, but this has always been fun in my experience rather than upsetting anyone.

[b]Strategy:[/b]
Long-term planning is essential for most players in most games, mostly due to the luck of the draw. If you start a big city, you may not be able to complete it for quite a while. If you decided to farm, you need to make sure cities are built around it.

[b]Tactics:[/b]
Tactics may seem minor in Carcassonne, but they come into play often. Placing city tiles near someone else's city might allow you to take over, or at least prevent them from completing a city. This choice often trumps the possibility of expanding your own city and getting points for doing so.

[b]Analysis Paralysis:[/b]
Everyone seems to experience some AP in this game until they're used to it. Even then, a few turns will have AP due to too many options for a tile or due to the noticed options not having clear advantages over each other.

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
Very easy to learn and play. It's not that hard to master, but somehow manages to be fun after many plays.

[b]Length:[/b]
Depends on the number of players. It is often long but really doesn't need to be. I recommend playing with a timer to make it a little more exciting and speedy. This isn't necessary though, unless you're playing with a very AP-prone player.

[b]Replayability:[/b]
I eventually grew a little tired of Carcassonne after many plays. I needed a break. Now that I've had the break, I'm ready for more. Expect this to have more longevity than most games in your collection if you have the right players in your group. It's excellent for parents to play with their children, for example. I'd primarily recommend it for that and for couples. Buy the Big Box for more variety and complexity.

RATING: 6
I give Carcassonne credit where credit is due: brilliant concept of building the board like a puzzle as the game progresses; also, a pretty solid "gateway" Euro game.  It also introduced the "meeple," which has become the icon of the board gaming community.  But Carcassonne is far from perfect.  The scoring is jacked.  Certain elements (like farmers) are way too OP.  This game also gets way too cumbersome with the gagillion expansions.  I keep it around because it's a staple game, a cornerstone of modern tabletop gaming.  But it almost never hits the table anymore.

RATING: 4
I personally don't care for it a ton. I'll play rarely and I'm willing to give expansions a try to attempt to spice it up, but if I never play Carcassonne ever again, I'll be fine with that. 

One of my biggest complaints is the spiky cities that develop, and the way farms are scored/formed. Neither of those things are truly terrible, but they bug me enough to lower my enjoyment of the game overall. I've also had personal issues understanding some cases where spike edges of cities touch or come close to each other, and whether it forms a connected farm. Again, not a gamebreaker but it did affect my enjoyment. 

For a new/novice gamer, I think there are better light games out there like Ticket to Ride or King of Tokyo. For an experienced gamer, there are way better and prettier tile laying games that have come out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
Carcassonne is a tile-placement game in which the players draw and place a tile with a piece of southern French landscape on it. The tile might feature a city, a road, a cloister, grassland or some combination thereof, and it must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played, in such a way that cities are connected to cities, roads to roads, etcetera. Having placed a tile, the player can then decide to place one of his meeples on one of the areas on it: on the city as a knight, on the road as a robber, on a cloister as a monk, or on the grass as a farmer. When that area is complete, that meeple scores points for its owner.

RATING: 7
A bit luck-heavy for me these days, but one of the first modern board games I got to play, as it is for so many other people.

I enjoy the leisurely pacing, the theme and the fact that new players can still win thanks to luck of the draw.

I don't enjoy that knowing what tiles are possible makes such a difference to strategy. It's no fun either to have or not to have an advantage in that respect. And counting the tiles on the map and comparing them to the counts on the back of the box is not the done thing, so it's hard for somebody not to have an advantage.

Perhaps, I'm not playing this the "right" way. Anyway, I still like it and I'll play it if it is on the table but I probably won't suggest it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A clever tile-laying game. The southern French city of Carcassonne is famous for its unique Roman and Medieval fortifications. The players develop the area around Carcassonne and deploy their followers on the roads, in the cities, in the cloisters and in the fields. The skill of the players to best develop the area will determine who is victorious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The beauty of Carcassonne is in its plug and play expandability. There are piles of interesting expansions for this game, almost all of which can be added or removed without negatively impacting gameplay. In fact, using different combinations of expansions drastically alters gameplay strategies (and almost always in a good way). The game has never really gotten old, mainly because we are always trying new things with it. Every time Carcassonne hits the table, it is with a different combination of expansions. As such, every play is a whole new experience.

I also enjoy the fact that the game can be played as a relaxing social experience or a brutal gamer showdown. There is a surprising amount of screwage that can be passed around the table for such an unassuming little game, yet you can just as easily play nice and make pretty pictures. For me (and my group, for the most part), this is one of those rare games that has gotten better after every play. I remember being lost my first play and confused my second, then loathing even sitting down for my third game. After the scoring mechanisms had finally sunk in, I found myself compulsively wanting another play. It's a hit with my wife, my kids, and most of my gamer buds, What more could you ask for?

Recommended Variants: Always play with a starting hand of two or three tiles instead of simply drawing and playing off the top of the stack. This adds even more strategy and planning to what is already a deceptively deep game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating dropped to an 8 after playing Carc: The Discovery, which is a better game and also highlights some of the problems with this one.

This was my gateway game, and it's still one of my favorites (and one of the only games my wife and I both enjoy). I find the base game to be very relaxing and a nice balance of skill and luck. Another huge plus is that it can be played very cutthroat or nearly cooperatively depending on the preferences of the players, which gives it a lot of flexibility. About the only downside is that I've found one player drawing more than about 75% of the monasteries virtually guarantees victory, but that doesn't happen often. This may be the only game that I think all gamers should own, because it's such a wonderful introduction to the hobby; out of literally dozens of people I've introduced the game to, only 2 did not like it (and they both have admitted to disliking any game where it takes more than one sentence to explain the rules, so I don't think anything would've been a hit with them).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Don't like this game. How can you like a game where at your turn you get a tile at random and everyone knows what's the best place to place your tile? Sucks completely in 2-player, poor game ir 3-player, and only in 4-player starts to give some fun.
Update: I did not try this (already sold the game), but I think game would be much better by letting player to always have 2 tiles in hand, and then during his turn take third and decide which one of the three tiles he wants to place. Idea taken from Beowulf the Movie Game. Should bring more strategy and less pure luck. Should work especially well with Traders&Builders expansion - where you could plan ahead where to place your builder based on what tiles you have in hand.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Everyone seems to love this game, and I don't get it.  The appeal is that it's light, easy to understand, and good for new gamers who aren't that serious about getting into games.  But I am a serious gamer, and this game just has way too much luck involved.  It takes skill and strategy too, but because tiles are drawn randomly from the box each round, and that not every tile is of equal value, chance has a lot to do with who comes out on top.  And with the score board keeping track of who's in what place, it can be very very frustrating for the person in last place who keeps drawing "roads" while another player keeps drawing the one very specific tile she needs to complete her huge castle.  I don't have fun playing this game, I just find myself getting angry.

RATING: N/A
A light tile-laying game where players pull a tile from the pool and place it against one of the previously played tiles. If you start a city, road, farm or monastery, you can place one of your control markers on the tile, which is then scored when that feature is complete. However, farmers are not returned and will score points at the game end.

Awards
2000 Meeples' Choice Award
Winner of the 2001 Spiel des Jahres.
Winner of the 2001 Deutscher Spiele Preis.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.825
Classic and simple tile-placement game.  Place a tile so that it matches all other sides (like a jigsaw puzzle) and then claim a feature on that tile (a road, an abbey, part of a castle or a field), then the next person places a tile and claims a piece.  Simple but entertaining and a good choice of game if introducing someone new to boardgaming - minimal learning curve, quick and easy set-up, and not too long (if you don't include any expansions...) 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a really great gateway game. For me its most fun with 2 players, but it works well with more players too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1/21/2009: Last of my 1st shipment of BGG-favored games to be played. Included "free river expansion" but did not play with it the first time. Similar to Ticket To Ride, it was easy to learn and fun in the first session! In fact, it went quicker than TTR (though our first play was 2 players instead of 4 with TTR). This game definitely has a future in my home.

2/10/2014: And the above has certainly turned out to be true. Very recently introduced it to my 4 year old and played a coached play without using Farmers. He seems to like it.

RATING: 10

RATING: 8
We have had Carcassonne for about a decade now.  We don't play with any of the expansions other than sometimes the river expansion.  It is a great tile laying game.  To me this game is about the right time frame (30-40 mins) as well as the right level of complexity (on the lighter side) for what I like.  It is quick to teach in a few minutes with the farmers as the only complex concept that people struggle with the first game or two.  It really only takes a game for people to be close enough in skill level to have a reasonable game.

RATING: 7
What I Liked:
-Low learning curve.
-Minimal setup
-Enjoyed the light theme and game play

What I didn't like:
-Toward the end of the game, the game can become really basic, with the most efficient placement being obvious.  It can become a matter of who gets the best tiles.

Final Thoughts:  Great gate-way game with simple rules and minimal setup time.  Fun and interesting gameplay, most of the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The gameplay is easy enough.  The mechanic rules are about as simple as you can get.  But the scoring, particularly the farmers, can be tough to work out.  Of the 6 pages in the rulebook and supplementary example sheet, about 5 are dedicated to an explanation of the scoring.  There are plenty of FAQs for this game, and one of them explains the farmers simply:  if the farmer can walk to the city without crossing a road or leaving the tile borders, it counts.

Its simplicity is its elegance.  No two games are the same.  It plays great with two, and better with three.  Best of all, it's never too long.

RATING: 8
Un clásico de los juegos de mesa modernos. Se irá formando en el tablero de juego un mapa formado por losetas a modo de puzzle. En cada partida el mapa será distinto, lo que le otorga una gran jugabilidad. Los jugadores irán colocando sus "seguidores" por todo el mapa en las zonas que crean que les otorgarán más puntos. Sencillo de reglas pero con mucha más estrategia de la que parece.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My foray away from my roots and into more Euro games has finally led me here.  And I have to say... I like it.  Quite a lot actually.  It can be played in so many different ways and is open to different strategies, yet its simple tile drawing/laying mechanic allows even non-gamers to quickly grasps the concepts involved.  I have read a lot of comments about how confusing the farmers are but that has not been the case for my group.  I have also read that this game can be very cutthroat... ahem... that HAS proven to be true with my group.  And thats what I love about it.

Update - Still a staple and no sign of fading.  We now play without the river and with a hand of three tiles.  This combined with the abbey opens the door for a lot of combinations and pre-planned plays.

RATING: 7

UPDATE:

Now my girls age 10 are playing with farmer rules. They are still very excited about this.

I still enjoy this. It had seen a dropping off because I find it not very deep but I have had more people ask to play this and it has come into rotation again. Overall a pleasing game and I have started adding the better expansions in which give it a little more strategy.

RATING: 7
Definitely a staple game for people to check out when new to the boardgame hobby or to use as gateway game. I love to look back at how the game ended and how the world was shaped by the players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In combination with the Inns & Cathedrals expansion, Carcassonne is one of my absolute favourite games. It was the one that really got me interested in "geeky" games, and led me to BGG.

But to me, "vanilla" Carcassonne is good, but lacks something. Roads, especially, score too poorly, so that if you draw a lot of road tiles you'll probably lose the game. It only really achieves its potential once Inns & Cathedrals is added -- and compared to the cost of the base game, that's relatively expensive (though the combined cost is still a lot less than many games).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Base game is enjoyable, and quick.

Rating goes down exponentially if more than 4 players are involved. I think it's optimal with 2, and still very good with 3. I would opt out with 4 although I can see it being [i]decent[/i] with that many as long as turns go quickly.

I used to always play with I&C and T&B mixed in, but lately have picked only one major expansion to play with since tactics, tiles, and game length all seem to stay more fresh. Although we do include the K&S (excluding bonus mechanic) and Mini Expansion tiles in every game.

I prefer the base game with the Mini Expansion only or with I&C included. T&B is a good expansion but in a way over-complicates things for me. I like this is a quick, light game with subtle conflict; my personal opinion.

I've played a ton of the iOS version, typically 2 or 3 player games against strong or evil opponents only. The app is incredible.

RATING: 1
public class Carcassonne {

private int tiles;
private int score;

public Carcassonne() {
//Carcassonne. Not just for persons anymore!
tiles = 72;
score = 0;
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
Carcassonne game = new Carcassonne();
for(i=0;i/tiles;i++)
game.drawChurch();
}

public void drawChurch() {
//The secret to winning. Don't tell anyone!
score += 9;
}
}

RATING: 8
Modern classic. Everyone should own this game. I use the house rule of drawing your new tile at the end of the turn, instead of the beginning. This really speeds up turns as players have a chance to look at the board while waiting on their turn and usually know where to put their tile by the time it is their turn again. I just played this recently and it STILL holds up.

Artwork- 8/10
Theme- 6/10
Mechanics- 8/10
Fun- 8/10

RATING: 7

The only part about this game that can be a bit complicated is counting up the points at the end, you just have to pay attention.  Overall a fun game and it is pretty quick, maybe an hour or so.

RATING: 9
A 2-5 player tile-laying game. The southern French city of Carcassonne is famous for its unique Roman and Medieval fortifications. The players develop the area around Carcassonne and deploy their followers on the roads, in the cities, in the cloisters, and in the fields

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
COMMENTS REV 2 (11-10-8):

I've since discovered an ideal place for this game with children 4 to 10. They love it. It's structured block building.

COMMENTS REV 1 (Early 2011):

Me to 15yo dd: "I think I actually don't like Carcassone."

15yo dd: "I know.  I don't either.  It's totally boring. It's like the same game every single time, and if you're not playing with some one who's paying attention it's even worse."

Me: "Yes.  And nothing actually ever happens---just the plodding of your meeple around the point track, and then a settlement at the end.  It's like Scrabble without all the laughs."

15yo dd: "Totally."

I think it's the endemic problem of puzzle games.

My adult-like peers have tried to convince me that it's more cunning and subtle than that, but I'm not buying.  Carcassone is a flash in the pan.  Or we'll have to figure out how to add combat.

COMMENTS REV 0 (early 2010):

I get an Endorphin rush just thinking about playing.

There's no luck in this.  Randomness, yes.  But not such that will deter skill.  Use a handicap curve.

RATING: 6.8
An excellent gateway game.  My top pick for best gateway game right beside Ticket to ride.  This game is the king of tile laying games in my opinion due to it's simplicity.  Strategies are simple and if you play nice, you'll most likely lose, but still have fun doing so.  The expansions add so much to the game that I feel like they are an essential purchase.  Especially Inns and Cathedrals, as well as, Traders and Builders.  I enjoy Isle of Sky more because its a bit more of a gamer's game, but this one is a classic design that is timeless.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good game to pass the time. a bit boring, to be honest. There isn't much going on the board.

!!UPDATE!!

The more I play this game, the more I enjoy it and 3 years later and my opinion totally changed. I used to rate it at 6, but now I give it an 8. Why?

a) It's extremely simple to setup and teach.
b) It has an element of puzzle solving with endless variation. Every game is never the same. Different player offer different challenge.
c) It has good interactivity among players to guarantee any session will always be lively and lighthearted.
d) It has the perfect length. It's not too fast that you feel you haven't done anything, but not too long that the game overstay its welcome.

I'm one of those guy who rotates his collection a lot. Of all the light/medium game that I bought, Carcassonne is the only one I keep and will never be sold.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game!  My current favorite... expansions make it even better.  Quick setup and a replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very easy to pick up and play, rules are simple enough to explain even to my family and relatives who don't speak English.  The game is good with any number of players.  While the gameplay itself is fairly straight forward, with your ability to score largely depending on the tiles you draw, I think the most strategic element of the game is the farmer, which often give an amazing amount of points at the end of the game, without the player's realization.  Carcassonne is also great because of the amount of socializing it illicits, everyone gets to participate during anyone's turn.

Update #1: Game seems to take longer and longer after each successive plays, rather than the other way around (even with only one additional expansion).  Too much metagaming during other people turn for my taste, I try very hard to just keep my mouth shut and let them do what they want, but sometimes it is maddeningly frustrating when they take forever.  Especially annoying when someone goes I'll help you out if you do this for me.  This isn't a negotiation game!

RATING: 8
This was one of the first games I purchased. I really like it from the start: you could play it cut throat, but you could play it casual also. There are a ton of expansions here, I have a handful of them and I have to say... not all of them makes sense to me. It's a bit long if you include too much expansions (like more than 2) at the same time, and doesn't handle well a lot of people. With 2 or 3 it's quite a good game. With 4 it's sort of ok, but with more it becomes too random and chaotic.
We stopped playing this game lately which is a bit of a pitty. It's the favourite game of my sister.
Play count definitely not accurate, since I have played this before I discovered bgg.

Costed about 2400 HUF if I remember well.

RATING: 8.5
Part of Carcassonne: Big Box

I played Hunters and Gatherers before this, but I am glad my wife and I decided to invest in the Big Box with all the expansions.  We have already played each expansion separately and are looking forward to a mega-game with all of them!

Edit: The mega-game takes quite awhile and I find that we forget to utilize one or more of the features from the expansions (eg the fairy).  Still, it is fun for the fact that you get to see so many tiles down on the table.  I wouldn't play like that too often, but it is worth it once in awhile.

Edit: I am a little annoyed that the Abbey and Mayor expansion is coming out...

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
Easy to teach and fun to play. My gf loves it as it involves building up stuff amd has just about enough confrontation. Personally I like it more with less players: it makes for a more strategic and cutthroat experience.

Update (Aug 2012): after few dozens of plays with the base set I can safely support who says this is a classic. Games play smoothly one after another, and no game feels repetitive or boring. To me it's an experience like a good ole trustworthy card game (like Spades perhaps), but more fun thanks to the bits and flavor of the game. I'm starting to include expansions right now, so my current 8.5 could potentially grow.

Update (Dec 2012): still a good game, but a combination of factors has made me decrease substantially my desire to play it. I can still appreciate the elegance and smoothness of gameplay, although some gamble-aggressive players can make the game annoying with more than 2 people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Type: Area Control
Number of Players: 2-6
Sub-Type: City Building, Tile drafting, Tile Placement
Game Flow: (2 / 4) 
Gameplay: (4 / 6)

Game Length: Average (w/ Reduced Tiles)
Game Balance: Average
Strategy: Average
Luck Factor: Average (High w/out Variant)
Replay Value: High

Suggested Variants: 
a) Tile Drafting - Players draft from a common pool of tiles (Equal to the Number of Players), rotating who picks first each round.
b) Limited Expansions - For more balanced play, do not use the Princess and Dragon, The Tower, Catapult and Wheel of Fortune expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After 20+ Plays: Shines best as a 2-player.  I love the tension of when to place farmers.  Too early and you'll lose lots of small scoring opportunities.  To late and your opponent could monopolize a huge field, making all your work pointless.  Best with the first two expansions.

After 50+ Plays: I continue to suggest it and continue to enjoy it - in fact this is one of those classics that I feel I don't get to play enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I avoided this game for a while because I was worried it would bore me. On the contrary, it is quite an entertaining light game. There's enough strategy possible that I would play it several times without losing interest. At the same time it still feels light and is easy to engage new gamers with. Definitely an excellent gateway game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I think it's the better true gateway game over Catan. Experienced players are less able to strong-arm new players with bad trades, and it's easier to see the multiple strategies for victory. Showing new players the value of building cities, getting quick points with roads, stacking monasteries to minimize tile investment gets players up to speed with a lot of the mechanics than Catan which only offers negotiation and resource management. Plus, Carcassone offers some more overt 'take-that' by encroaching on opponent cities and sneaking farmers into other players lands. A+ gateway, B+ game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic tile-laying and area control game. Players draw tiles adorned with different features such as cities and roads, then place them onto the ever-expanding board. Features can be claimed using a limited supply of "meeples" and are scored once completed. Easy to learn but with a surprising amount of depth and nuance, it is best played as a two player game.

Theme: Medieval territory building
Mechanic: Tile placement / area control
Ideal players: 2-4
Length: Medium
